HEADLINE: Allstate Rebounds With Storm-Free Summer 

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Allstate reported a sharp increase in third-quarter profit yesterday after a summer with no hurricanes. Analysts said the results were a harbinger for a record performance by the property casualty insurance industry in 2006.
 The company, the second-largest home and auto insurer after State Farm, said it earned $1.16 billion, in contrast to a loss of $1.5 billion for the same quarter last year after Hurricane Katrina and other storms destroyed or damaged more than 300,000 homes and businesses insured by Allstate.
 ''It's a big rebound,'' said Adam Klauber, an analyst at Cochran Caronia Waller, an investment bank in Chicago. 
Edward M. Liddy, the chief executive of Allstate, said in an interview that strong results were producing excess cash and that Allstate was buying back $3 billion of its shares. Such a step often increases share value. 
 Allstate's stock closed down 19 cents at $63.30 yesterday. But that was a 14 percent increase from $55.75 on Aug. 1, when the industry's share prices began rising as fears of a bad hurricane season began to ease. On average, property insurance stocks were up 10 percent yesterday from Aug. 1, Mr. Klauber said.
 Insurance experts said last week that they expected record profits of $60 billion for the industry in 2006, up from $43 billion in 2005 even after paying for damage in Hurricane Katrina and other storms. 
 The insurers ended 2005 with a big gain because of strong investment earnings and exceptional profits on auto insurance, workers' compensation, general liability and coverage on homes away from the coasts.
 Allstate was the first property insurer to report third-quarter results. Over the next month, 40 property insurers are scheduled to report profits, said Brian Meredith, an analyst at UBS Securities.
 ''You're going to have very, very big earnings from the companies,'' he said.
 Allstate reported an annual profit in 2005 of $1.8 billion, mostly because of strong earnings on auto insurance, said Kevin Callahan, a portfolio manager at Century Funds in Boston, which owns 40,000 shares of Allstate. 
 Mr. Liddy said he expected record annual earnings for Allstate in 2006 of $4.8 billion to $5 billion -- about the same as Allstate's losses from hurricanes in 2005. Altogether, property insurers paid out $61 billion for hurricane damage in 2005. 
 Allstate and other insurers raised prices along the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico after heavy hurricane losses in 2004 and 2005 and forecasts for this year of about a dozen hurricanes. The worst storm has been Tropical Storm Ernesto, which reached hurricane strength briefly over water but hit land in Florida in late August with winds well below hurricane force. No major storms are expected in the remaining six weeks of the hurricane season.
 Prices for coverage for many coastal properties have tripled and quadrupled. Some have risen to more than 10 times higher than last year. 
 But analysts said they expected little or no declines and perhaps some increases because forecasters were still predicting another decade of powerful hurricanes. 
 Allstate has led home insurers in combining price increases with cuts in coverage along the coasts. In Florida alone, Allstate has refused to renew 215,000 policies. It is not renewing nearly 40,000 policies in New York. 
 Consumer advocates say prices on the coasts are excessive. ''Insurers like Allstate are using last year's catastrophes as an excuse to jack up rates and, at the same time, cut back coverage,'' said Birny Birnbaum, the executive director of the Center for Economic Justice in Austin, Tex.

HEADLINE: Run, Barack, Run

BYLINE: By DAVID BROOKS

DATELINE: Springfield, Illinois 

 BODY:
Barack Obama should run for president.
 He should run first for the good of his party. It would demoralize the Democrats to go through a long primary season with the most exciting figure in the party looming off in the distance like some unapproachable dream. The next Democratic nominee should either be Barack Obama or should have the stature that would come from defeating Barack Obama.
 Second, he should run because of his age. Obama's inexperience is his most obvious shortcoming. Over the next four years, the world could face a genocidal civil war in Iraq, a wave of nuclear proliferation, more Islamic extremism and a demagogues' revolt against globalization. Do we really want a forty-something in the White House? 
 And yet in his new book, ''The Audacity of Hope,'' Obama makes a strong counterargument. He notes that it's time to move beyond the political style of the baby boom generation. This is a style, he said in an interview late Tuesday, that is highly moralistic and personal, dividing people between who is good and who is bad.
 Obama himself has a mentality formed by globalization, not the S.D.S. With his multiethnic family and his globe-spanning childhood, there is a little piece of everything in Obama. He is perpetually engaged in an internal discussion between different pieces of his hybrid self -- Kenya with Harvard, Kansas with the South Side of Chicago -- and he takes that conversation outward into the world. 
 ''Politics, like science, depends on our ability to persuade each other of common aims based on a common reality,'' he writes in his book. He distrusts righteous anger and zeal. He does not demonize his opponents and tells audiences that he does not think George Bush is a bad man.
 He has a compulsive tendency to see both sides of any issue. Joe Klein of Time counted 50 instances of extremely judicious on-the-one-hand-on the-other-hand formulations in the book. He seems like the guy who spends his first 15 minutes at a restaurant debating the relative merits of fish versus meat.
 And yet this style is surely the antidote to the politics of the past several years. It is surely true that a president who brings a deliberative style to the White House will multiply his knowledge, not divide it.
 During our talk, I reminded Obama that at some level politics is about power, not conversation. He pointed out that he'd risen from nothing to national prominence in a few years so he knew something about acquiring power, but he kept returning to his mode, which is conversation, deliberation and reconciliation.
 The third reason Obama should run for president is his worldview. At least in the way he conceptualizes the world, he is not an orthodox liberal. In the book, he harks back to a Hamiltonian tradition that calls not for big government, but for limited yet energetic government to enhance social mobility. The contemporary guru he cites most is Warren Buffett.
 He has interesting things to say about the way culture and economics intertwine to create urban poverty. He, conceptually, welcomes free trade and thinks the U.S. may have no choice but to improvise and slog it out in Iraq. 
 The chief problem in his book is that after launching off on some interesting description of a problem, he will settle back, when it comes time to make a policy suggestion, into a familiar and small-bore Democratic proposal. I'd give him an A for conception but a B-minus for policy creativity.
 Obama, who is nothing if not honest about himself, is aware of the problem, and has various explanations for it. And what matters at this point is not his platform, but the play of his mind. He is one of those progressives, like Gordon Brown in Britain, who is thinking about the challenges of globalization outside the normal cliches.
 Coming from my own perspective, I should note that I disagree with many of Obama's notions and could well end up agreeing more with one of his opponents. But anyone who's observed him closely can see that Obama is a new kind of politician. As Klein once observed, he's that rarest of creatures: a megahyped phenomenon that lives up to the hype.
 It may not be personally convenient for him, but the times will never again so completely require the gifts that he possesses. Whether you're liberal or conservative, you should hope Barack Obama runs for president. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: How Far Past 12,000? Watch Data

BYLINE: By VIKAS BAJAJ; Jeremy W. Peters contributed reporting.

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 12,000 mark for the first time yesterday, but looking ahead, the stock market's performance in the coming year will largely hinge on how gracefully the economy handles the troubled housing market.
 The Dow squeaked by 12,000 after two weeks of gains, indicating that investors are increasingly confident that the economy is poised to perform the relatively rare feat of slowing without stalling. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a broader measure of the market, has also done well and is up 9.5 percent for the year. 
The Dow industrials closed up 19.05 points yesterday, at 12,011.73; the S.& P. 500 advanced one point, to 1,366.96; the technology-focused Nasdaq composite index gained 3.79 points, closing at 2,340.94; and the Russell 2000 index of smaller-capitalization companies rose 3.98 points, to 767.39.
 Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange exceeded those declining by nearly five to three. Big Board volume was about 1.63 billion shares, compared with 1.62 billion on Wednesday. 
 On the bond market, the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose to 4.79 percent from 4.76 percent, as prices declined.
 Among market optimists was Steven M. Roge, a portfolio manager at the Roge Partners Fund. ''It is the best of both worlds here,'' he said. ''We have interest rates that are still below the long-term average, capital is still flowing freely and growth is strong but not excessive.'' 
 But doubters say that may be too sanguine a view. Atop their list of concerns is the softening housing market and its direct and indirect effects on the economy. In addition to job losses in construction, finance and related fields, falling home sales and prices threaten to dampen consumer spending, which has been energized by low-cost mortgages and home equity loans.
 ''I am a little nervous that there is too much complacency,'' said Liz Ann Sonders, the chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab & Company. ''An overall economic soft landing is what is priced into the market. Believe me, I would love to get one, but soft landings are pretty hard to come by.''
 Other concerns include tensions in the Middle East and on the Korean peninsula. Those and other geopolitical matters could easily reverse the slide in oil and gasoline prices that started in August and helped lift consumers' spirits and their spending in the last month.
 The recent run-up in the market has favored large stocks, fattening the Dow, a dollar-weighted index of 30 blue-chip companies. Among Dow components, the technology giants Intel and Microsoft, which lagged early in the year, have had a good run.
 But some stock pickers see that strength as a worrying signal that large-company stocks may have become too expensive for the time being. More bullish investors say that such concerns remain hypothetical. In their view, stocks are fairly priced based on still-strong earnings reports and forecasts. The price-to-earnings ratios of stocks -- 17.8 for the S.& P. 500 and 22.5 for the Dow components, according to Bloomberg News -- are close to historical averages and far below the lofty levels of early 2000 in the technology boom. In the third quarter, profits at S.& P. 500 companies are expected to rise almost 14 percent from the period a year earlier.
 ''I think the direction of the market is up,'' said Scott Black, president of Delphi Management, an investment firm in Boston. Mr. Black said he did not foresee ''housing melting down completely'' and liked the prospects of energy and technology companies.
 Still, even many optimistic market watchers acknowledge that it may be unrealistic to expect corporate profits to stay on their current run -- earnings have risen by double digits every quarter for the last four and a half years. As of now, Wall Street is expecting that the profit machine will continue to mint money even as the economy slows.
 ''For U.S. equities to have a sustained move on the upside, we need earnings estimates to come down to a realistic level,'' said Robert C. Doll, vice chairman and global chief investment officer for equities at BlackRock, who is generally upbeat on stocks.
 Market experts also note that the rally over much of the last four years has still not been tested by a true correction, which is defined as a drop of 10 percent or more in the major indexes. The market came closest to that in the late spring and early summer, when the S.& P. 500 and the Dow each fell about 8 percent and the Nasdaq composite dropped 15 percent. Stocks fell harder and further in foreign markets, particularly in developing nations, and so did commodities like gold and oil.
 Since then, the market has risen steadily, following a well-charted pattern in which stocks do well toward the end of midterm election years, market specialists note. The difference this time is that the market started moving up in the third quarter, which has tended to be a weak stretch.
 ''You have to go back a very long way to find a negative'' performance during a midterm election year, said Sam Stovall, chief investment strategist at Standard & Poor's equity research. ''On average, you have a positive year 90 percent of the time.'' By his calculation, the average gain for the S.& P. 500 in the fourth quarter of midterm election years since 1945 is 7.6 percent.
 Mr. Stovall said he found it a ''bit disconcerting'' that stocks in the United States had not had a correction in nearly four years, but that he was beginning to think that as investing abroad had become more common, he should be satisfied that stocks around the world dropped more. The S.& P. Global 1,200 stock index fell 11.5 percent this summer.
 Another contrarian signal that cheers some market watchers for the longer term is that many investors remain ambivalent about stocks, based on sentiment surveys and mutual fund flows. Typically, markets are closest to a top when exuberance among investors is palpable.
 ''Investor confidence is still somewhat cautious,'' said Bruce Bittles, chief market strategist at Robert W. Baird. ''We don't have the extreme optimism like we had in the past. Until we get them invested, I think the market is going to keep going up.''

HEADLINE: You Can't Use That Tax Idea. It's Patented.

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
As the American tax law gets more and more complicated, lawyers have come up with one more way to make life difficult for taxpayers: Now you may face a patent infringement suit if you use a tax strategy someone else thought of first.
 ''I can't even imagine what it will be like in 5 or 10 years,'' said Dennis B. Drapkin, a tax lawyer with Jones Day in Dallas, ''if anytime a lawyer or accountant gives tax advice, they have to find out if there is a patent on this.'' He notes that researching patents, and then licensing them, would just make tax compliance more costly. 
Mr. Drapkin is chairman of a task force of the American Bar Association's tax section that will discuss the issue today in Denver. He said that after one conference where tax strategies were discussed, participants got a letter warning that using one idea mentioned would be in violation of a patent.
 Why would Congress pass a law allowing such a thing? The answer is that it did not. But a federal appeals court ruled in 1998 that business methods can be patented, and since then the Patent Office has issued 49 tax-strategy patents, with many more pending.
 There is even one case pending in federal court in Connecticut, in which an organization called Tax Strategies Group complains that John W. Rowe, the former chief executive of Aetna, infringed on its patent by using a certain type of trust to minimize taxes on profits from stock options. The group wants Mr. Rowe to be barred from using that strategy unless he buys a license from them.
 To patent lawyers, all this makes some sense. Others might see it as an example of judicial absurdity.
 But if it is legal, the mind boggles at the possibilities. Could I get a patent on taking a deduction for dependents, so that every parent in America would have to pay a royalty to me to take advantage of the tax law passed by Congress? 
 I presume the patent office would find that obvious, and thus not patentable, but there are plenty of slightly more complicated strategies that might be patentable, particularly considering the fact that patent examiners may not be tax experts.
 Indeed, Cheryl E. Hader, a partner at Ropes & Gray who represents Mr. Rowe, argues that the strategy he used was clearly authorized by the tax law and that no patent should have been granted.
 One can imagine lawyers and accountants rushing to the patent office as soon as a new tax law is passed, seeking to claim credit for dreaming up ideas that were made possible by the new law. Lobbyists who get tax breaks inserted into such bills would be in a preferred position to win the race to patent them.
 In an article in Legal Times this week, Paul Devinsky, John R. Fuisz and Thomas D. Sykes, three lawyers from McDermott, Will & Emery, suggested that a company might figure out a tax strategy that would save it a lot of money, and then patent it. Then the company could refuse to license the patent to its competitors, thus raising its rivals' cost of doing business.
 Tax patents, the lawyers wrote, amount to ''government-issued barbed wire'' to keep some taxpayers from getting equal treatment under the tax code.
 In an ideal world, Congress might pass tax laws so simple that clever strategies would be impossible and tax lawyers would need to find other employment. But until that happens, it would seem obvious that Congress would want to assure that all taxpayers are treated equally. 
 After all, as Mr. Devinsky and his colleagues wrote, ''The successful patenting of tax strategies now limits Congress' ability to shape economic policy through legislation, and places that power in the hands of individual patent holders.''
 But in Washington, such things are seldom simple. Asked what he thought Congress would do, Mr. Fuisz said action was possible, recalling that six years ago doctors got Congress to protect them from patent infringement suits over surgical techniques.
 But, he added, it will be a battle of interests. ''You will see the people making money off these patents lining up against those who dispense tax strategy advice,'' he said.
 So now we can have lobbying over whether all can benefit from what the lobbyists accomplished earlier.
 Ain't democracy great?

 BODY:

GOOGLE KEEPS ON GROWING -- Google, the world's largest search engine company, said that its profits nearly doubled from a year ago, maintaining a torrid growth rate at a time when rivals like Yahoo appeared to be faltering. Google said it earned $733 million in the third quarter, up 92 percent from a year ago. Revenue climbed to $2.69 billion, with 44 percent of that coming from outside the United States. [Page C3.] 


DOW ABOVE 12,000 -- The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychologically important 12,000 level for the first time, indicating that investors were increasingly confident that the economy was poised to perform the rare feat of slowing without stalling. The performance in the months ahead will depend, in part, how gracefully the economy handles the slowing housing market. [C1.]

BIG BANK EARNINGS -- Citigroup seemed to stumble and Bank of America appeared to strut through a messy third quarter as the country's two biggest banks contended with pressures of a slowing economy and higher interest rates. [C3]

CBS SETTLES ACCUSATIONS -- CBS became the first radio corporation to settle accusations of illicit pay-for-play practices made by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. CBS, which runs approximately 180 radio stations, agreed to adopt more stringent policies on its stations' dealings with record labels and to make a $2 million payment to New York charities. [C3.]

MEDICINE VS. MARKETING -- For many doctors, it's an irresistible pitch: a $250 profit from a 15-minute test. With that lure, some 12,000 of the nation's physicians have purchased an automated device that checks patients for nerve disease. Specialists say the problem is that many general practitioners are not qualified to do such tests. [A1.]

HIGHER PROFITS AT DRUG MAKERS -- Drug makers continued to post strong profit gains, led by Pfizer, the world's biggest pharmaceutical company, which reported that its third-quarter earnings had more than doubled from a year earlier. Eli Lilly, Novartis, and Wyeth also reported higher quarterly profits. [C2]

VIDEO GAME WARS -- Laying the groundwork for a battle against rival Microsoft, Sony said that 21 games would be available for the PlayStation 3 game console when it goes on sale next month. Sony also plans to highlight the console's ability to play high-definition DVD's in Sony's Blu-ray format. [C11.]

BANNER YEAR IN HONG KONG -- In a reflection of China's growing prominence in international finance, Hong Kong is set for a banner year in global markets with more money raised by companies selling shares to the public here than on the biggest exchanges in New York and London. Pricing will be set today for the world's largest IPO ever, that of China's biggest bank, Industrial and Commercial Bank of China. [C1.]

BEYOND REGULATORS' REACH -- Every month, roughly 19,000 households across the country write check to Christian Care Ministry. The members pool their health expenses and contributions and the ministry writes checks to health care providers. Such payments totaled $57 million in the latest fiscal year. While ministry members say they are helping to carry each others burdens, some Florida state officials see what they would call unregulated health insurance. [C1.]

RULING AGAINST GRASSO -- A New York judge ruled that Richard A. Grasso, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, would have to return as much as $100 million of a fiercely contested $139.5 million retirement payout to the exchange The judge, Justice Charles E. Ramos of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, said that Mr. Grasso did not disclose to his fellow directors on the board of the exchange the extent to which his soaring compensation had caused his pension and savings to balloon. [A1.]

MERGER REVERBERATIONS -- The $8 billion combination of Chicago's derivatives markets is being heralded as good for Chicago and good for the exchanges. But in Europe, it is raising concerns at banks and rival exchanges that it may increase costs or stifle competition. One of the biggest fears in London where the local derivatives exchange will be dwarfed, is that it creates a so-called vertical silo, or a market where one giant entity is both a trading platform and a clearing system. [C8.]

NBC STAFF CUTBACKS -- NBC said it planned to reduce its 6,000-person newsgathering staff by an estimated 5 percent, or 300 people to adapt to the migration of news viewers to the Internet and eliminate overlaps in news coverage. Steve Capus, president of NBC News, said the bulk of the cuts would come from eliminating jobs already vacant, as well as from early retirements and voluntary buyouts, but that some layoffs were inevitable. [C4.]

LOWER COST PROGRAMMING -- As part of the extensive cost-cutting program it announced yesterday, NBC intends to dramatically alter its prime-time programming, starting in the fall of 2007, filling the 8 p.m. hour each night of the week with lower-cost, unscripted programs and saving its more expensive scripted comedies and dramas for the 9-to-11 block. [C1.]

WEAK NEWSPAPER PROFITS -- Newspaper companies continued to show weakness, with The New York Times Company and the Tribune Company both reporting lackluster earnings, citing soft advertising sales as a major culprit. At the Times Company, the slowdown ''is expected to continue through the end of the year,'' said Janet L. Robinson, the company's president and chief executive. [C7.]

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; ADVERTISING; Pg. 7

HEADLINE: To Explain Soft Numbers, Newspaper Companies Name a Common Culprit

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JEREMY W. PETERS

 BODY:
NEWSPAPER companies continued to show weakness yesterday, with The New York Times Company and the Tribune Company both reporting lackluster earnings, citing soft advertising sales as a major culprit.
 At the Times Company, the slowdown ''is expected to continue through the end of the year,'' said Janet L. Robinson, the company's president and chief executive.
The Times Company reported a 39 percent drop in profit for the third quarter compared with the same period a year ago. In addition to being hurt by sagging ad revenues in several categories, the company's results were pulled down by continuing economic weaknesses in New England, where the company owns The Boston Globe. 
 The Tribune Company managed an increase, thanks primarily to a one-time gain. Excluding this gain, however, the company's earnings fell short of Wall Street's expectations by about 2 cents a share. Tribune's stock price rose a penny yesterday, to $32.91.
 On Wednesday, Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal, said its third-quarter earnings rose because of a tax gain. Not counting that gain, earnings slipped to $9.4 million, or 11 cents a share, from earnings of $10 million, or 12 cents a share, the year before. It also said that advertising revenue at The Journal fell 5.9 percent in September compared with the previous year. The company said its volume of advertising decreased 8 percent, ''due to declines in the technology, classified, general and financial categories.''
 At the Times Company, net income for the quarter fell to $14 million, or 10 cents a share, from $23 million, or 16 cents a share, from the same period last year. Total revenues declined 2.4 percent, to $740 million.
 Revenue from advertising for The New York Times Media Group, which includes The New York Times, nytimes.com, The International Herald Tribune and IHT.com, fell 4.1 percent, and revenue from circulation was down 0.3 percent. Advertising revenue for The New England Media Group, which consists largely of The Globe, tumbled 12.4 percent and revenue from circulation fell 5.7 percent.
 Asked in a conference call with financial analysts if the Times Company had considered selling The Globe, Ms. Robinson said that it was company policy not to comment on such matters. ''That said,'' she added, ''we view The Globe as an extremely important asset to our overall portfolio, and we've taken great steps to improve its performance.''
 She said part of the problem in Boston had been weaker classified advertising in print, attributable in part to the consolidation of department stores. But she said she expected better news as other major stores opened. In addition, The Globe has allowed advertising on the front of its sections, she noted, and can expect higher revenues from a new zoned auto section and a glossy magazine on design.
 Alexia S. Quadrani, a media industry analyst at Bear Stearns, who had asked about The Globe, said in an interview later that The Globe had been ''such a drain on the company's overall finances for so long'' that a short-sighted investor might wish The Times would sell it. She said she took from Ms. Robinson's response that the company could eventually do so, but would not in the near future. 
 Ms. Quadrani said The Times was probably keeping The Globe because the company expected the Boston market to improve and because the company was busy selling its television stations and building up its digital business. Moreover, she said, The Globe is at ''a low point'' and would probably not bring a strong return. The Times Company paid $1.1 billion for it in 1993. Selling it would also have tax consequences. 
 While the New England group lost revenue from advertising and circulation, it increased other revenues more than 18 percent, largely from commercial printing. The Worcester Telegram & Gazette, a Times Company paper, prints Metro Boston, a free daily, as well as The Daily News of New York; in June, The Globe began printing The New York Post.
 Tribune, which owns The Los Angeles Times, Newsday, The Chicago Tribune and The Baltimore Sun, reported net income of $162.2 million, compared with $21.9 million a year earlier. But revenue for the company fell, declining 2.5 percent from a year earlier.
 Tribune said it benefited from reworking two partnerships with the Chandler family, its biggest shareholder. A recent agreement with the Chandlers increased their stake in the company to about 20 percent, from 15 percent, and yielded the company a $48 million gain after taxes, accounting for one-third of the company's net profit for the quarter. 
 At the Times Company, the cost of job cuts and the sale of its stake in the Discovery Times Channel shaved about 6 cents off per-share earnings. Without those charges, the company would have earned 16 cents a share, well ahead of Wall Street estimates of 12 cents a share for the quarter, and would have kept its earnings flat. The company's share price fell by 51 cents yesterday, to $22.74.
 Internet-related revenues for the entire company continued to climb, and accounted for 8.5 percent of revenues in the third quarter, compared with 6.7 percent a year ago, Ms. Robinson said. Also, revenues from about.com increased 29 percent, to $18.3 million.
 Both the Times Company and Tribune Company expect to reshape their businesses. The Times Company announced last month that it planned to sell its Broadcast Media Group, a profitable collection of nine television stations that will bring in about $150 million in revenue this year.
 In response to an analyst's question about whether the company might consider a leveraged buyout, Ms. Robinson said the company has two classes of stock, which safeguards it from an unwanted takeover. ''Only the Ochs-Sulzberger family, which owns 20 percent of the equity of the company, can change the capital structure,'' she said. ''They have given no indication that they plan to do so.''
 Tribune said last month it was exploring selling some or even all of its 11 newspapers and two dozen television stations. The Tribune board agreed to consider breaking off some of its assets after coming under pressure from the Chandler family. 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 24, 2006

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column on Friday, about quarterly earnings for the Tribune Company and The New York Times Company, gave the incorrect name in some copies for a newspaper that The Times owns and operates as part of its New England group, a division that lost revenue from advertising and circulation but increased other revenues, largely from commercial printing. It is the Worcester Telegram & Gazette, not the Wooster Telegram & Gazette.
