Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section E; PT1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk; THE LISTINGS: Oct 20-Oct.26; Pg. 25

LENGTH: 16037 words

 BODY:

Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week. * denotes a highly recommended film, concert, show or exhibition.

Theater

Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current shows, additional listings, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/theater. 


Previews and Openings

'BHUTAN' In previews; opens on Oct. 29. Witness the ups and downs of a New England family in Daisy Foote's new play (1:20). Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, between Barrow and Bedford Streets, West Village, (212) 239-6200.

'BUTLEY' In previews; opens on Wednesday. Nathan Lane plays an embattled professor in this Simon Gray comedy, which was a hit at the Huntington in Boston (2:30). Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200.

'THE CLEAN HOUSE' In previews; opens on Oct. 30. The MacArthur grant winner Sarah Ruhl's fantastical romantic comedy is about a well-heeled Connecticut family that hires a maid who would rather compose the perfect joke than clean (2:15). Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200.

'THE COAST OF UTOPIA: VOYAGE' In previews; opens on Nov. 5. Tom Stoppard's three-play epic about the forebears of the Russian Revolution begins with ''Voyage,'' set in 1833 in the Russian countryside. The all-star cast includes Billy Crudup, Ethan Hawke, Jennifer Ehle, Richard Easton and many, many more (2:45). Vivian Beaumont Theater, 150 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 239-6200.

'DR. SEUSS'S HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS: THE MUSICAL' Previews start on Wednesday. Opens on Nov. 8. You loved the book. You hated the movie. Now see the musical (1:30). Hilton Theater, 213 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100.

'GREY GARDENS' In previews; opens on Nov. 2. The Playwrights Horizons's musical adaptation of the Maysles documentary moves to Broadway (2:40). Walter Kerr Theater, 219 West 48th Street, (212) 239-6200.

'THE INTERNATIONALIST' In previews; opens on Nov. 7. This new play by Anne Washburn (''Apparition'') is about an American businessman making do abroad (2:00). Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street, (212) 353-0303.

'MARY POPPINS' In previews; opens on Nov. 16. Disney looks to find its old magic touch with this new blockbuster, which transfers from London with good buzz. Richard Eyre and Matthew Bourne direct (2:30). New Amsterdam Theater, 214 West 42nd Street, (212) 307-4100.

'MIMI LE DUCK' In previews; opens on Oct. 31. A Mormon housewife leaves her husband, Idaho and a QVC Network job for a new life in Paris in this comic musical (2:05). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200.

'LES MISERABLES' Previews start on Tuesday. Opens on Nov. 9. And you thought the romance was over. Three years later, the famous revolve returns to Broadway (2:55). Broadhurst Theater, 235 West 34th Street, (212) 239-6200.

'MY DEAH' In previews; opens on Wednesday. John Epperson -- a k a Lypsinka -- offers his inimitable take on ''Medea'' (1:30). Abingdon Theater, 312 West 36th Street, (212) 868-4444.

'POST MORTEM' In previews; opens on Nov. 2. A. R. Gurney goes meta in this new play about political repression set in the not-too-distant future, when a new work by an obscure writer named A. R. Gurney is discovered. Jim Simpson directs (1:30). The Flea Theater, 41 White Street, TriBeCa, (212) 352-3101.

'REGRETS ONLY' In previews; opens on Nov. 19. The Manhattan Theater Club presents the world premiere of Paul Rudnick's new zinger-filled comedy of manners set in high society (2:00). City Center Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, (212) 581-1212.

'A SMALL MELODRAMATIC STORY' In previews; opens on Tuesday. The Labyrinth Theater Company presents a new play by Stephen Belber (''Match''), about a widow who falls in love with a policeman with a history that she might not want to know about (1:40). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555.

'SUDDENLY LAST SUMMER' Previews start today. Opens on Nov. 15. The always lovely Blythe Danner stars in a revival of Tennessee Williams's brutal psychological drama. Mark Brokaw directs (1:30). Laura Pels Theatre, 111 West 46th Street, (212) 719-1300.

'THE SUNSET LIMITED' Previews start on Tuesday. Opens on Oct 29. The novelist Cormac McCarthy's new play is about an ex-con and an intellectual atheist who meet on a subway platform. Austin Pendleton stars (2:00). 59E59 Theaters, 59 East 59th Street, (212) 279-4200.

'THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN' ' In previews; opens on Thursday. Bob Dylan has come back in vogue just in time for his Broadway show, staged by Twyla Tharp (1:30). Brooks Atkinson Theater, 256 West 47th Street, (212) 307-4100.

'THE WILD DUCK' Starts on Wednesday. Closes on Oct. 29. The National Theater of Norway celebrates the 100th anniversary of Ibsen's death with a new production of his masterpiece set in the 1950's (2:00). Brooklyn Academy of Music, Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100.

Broadway

'A CHORUS LINE' If you want to know why this show was such a big deal when it opened 31 years ago, you need only experience the thrilling first five minutes of this revival. Otherwise, this archivally exact production, directed by Bob Avian, feels like a vintage car that has been taken out of the garage, polished up and sent on the road once again (2:00). Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Ben Brantley)

'THE COLOR PURPLE' So much plot, so many years, so many characters to cram into less than three hours. This beat-the-clock musical adaptation of Alice Walker's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about Southern black women finding their inner warriors never slows down long enough for you to embrace it. LaChanze leads the vibrant, hard-working cast (2:40). Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'THE DROWSY CHAPERONE' (Tony Awards, best book of a musical and best original score, 2006) This small and ingratiating spoof of 1920's stage frolics, as imagined by an obsessive show queen, may not be a masterpiece. But in a dry season for musicals, it has theatergoers responding as if they were withering houseplants finally being watered after long neglect. Bob Martin and Sutton Foster are the standouts in the avid, energetic cast (1:40). Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

'JAY JOHNSON: THE TWO AND ONLY' A genial 90-minute entertainment giving Broadway audiences a chance to get reacquainted with the (almost) lost art of ventriloquism. Jay Johnson, the onetime star of the television comedy ''Soap,'' gives a pocket history of the profession, in addition to an ample demonstration, with partners that include a vulture who sings ''My Way,'' a foul-mouthed wooden tyke, a talking tennis ball and a monkey purveying some of the corniest shtick this side of a Friar's roast (1:30). Helen Hayes Theater, 240 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200.(Charles Isherwood)

'JERSEY BOYS' (Tony Award, best musical, 2006) From grit to glamour with the Four Seasons, directed by the pop repackager Des McAnuff (''The Who's Tommy''). The real thrill of this shrink-wrapped biomusical, for those who want something more than recycled chart toppers and a story line poured from a can, is watching the wonderful John Lloyd Young (as Frankie Valli) cross the line from exact impersonation into something far more compelling (2:30). August Wilson Theater, 245 West 52nd Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'MARTIN SHORT: FAME BECOMES ME' This eager and amiably scattershot satire of celebrity memoirs and Broadway musicals, starring the immodestly modest Mr. Short, arrives a little late to the table for such parody to taste fresh. With serviceably tuneful songs by Scott Wittman and Marc Shaiman (of ''Hairspray'' fame) (1:45). Jacobs Theater, 242 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'TARZAN' This writhing green blob with music, adapted by Disney Theatrical Productions from the 1999 animated film, has the feeling of a superdeluxe day care center, equipped with lots of bungee cords and karaoke synthesizers, where children can swing when they get tired of singing, and vice versa. The soda-pop score is by Phil Collins (2:30). Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley)

* 'THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE' The happy news for this happy-making little musical is that the move to larger quarters has dissipated none of its quirky charm. William Finn's score sounds plumper and more rewarding than it did Off Broadway, providing a sprinkling of sugar to complement the sass in Rachel Sheinkin's zinger-filled book. The performances are flawless. Gold stars all around (1:45). Circle in the Square, 1633 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood)

'THE WEDDING SINGER' An assembly-kit musical that might as well be called ''That 80's Show,'' this stage version of the 1998 film is all winks and nods and quotations from the era of big hair and junk bonds. The cast members, who include Stephen Lynch and Constantine Maroulis, are personable enough, which is not the same as saying they have personalities (2:20). Al Hirschfeld Theater, 302 West 45th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

Off Broadway

'ARMS AND THE MAN' Shaw's story of a mercenary who breaks into a young Bulgarian woman's bedroom while fleeing a battle seems not to have much social bite in this rendition, but the humor still works nicely, particularly when in the hands of Robin Leslie Brown and Dominic Cuskern as the invaded household's matriarch and patriarch. Bradford Cover has an appealing offhand delivery as the soldier (2:15). The Pearl Theater Company, 80 St. Marks Place, East Village, (212) 598-9802. (Neil Genzlinger)

'ASCENSION' Brandon Ruckdashel makes a stunning debut in Edmund De Santis's clever comic mystery about a priest, a beautiful young man and a mother's accusation of sexual abuse (1:30). The Lion Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, (212) 279-4200. (Anita Gates)

'BIRTH AND AFTER BIRTH' Baby is a bruiser in Tina Howe's self-conscious foray into the jungles of absurdism. Written in 1972, this explosion of the nuclear family appears to be stepping, with cautious exactitude, in the footprints of early Edward Albee. Christian Parker directed the rather stilted cast (1:45). Atlantic Theater, 336 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'BLUE DOOR' An African-American math professor struggles to reconnect to his cultural past in this small but densely packed new play by Tanya Barfield. Reg E. Cathey is the professor, abandoned by his wife and visited by the ghosts of his ancestors, all played by the vibrant young actor Andre Holland (1:35). Playwrights Horizons, Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (Isherwood)

'BUSH IS BAD: IMPEACHMENT EDITION' A musical revue of silly, heavy-handed sketches aimed at Bush-haters (1:30). Triad Theater, 158 West 72nd Street, (212) 279-4200. (Jason Zinoman)

'ESOTERICA' Eric Walton's very entertaining one-man show is a mix of magic, mentalism and intelligent chat. He does all three impressively (1:30). DR2 Theater, 103 East 15th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Gates)

'THE FANTASTICKS' A revival -- well, more like a resuscitation -- of the Little Musical That Wouldn't Die. This sweet-as-ever production of Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt's commedia-dell'arte-style confection is most notable for Mr. Jones's touching performance (under the pseudonym Thomas Bruce) as the Old Actor, a role he created when the show opened in 1960. Mr. Jones also directs (2:05). Snapple Theater Center, 210 West 50th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

* 'FORBIDDEN BROADWAY: SPECIAL VICTIMS UNIT' This production features the expected caricatures of ego-driven singing stars. But even more than usual, the show offers an acute list of grievances about the sickly state of the Broadway musical, where, as the lyrics have it, ''everything old is old again'' (1:45). 47th Street Theater, 304 West 47th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

* 'THE HAIRY APE' The Irish Repertory Theater has put together a startling production of Eugene O'Neill's tale of a galoot called Yank who goes looking for his place in the world, one that vividly conveys what a gut-punch this work must have been when it was first seen in 1922. Eugene Lee's set is something to see, and the soundscape, by Zachary Williamson and Gabe Wood, is something to hear (2:00). Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 727-2737. (Genzlinger)

'JACQUES BREL IS ALIVE AND WELL AND LIVING IN PARIS' A powerfully sung revival of the 1968 revue, presented with affectionate nostalgia by the director Gordon Greenberg. As in the original, two men (Robert Cuccioli and Drew Sarich) and two women (Natascia Diaz and Gay Marshall) perform a wide selection of Brel's plaintive ballads and stirring anthems. Ms. Marshall's performance of ''Ne Me Quitte Pas,'' sung with heart-stirring transparency, represents Brel at his best (2:00). Zipper Theater, 336 West 37th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood)

'JOHN FERGUSON' This 1919 tragedy about a poor Irish family and how far its members will go not to lose their farm is a compelling, fully realized drama with a cast that doesn't miss a beat (2:20). Mint Theater, 311 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 315-0231. (Gates)

'KING LEAR' The ''promised end'' comes with disarming swiftness in this Classical Theater of Harlem production, starring Andre De Shields, which clocks in at just over two hours, not including an intermission. There's nothing distilled about Mr. De Shields's vigorous performance in the title role, but his impressive energy is not always productively channeled, and the supporting cast is uneven (2:10). The Harlem School of the Arts Theater, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 141st Street, (212) 868-4444. (Isherwood)

'MY NAME IS RACHEL CORRIE' A small, intense and loudly heralded one-woman drama that tells the true story of its title character, a pro-Palestinian activist killed in the Gaza strip by an Israeli Army bulldozer. Yet for all the political and emotional baggage carried by this production, adapted from Ms. Corrie's writings and starring Megan Dodds, it often feels dramatically flat, even listless (1:30). Minetta Lane Theater, 18 Minetta Lane, Greenwich Village, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

* 'NIXON'S NIXON' Russell Lees's savory political satire takes place on the night before the president announced his resignation. Gerry Bamman and Steve Mellor created the roles of Nixon and Kissinger, respectively, in the original production from 1995, also directed by Jim Simpson, and they return to them with the ease of veteran vaudevillians slipping back into a comfortable partnership (1:30). Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 279-4200. (Isherwood)

'NO CHILD' Teachers will love Nilaja Sun's one-woman show about the challenges of teaching drama at Malcolm X High School (1:10). Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village, (212) 239-6200. (Gates)

'THE PRIME OF MISS JEAN BRODIE' A slow, airless revival of Jay Presson Allen's 1966 play (adapted from Muriel Spark's novel) about a dangerous Scottish schoolteacher, directed by Scott Elliott and starring the wonderful (but miscast) Cynthia Nixon, who seems much too sane and centered as the deluded Miss Brody. (2:40). The Acorn Theater at Theater Row, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. (Brantley)

'SHOUT!' A miniskirted, go-go-booted zombie of a musical about women searching for love in London in the 1960's. You won't see anything this groovy, this far-out, this with-it outside of, oh, maybe the showroom of a Carnival cruise ship (1:30). Julia Miles Theater, 424 West 55th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood)

'SONGS OF THE DRAGONS FLYING TO HEAVEN' Young Jean Lee has fashioned a hysterically funny piece of theater with twisted socio-political power and giggly Korean dancers who would fit right into a Quentin Tarantino movie (1:30). Here Arts Center, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Dominick Street, South Village, (212) 868-4444. (Gates)

'SUBURBIA' This black-hole revival of Eric Bogosian's 1994 group portrait of losers in Angstville, U.S.A., directed by Jo Bonney, features lively performances from Gaby Hoffman, Kieran Culkin and Jessica Capshaw. But even if you're as success-addicted as Donald Trump, you're likely to find yourself identifying with these characters in the wrong way: They're beyond caring what happens to them, and so are you (2:00). Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43rd Street, Clinton, (212) 246-4422. (Brantley)

'TEMPEST TOSSED FOOLS' This musical audience-participation children's version of ''The Tempest'' is rowdy, colorful and not all that Shakespearean. Manhattan Ensemble Theater, 55 Mercer Street, SoHo, (212) 239-6200. (Gates)

'25 QUESTIONS FOR A JEWISH MOTHER' This is the comedian Judy Gold's fiercely funny monologue, based on her own life as a single Jewish lesbian mother and interviews with more than 50 other Jewish mothers (1:10). St. Luke's Theater, 308 West 46th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Phoebe Hoban)

'WRECKS' The tail wags the scorpion in the latest play by Neil LaBute to be propelled by a poisoned lunch line. This slender, prickly tease of a monologue -- whose whole raison d'etre is its last-minute revelation -- is given substance by an expert performance by Ed Harris as a newly bereaved widower (1:15). Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555. (Brantley)

Off Off Broadway

'HELL HOUSE' Les Freres Corbusier recreate evangelical Christian entertainments in this typically deadpan show (45 minutes).St. Ann's Warehouse, 38 Water Street, at Dock Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 254-8779. (Brantley)

'KRANKENHAUS BLUES' Sam Forman's bizarre tale of an actress, a playwright and a clown in a Nazi camp goes off the deep end fast, but there's a great monologue about cheese (1:15). Abingdon Theater Arts Complex, 312 West 36th Street, (212) 868-4444. (Gates)

'ME, MY GUITAR AND DON HENLEY' Krista Vernoff's saucy, satisfying black comedy is about six very different women in one dying man's complicated family tree (1:40). the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101. (Gates)

'THE THUGS' Rumors of death at a law firm make Adam Bock's new play a chilling little nightmare (1:15). SoHo Rep, 46 Walker Street, between Church Street and Broadway, TriBeCa, (212) 868-4444. (Zinoman)

'TRUTH $(the heart is a million little pieces above all things$)' The virtuoso storyteller Mike Daisey's new monologue, which addresses issues about lying, memoir and the James Frey scandal, is less funny than his previous work but just as engaging and intellectually curious (1:40). Ars Nova, 511 West 54th Street, Clinton, (212) 868-4444. (Zinoman)

Long-Running Shows

'ALTAR BOYZ' This sweetly satirical show about a Christian pop group made up of five potential Teen People cover boys is an enjoyable, silly diversion (1:30). New World Stages, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Isherwood)

'AVENUE Q' R-rated puppets give lively life lessons (2:10). Golden Theater, 252 West 45th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'BEAUTY AND THE BEAST' Cartoon made flesh, sort of (2:30). Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, (212) 307-4747. (Brantley)

'CHICAGO' Irrefutable proof that crime pays (2:25). Ambassador Theater, 219 West 49th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'DRUMSTRUCK' Lightweight entertainment that stops just short of pulverizing the eardrums (1:30). New World Stages, Stage 2, 340 West 50th Street, Clinton, (212) 239-6200. (Lawrence Van Gelder)

'HAIRSPRAY' Fizzy pop, cute kids, large man in a housedress (2:30). Neil Simon Theater, 250 West 52nd Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

'THE LION KING' Disney on safari, where the big bucks roam (2:45). Minskoff Theater, 200 West 45th Street at Broadway, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

'MAMMA MIA!' The jukebox that devoured Broadway (2:20). Cadillac Winter Garden Theater, 1634 Broadway, at 50th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA' Who was that masked man, anyway? (2:30). Majestic Theater, 247 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'THE PRODUCERS' The ne plus ultra of showbiz scams (2:45). St. James Theater, 246 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'RENT' East Village angst and love songs to die for (2:45). Nederlander Theater, 208 West 41st Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

'SLAVA'S SNOWSHOW' Clowns chosen by the Russian master Slava Polunin stir up laughter and enjoyment. A show that touches the heart as well as tickles the funny bone (1:30). Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street, (212) 307-4100. (Van Gelder)

'SPAMALOT' A singing scrapbook for Monty Python fans. (2:20). Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, (212) 239-6200. (Brantley)

'WICKED' Oz revisited, with political corrections (2:45). Gershwin Theater, 222 West 51st Street, (212) 307-4100. (Brantley)

Last Chance

'EL CONQUISTADOR!' Thaddeus Phillips's one-man show about a hapless Colombian doorman can be slow, but it's also ingenious and an excellent showcase for Mr. Phillips, who would have made a great silent-movie comedian (1:30). New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200; closing on Sunday. (Gates)

'DRUG BUDDY' The aimless Texas drug dealers of David Folwell's slight slacker dramedy are one losers' club we wouldn't mind spending more time with, particularly the engaging lead, Matthew Stadelmann (51 minutes). Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, between Barrow and Bedford Streets, West Village, (212) 868-4444; closing tomorrow. (Rob Kendt)

'GARDEL: THE MUSICAL' A standard-issue biomusical about the tango legend Carlos Gardel that wallows in melodrama (1:30). Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, (212) 225-9920; closing on Sunday. (Zinoman)

* 'THE TOOTH OF CRIME' This highly entertaining revival of Sam Shepard's musical comic-book melodrama about celebrity, mortality and rock 'n' roll may not be the slickest show around. But as directed by George Ferencz, it brings a demystifying clarity to a work often dismissed as a smoky head trip and makes a strong case for ''Tooth'' as one of Mr. Shepard's best plays (2:15). La MaMa Annex, 66 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 475-7710; closing on Sunday. (Brantley)

'THE TREATMENT' A new play by Eve Ensler (''The Vagina Monologues'') depicting fraught encounters between a traumatized war veteran and a military psychologist. Fervently acted by Dylan McDermott and Portia, it is an overwrought amalgam of psychodrama and political sermonizing (1:05). Culture Project, 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 253-9983, impactfestival.org.; closing on Sunday. (Isherwood)

Movies

Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases, movie trailers, show times and tickets: nytimes.com/movies.

'ALEX RIDER: OPERATION STORMBREAKER' (PG, 93 minutes) Based on the first in a series of best-selling kid lit adventure novels, the movie debut of Alex Rider, teenage super spy, is a James Bond flick for kids who have never heard of James Bond. (Nathan Lee)

'ALL THE KING'S MEN' (PG-13, 120 minutes) This second adaptation of Robert Penn Warren's big novel of political and spiritual corruption in Depression-era Louisiana is full of grand themes, good actors (Jude Law, Sean Penn, Kate Winslet, Mark Ruffalo) and lovingly-photographed southern scenery. And yet nothing seems to work. It's a chaotic stew of ambitions and ideas, but in the end neither convincing nor coherent. (A. O. Scott)

* 'DELIVER US FROM EVIL' (No rating, 101 minutes) Amy Berg's urgent, hard-to-watch documentary looks at sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church, interviewing victims and their families and, chillingly, a priest who preyed on several California parishes while his superiors apparently looked the other way. (Scott)

* 'THE DEPARTED' (R, 150 minutes) Martin Scorsese's cubistic entertainment about men divided by power, loyalty and their own selves is at once a success and a relief. Based on the crackling Hong Kong thriller ''Infernal Affairs,'' it features fine twinned performances from Matt Damon and Leonardo DiCaprio, and a showboating Jack Nicholson. (Manohla Dargis)

'DRIVING LESSONS' (PG-13, 98 minutes) ''Driving Lessons'' belongs to that hardy niche of British comedies designed as star vehicles for distinguished actresses (preferably dames) of a certain age whose assignment is to win awards by devouring the scenery. If Julie Walters isn't yet a dame, her hammy portrayal of a retired actress who hires as her assistant a shy 17-year-old boy (Rupert Grint) from a strict Christian background is a step in that direction. (Stephen Holden)

'EMPLOYEE OF THE MONTH' (PG, 103 minutes) A minimum-wage comedy chronicling the romance between a slacker box boy (Dane Cook) and a bodacious cashier (Jessica Simpson) working at a Costco-like megastore. Directed by Greg Coolidge with the creative flair of an entry-level training video, the movie is more tired than a Wal-Mart greeter at the end of a Saturday shift. (Jeannette Catsoulis)

'THE GRUDGE 2' (PG-13, 95 minutes) Puberty sets off an exponential increase in evil -- and incoherence -- in Takashi Shimizu's continuing saga about a Japanese wraith with a fondness for neck-snapping and Goth makeup. What's new is an Altmanesque cast of victims, vaporized according to stupidity and/or sluttiness. What's old are the defective light bulbs, scummy bath water and camerawork that makes even teenage flesh look mottled. What's sad is that ''The Grudge 3'' is already in the works. (Catsoulis)

* 'A GUIDE TO RECOGNIZING YOUR SAINTS' (R, 98 minutes) Rough, ragged and full of life, this autobiographical movie, written and directed by Dito Montiel, about his youth on the streets of Astoria, Queens, is a remarkable debut, stuffed almost to bursting with bold performances and operatic emotions. (Scott)

* 'HAIR HIGH' (No rating, 78 minutes) Bill Plympton's gleefully outrageous animated feature has teenage romance, a big game with a halftime show that would make Janet Jackson blush, and, of course, a prom where death comes calling. It's eye-popping -- sometimes literally. (Neil Genzlinger)

'INFAMOUS' (R, 118 minutes) Truman Capote -- again! -- on the trail of ''In Cold Blood.'' It is warmer and more stylish than last year's ''Capote'' -- with fine performances by Toby Jones as Truman and Sandra Bullock as his pal Harper Lee -- but also thinner. (Scott)

'JUSTICE' (No rating, 102 minutes, in Portuguese) Maria Ramos's documentary following a few cases of petty crime through low-level Brazilian courts views editing as a vice; why indicate a walk down a hallway when you can show the entire long shuffle? The minimalist technique is deliberate, of course, and it admirably reveals the tedium of life for defendants, lawyers and judges alike, but any broader point is up to you. (Genzlinger)

'KETTLE OF FISH' (R, 93 minutes) Casting Gina Gershon as a mousy scientist (yeah, right) is the first mistake, though by no means the last, in this deeply misguided romantic comedy. (Lee)

* 'LITTLE CHILDREN' (R, 130 minutes) Todd Field's adaptation of Tom Perrotta's novel of suburban adultery is unfailingly intelligent and faultlessly acted. Kate Winslet and Patrick Wilson are superb as the parents of young children who meet at the playground and enact a two-handed variation on ''Madame Bovary'' against a backdrop of social paranoia and middle-class malaise. (Scott)

'MAN OF THE YEAR' (PG-13, 115 minutes) Robin Williams plays a comedian and talk show host who plunges into the presidential campaign, telling truths the timid politicians dare not utter. Not really. This would-be satire, written and directed by Barry Levinson, is hectic and tired, with too many plots and too few sharp insights. (Scott)

* 'MARIE ANTOINETTE' (PG-13, 123 minutes) In this elaborate, bittersweet confection, Sofia Coppola imagines the last pre-revolutionary queen of France (played with wit and charm by Kirsten Dunst) as a bored, pleasure-seeking teenager trapped in a world of artifice and rigid protocol. Dreamy and decadent, the film is also touching, funny and bracingly modern. (Scott) 'THE MARINE' (PG-13, 93 minutes) Discharged from the Marine corps, John Triton returns home to find obnoxious yuppies, psychotic diamond thieves, a kidnapped wife and exploding gas stations. (Lee)

* 'THE QUEEN' (PG-13, 103 minutes) Directed by Stephen Frears from a very smart script by Peter Morgan, and starring a magnificent Helen Mirren in the title role, ''The Queen'' pries open a window in the House of Windsor around the time of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, blending fact with fiction. (Dargis)

'THE RITCHIE BOYS' (No rating, 90 minutes, in English, with some subtitled German) Though it may seem more like a History Channel special than a film for theatrical release, this documentary by Christian Bauer is an elegant entry in the Greatest Generation genre. It tells the story of a group of young Jewish men who fled Germany before the war, then volunteered for intelligence work with the American military when the fighting broke out. The ''boys'' -- named for the camp where they were trained, and now aging gentlemen -- tell their own story in a series of engaging anecdotes. (Genzlinger)

'SCHOOL FOR SCOUNDRELS' (PG-13, 101 minutes) Billy Bob Thornton stars as an alpha scoundrel who runs a self-improvement course for sad sacks of the sort persuasively played by the film's other lead actor, Jon Heder. (Dargis)

* 'SHORTBUS' (No rating, 102 minutes) John Cameron Mitchell's ode to the joy and sweet release of sex also manages to be a sincere, modest political venture that finds humor where you might least expect it. (Dargis)

'SWEET LAND' (PG, 110 minutes) There's a tartness at the center of Ali Selim's sentimental tale of the prejudice faced by a German mail-order bride (Elizabeth Reaser) who arrives in 1920 Minnesota to marry a Norwegian farmer (Tim Guinee) she has never seen. The film's guileless, heartfelt style veers perilously close to corny at times, but the superb cast dares you to mock. Lovingly filmed in glorious 35-millimeter, the movie celebrates an old-fashioned love born of backbreaking work and shared difficulties, while the endless wheat fields and magnificent skyline seem reason enough to endure. (Catsoulis)

'THE TEXAS CHAINSAW MASSACRE: THE BEGINNING' (R, 84 minutes) A prequel to a remake of a 1974 movie that spawned several sequels and numberless copycats, this hateful trash begs the question: how many chainsaw massacres can one state possibly contain? (Lee)

'TIDELAND' (R, 120 minutes) Terry Gilliam, usually bold in his explorations of the boundary between fantasy and reality, here stumbles into a different frontier, the one that separates the merely bad from the utterly inexcusable. (Scott)

Film Series

THE JAPANESE FILM: A TRIBUTE TO DONALD RICHIE (Through Oct. 28) The Museum of the Moving Image honors Mr. Richie, the American-born screenwriter and film historian, with a two-weekend program of his selections and his own short films. This weekend's features include Akira Kurosawa's ''Rashomon'' (1951), the classic about one crime from four points of view, and Yasujiro Ozu's ''Tokyo Story'' (1953), about an elderly couple visiting their grown children in the big city. 35th Avenue at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718) 784-0077; $10. (Anita Gates)

POLICE PARIS NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL: FROM THE STREETS TO THE SCREEN (Through tomorrow) The French Institute Alliance Francaise is sponsoring a three-day series of French films written and directed by former police officers. This weekend's features include Claude Zidi's comedy sequel ''Ripoux 3'' (2003), about old police department pals on a money laundering case in Paris's Chinatown; Alain Corneau's drama ''Le Cousin'' (1997), about a narcotics officer; and Olivier Marchal's ''36 Quai des Orfevres'' (2004), starring Daniel Auteuil and Gerard Depardieu as ambitious cops competing for a promotion. Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, Manhattan, (212) 355-6160; $9. (Gates)

PORDENONE SILENT FILM WEEKEND (Through Sunday) BAMcinematek's four-day selection of highlights from the annual Pordenone silent-movie festival in Italy continues. Features include a Lillian Gish double feature, ''Enoch Arden'' (1915) and ''The Lily and the Rose'' (1915); ''The Triumph of the Rat'' (1926), starring Ivor Novello as a jewel thief trying to go straight in high society; and Anthony Asquith's masterpiece ''A Cottage on Dartmoor'' (1929), about a small-town romantic triangle. BAM Rose Cinemas, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100; $10. (Gates)

OTTO PREMINGER: NOTORIOUS (Through Oct. 29) The Museum of Modern Arts's nine-film retrospective of Preminger's work (he would have turned 100 this year) continues this weekend with three films. ''Laura'' (1944) is his classic Manhattan murder mystery. ''Carmen Jones'' (1954) is an African-American musical version of Bizet's opera. And ''Skidoo'' (1968) is an odd little comedy starring Jackie Gleason and Carol Channing as car-wash owners. Roy and Niuta Titus Theaters, (212) 708-9400; $10. (Gates)

SOROS/SUNDANCE DOCUMENTARY FUND: A 10th-ANNIVERSARY FILM SERIES (Through Oct. 29) This program of 19 international documentaries that deal with human rights and social injustice is sponsored by the Open Society Institute and the Sundance Institute. It begins on Thursday at Film Forum. Opening-day features include Mandy Jacobson and Karmen Jelincic's ''Calling the Ghosts: A Story About Rape, War and Women'' (1996), the story of two Bosnian women in a Serbian camp; and Elizabeth Barret's ''Stranger With a Camera'' (2000), about the murder of a Canadian filmmaker. 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, (212) 727-8110; $5.50. (Gates)

Pop

Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music.

BETTIE SERVEERT (Wednesday) Bettie Serveert -- a Dutch band led by Carol van Dijk, who sings in fluent English -- has persevered since the early 1990's on the collegiate-rock circuit. Ms. van Dijk writes and sings observant songs about romantic ups and downs, continually expanding a musical vocabulary that now stretches from pop tunefulness to indie-rock guitar furor to the easy-rolling incantations of Van Morrison. At 9 p.m., Southpaw, 125 Fifth Avenue, near Sterling Place, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 230-0236, spsounds.com; $13 in advance, $15 at the door. (Jon Pareles)

FRANK BLACK (Tonight and Monday) Don't expect those baby-crying-in-hell screams that Frank Black (as Black Francis) relied on to spike his Pixies songs with terror and raw sexual angst. As a solo artist, he has been veering into gentle and reflective, if sometimes cheerlessly dry, territory. His most recent two albums, ''Honeycomb'' and ''Fast Man Raider Man'' (Back Porch) -- both underrated -- were recorded in Nashville with master country-soul session men like Spooner Oldham and Steve Cropper. Also on the bill is his longtime New York opening act, the gravelly-voiced grumbler Reid Paley. Tonight at 9, Warsaw, 261 Driggs Avenue, at Eckford Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 387-0505, warsawconcerts.com; Monday at 9 p.m., Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800, irvingplaza.com; $25. (Ben Sisario)

ROSANNE CASH (Tonight) Always an introspective songwriter, Ms. Cash has said that the songs on her latest album, ''Black Cadillac'' (Capitol) -- about the deaths, in quick succession, of her father, Johnny Cash; her stepmother, June Carter Cash; and her mother, Vivian Liberto Cash Distin -- represent a shift to even deeper and more personal material. She plays an acoustic set of songs from ''Black Cadillac'' and throughout her career. At 8:30, Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7000, carnegiehall.org; $38 to $43. (Sisario)

CELTIC FIDDLE FESTIVAL (Sunday) Three master fiddlers offer a collaborative primer of three branches of the Celtic style. Kevin Burke, born in London to Irish parents, plays in the ornamental Sligo style of Ireland; Christian Lemaitre represents Brittany, France's Celtic region. Andre Brunet, a young Canadian player, has the daunting task of replacing Johnny Cunningham, a pillar of the international Celtic scene who began touring with Mr. Burke and Mr. Lemaitre in the early 90's, and who died three years ago at 46. They are accompanied by the English guitarist Ged Foley. At 7 p.m., Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 545-7536, symphonyspace.org or heartheworld.org; $27, $15 for students. (Sisario)

CHEETAH GIRLS (Tonight and tomorrow) Behold the new teenage pop: it is female, its reference points are sexed-up strutters like the Pussycat Dolls and Christina Aguilera, and it has the Disney seal of approval. The Cheetah Girls began as a Disney Channel movie, and the group's latest album (the soundtrack to the sequel) opened in the Top 5. Also on the bill is Vanessa Anne Hudgens, one of the never-frowning stars of ''High School Musical,'' the smash Disney Channel movie whose soundtrack is the best-selling album this year. Tonight at 7, Nassau Coliseum, 1255 Hempstead Turnpike, Uniondale, N.Y., (631) 888-9000, nassaucoliseum.com; tomorrow at 4 p.m., Continental Airlines Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., (201) 935-3900, meadowlands.com; $25.50 to $42. (Sisario)

DEICIDE (Tonight) For all its militancy -- lyrics vilifying Christianity, studded breastplates, beefy arms -- this Florida band makes unremarkable meat-and-potatoes death metal: buzz-saw guitar themes in minor modes give way to fast, narrow two-beat drum thrashing. Glen Benton, the leader and demagogue, uses the genre's generic low growl; it's business as usual, no big deal. (He also prefers to present himself as being against organized religion rather than, uh, pro-Satan.) With Nachtmystium, Daath, Embalmer, Desolation, Annunaki and Dimentianon. At 8, Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5103, northsix.com; $25. (Ben Ratliff)

FLOETRY (Wednesday and Thursday) Cooing melodies meet socially conscious rapping in this English duo, which allies a rapper, Natalie Stewart, and a singer, Marsha Ambrosius. They boast, preach positive thinking and delve into love, articulating uncertainties along with lust. With Emily King. At 9 p.m., S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940, sobs.com; $32 in advance, $36 at the door. (Pareles)

THE FRAY (Wednesday and Thursday) This Denver band has the No. 1 song on iTunes with ''How to Save a Life,'' a gushy piano ballad that, like all the Counting Crows, Wallflowers, Coldplay and Keane songs whose template it studiously follows, features a man meekly apologizing to the woman who dumps him. (Maybe she grew tired of creepy let's-be-friends lines like, ''I would have stayed up with you all night.'') At 7:30 p.m., Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, mcstudios.com; sold out. (Sisario)

GOOGOOSH (Tomorrow) In pre-revolutionary Iran, Googoosh was Iran's Barbra Streisand, Linda Ronstadt, Cher, Edith Piaf and Madonna rolled into one: not just a magnificent singer but also a fashion trailblazer and a symbol of modernity. Her songs were romantic, not political, and while they drew on Western styles, they held onto both the fervor of Persian love poetry and the sliding, quivering, impassioned phrasing of traditional Persian music. With Mehrdad. At 9 p.m., the Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $54.50 to $254.50. (Pareles)

GOTAN PROJECT (Wednesday) Tango meets late-night chill-out electronica in the music of this stylish Paris trio, and thanks to tasteful restraint and some studio finesse, the gimmick works. Its latest album, ''Lunatico'' (XL), expands the palette a bit further with guest appearances by the mariachi-and-surf-guitar Arizona band Calexico and some rap. At 8 p.m., Webster Hall, 125 East 11th Street, East Village, (212) 533-2111, bowerypresents.com; $30 in advance, $35 at the door. (Sisario)

JOLIE HOLLAND (Tonight) With a playful quiver of a voice, like a countryfied Billie Holiday, and a junk-shop aesthetic that mingles brassy swing with Appalachian folk, Ms. Holland sings charming and deceptively childlike songs: ''Crush in the Ghetto,'' on her new album, ''Springtime Can Kill You'' (Anti-), finds her overdressed on a bus ride home from a one-night stand. With David Dondero. At 7:30, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 653-1703, maxwellsnj.com; $15. (Sisario)

* THE KILLERS (Tuesday and Wednesday) Big-league arrogance is nothing new in a rising rock band, but not many have the songwriting chops to back it up the way the Killers do. Two years ago this Las Vegas quartet became instant stars with ''Hot Fuss,'' a hit-packed album whose adrenalized update of new-wave pop cloaked some of the blase cynicism of its lyrics (''Dreams aren't what they used to be''). This month the band released ''Sam's Town'' (Island/Def Jam), which is grandiose and aloof where its predecessor was sharp and hungry, though it still has a few songs you won't easily get out of your head. With Red Romance. At 8 p.m., the Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; sold out. (Sisario)

MARITIME (Tomorrow) Founded by former members of the Promise Ring and the Dismemberment Plan, two bands that in the mid-90's did as much as any to establish the emo sound, Maritime plays understated and effortlessly catchy songs with minimal touches of acoustic guitar and new-wave keyboards. With Bound Stems, the Secret Life of Sofia and Heather Duby. At 8:30 p.m., Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700, mercuryloungenyc.com; $10 in advance, $12 at the door. (Sisario)

* MILTON NASCIMENTO (Monday through Thursday) A somewhat rare club appearance by Mr. Nascimento, one of Brazil's greatest songwriters as well as a singer of gentle and entrancing purity. His band will include Gastao Villeroy on bass, Wilson Lopes on guitar, Kiko Continentino at the piano and Lincoln Cheib on the drums. At 8 and 10:30 p.m., Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592, bluenote.net; cover, $55 at tables, $35 at the bar, with a $5 minimum. (Sisario)

* JOHNNY PACHECO TRIBUTE (Tonight) The Fania All-Stars, the great salsa mafia that ruled New York Latin music in the 70's, pays tribute to its founder and musical director, the Dominican flutist and bandleader Johnny Pacheco, who is celebrating 50 years of making music. The lineup spans several generations of Latin stars: Bobby Valentin, Ismael Miranda, Jimmy Bosch, Roberto Roena, Papo Lucca, Adalberto Santiago, Yomo Toro, Nicky Marrero, Eddie Montalvo and others. At 8, the Theater at Madison Square Garden, (212) 465-6741, thegarden.com; $69.50 to $109.50. (Sisario)

SCISSOR SISTERS (Tomorrow) You would be forgiven if you didn't know that the Scissor Sisters were one of the most popular New York City bands in the world: despite Top 10 success in Britain with its almost parodically falsetto-heavy disco-soul, the group has struggled for attention at home. Its main songwriters, the singer Jake Shears and the bassist Babbydaddy, can crank out some very entertaining dance-floor anthems, but as its recently released second album, ''Ta-Dah'' (Universal), makes clear, this sound can go on forever without much development, and the Bee Gees and George Michael wrote better songs. With Small Sins. At 8 p.m., the Grand Ballroom at Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 307-7171, mcstudios.com; sold out. (Sisario)

SIERRA LEONE'S REFUGEE ALL STARS (Tuesday) These six musicians, ranging from a teenage rapper to a guitarist in his 50's, fled civil war in their homeland for a refugee camp in rural Guinea. They formed a band there four years ago, and tell their stories in songs tinged with soul and reggae. A documentary about them, made by Zach Niles and Banker White, will be shown at 7:30 p.m., and the band will go on at 9. S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940, sobs.com; $25 in advance, $30 at the door. (Sisario)

PAUL SIMON (Tomorrow) At 64, Mr. Simon, who in the 1960's conquered the dorm rooms of the world with a sweetened, sharpened revision of coffeehouse folk, and in the 80's virtually created the idea of the world-music crossover, this year released one of his most adventurous albums, ''Surprise'' (Warner Brothers). Produced by Brian Eno (David Bowie, Talking Heads, U2) along with Mr. Simon, it accompanies his voice with bubbly and slightly disorienting electronics, and the two elements interact as discrete, parallel planes. With Jerry Douglas, a master of the bluegrass Dobro. At 7:30 p.m., Radio City Music Hall, (212) 307-7171, radiocity.com; $39.50 to $129.50. (Sisario)

PATTI SMITH (Tonight) Fresh from her appearance at CBGB as the club's eulogist -- singing her own otherworldly rhapsodies, like ''Birdland,'' as well as raw-throated punk-rock classics like the Dead Boys' ''Sonic Reducer'' -- Ms. Smith heads to another, quieter New York institution, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to celebrate heroes of French culture. Baudelaire, Rimbaud and Juliet Greco are among those she and a circle of friends are to honor with poetry and music, but the focus of the evening will be Joan of Arc, specifically Jules Bastien-Lepage's enormous and endlessly mesmerizing 1879 painting of her, in the Met's permanent collection. At 8, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $40. (Sisario)

THE STRAWBS (Tomorrow) Led by David Cousins, the Strawbs were part of the British trad-rock movement of the late 1960's and 70's, reaching back to modal Celtic melodies and the lore of ancient ballads. This version of the band is unplugged, with Mr. Cousins, Dave Lambert and Chas Cronk. At 7 and 9:30 p.m., Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, joespub.com; $30. (Pareles)

ELAINE STRITCH (Tonight and tomorrow, and Tuesday through Thursday) The third autobiographical go-round by this feisty 81-year-old legend features 10 astutely chosen new songs (including the theme from ''The Sopranos'') performed with verve and humor. But her between-song patter finds her at a loss to come up with amusing or enlightening new stories from her glittering show business life. (Through Nov. 4.) At 8:45 p.m., Cafe Carlyle, Carlyle Hotel, 35 East 76th Street, Manhattan, (212) 744-1600, thecarlyle.com; $125; dinner required. (Stephen Holden)

* SUISHOU NO FUNE (Tuesday and Thursday) This Tokyo group, whose name means ship of crystal, carries on a decades-long tradition in underground Japanese rock of immersion in both tranquil, spooky psychedelia and rumbling sonic chaos. Like Fushitsusha, its earliest ancestor on the Japanese scene, Suishou no Fune is transcendent in either extreme. Tuesday at 9 p.m., with Malkuth and Titan, Club Midway, 25 Avenue B, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 253-2595, clubmidway.com; $8 in advance, $10 at the door. Thursday at 9 p.m., with Magik Markers, Northsix, 66 North Sixth Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-5103, northsix.com; $10. (Sisario)

Jazz

Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

AHMED ABDULLAH'S EBONIC TONES (Tomorrow) On the recent album ''Tara's Song'' (Tum), the trumpeter Ahmed Abdullah led this ensemble in an exploration of themes by Thelonious Monk and Ornette Coleman, among others. Mr. Abdullah reconvenes the group at Sista's Place, the fiercely independent Brooklyn arts space that he partly oversees. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Sista's Place, 456 Nostrand Avenue, at Jefferson Avenue, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, (718) 756-7600; sistasplace.org; cover, $25 in advance, $30 tomorrow. (Nate Chinen)

FRANK CARLBERG QUINTET (Tomorrow) Literary themes often provide inspiration for Frank Carlberg, a pianist and composer; here he will present a song cycle set to poems by Robert Creeley, with collaborators including the tenor saxophonist Chris Cheek and the vocalist Christine Correa. At 9 and 10:30 p.m., Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $10, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)

ANAT COHEN QUARTET (Tonight) As part of the ''Harlem in the Himalayas'' series at the Rubin Museum of Art, the clarinetist and saxophonist Anat Cohen performs music loosely inspired by the Tibetan art in the museum's collection. She also introduces material from a forthcoming album, with Jason Lindner on piano, Omer Avital on bass and Daniel Freedman on drums. At 7, Rubin Museum of Art, 150 West 17th Street, Chelsea, (212) 620-5000, Ext. 344, rmanyc.org; $20. (Chinen)

* MARILYN CRISPELL (Tomorrow) Ms. Crispell, a pianist equally celebrated for aggressive atonality and delicate lyricism, reunites with the bassist Mark Helias and the drummer Paul Motian, the same team as on her superb 2004 album ''Storyteller'' (ECM). There's a welcome X factor, too: the tenor saxophonist Joe Lovano, a musician capable of shifting from a murmur to a shriek, though he's most comfortable somewhere between the two. At 8 p.m., Miller Theater, Columbia University, 116th Street and Broadway, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799, millertheatre.com; $25. (Chinen)

EDDIE DANIELS 65TH BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION (Tonight through Sunday night) The clarinetist Eddie Daniels just reached standard retirement age, though he shows little interest in laying back. Along with Joe Locke on vibraphone, David Finck on bass and Joe La Barbera on drums, he revisits music from a new album, ''Mean What You Say'' (IPO), and records material for a forthcoming live release. At 8:30 and 10:30, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121, iridiumjazzclub.com; cover, $32.50, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

* KALAPARUSHA AHRA DIFDA/REGGIE NICHOLSON (Tonight) The New York chapter of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians presents one of its sporadic concerts, featuring ensembles led by Mr. Difda, the founding member and multireedist formerly known as Maurice McIntyre, and Mr. Nicholson, a drummer with experience both in and out of the A.A.C.M. scene. At 8, Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, Manhattan, (212) 683-4988, aacm-newyork.com; $25; students, $12. (Chinen)

ERIK FRIEDLANDER/SHANIR BLUMENKRANZ (Tuesday) ''Masada Book Two,'' a body of John Zorn compositions, provides fodder for Mr. Friedlander, a cellist, in a solo recital. Mr. Blumenkranz, who plays oud, leads a quintet with Mr. Friedlander, the bassist Greg Cohen and the percussionists Satoshi Takeishi and Cyro Baptista. At 8 p.m., the Stone, Avenue C and Second Street, East Village, thestonenyc.com; cover, $10. (Chinen)

JIM HALL TRIO (Tonight through Sunday night) Jim Hall's economical style and deep harmonic command have made him a quiet hero of jazz guitar; he leads his regular trio with the bassist Steve LaSpina and the drummer Terry Clarke. At 9 and 11, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $25, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

JOEL HARRISON (Monday) As a singer as well as a guitarist, Mr. Harrison leans on American roots traditions. Here he focuses exclusively on music by the drummer Paul Motian, with a group he calls his string choir, comprising the violinist Christian Howes, the violist Alan Grubner and the cellist Dana Leong. At 9 and 10:15 p.m., Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, West Village, (212) 989-9319, corneliastreetcafe.com; cover, $12, with a one-drink minimum. (Chinen)

BILL MAYS TRIO (Tonight and tomorrow night) An accomplished mainstream trio, featuring the articulate pianist Bill Mays and the fluent rhythm team of Martin Wind on bass and Tim Horner on drums. At 7:30 and 9:15 p.m., , Kitano Hotel, 66 Park Avenue, at 38th Street, (212) 885-7119, kitano.com; cover, $20, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

MEPHISTA (Thursday) Texture and tonality are flexible elements in this exploratory trio, with Sylvie Courvoisier on piano, Susie Ibarra on drums and percussion, and Ikue Mori on electronics. At 9 p.m., Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501; tonicnyc.com cover, $10. (Chinen)

JOHN PATITUCCI TRIO (Tonight through Sunday) Best recognized lately as the bassist of choice for Wayne Shorter, John Patitucci has several strong albums to his name; ''Line by Line'' (Concord), his newest, confirms his unmistakable gift for light-handed fusions. The album's most valuable players, the guitarist Adam Rogers and the drummer Brian Blade, are appearing with him. At 7:30 and 9:30, with an 11:30 set tonight and tomorrow, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $30; $25 on Sunday. (Chinen)

MADELEINE PEYROUX/ODETTA (Wednesday) Ms. Peyroux is a coyly reticent songbook crier whose songbook includes Leonard Cohen as well as Johnny Mercer, as she demonstrates on a likable new album called ''Half the Perfect World'' (Rounder). Odetta may as well be her polar opposite: regal and unequivocal, with a voice that emits a deep and certain authority. At 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, (212) 840-2824, the-townhall-nyc.org; $48.50 and $62.50. (Chinen)

ANDREW RATHBUN QUARTET (Wednesday) Andrew Rathbun is a sure-footed tenor and soprano saxophonist, but it is as a composer that he makes his mark, especially when his music is entrusted to improvisers like his fellow tenor player George Garzone, a featured guest here. At 8 p.m., Barbes, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. (Chinen)

BOBBY SANABRIA (Tonight) Mr. Sanabria, a powerhouse percussionist and bandleader, tackles music by the Brazilian composer Hermeto Pascoal, the rock iconoclast Frank Zappa and several members of his big band, which he leads here. At 8, TriBeCa Performing Arts Center, Borough of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, between Greenwich and West Streets, (212) 220-1460, tribecapac.org; $25; students, $15. (Chinen)

ANTONIO SANCHEZ TRIO (Monday) Antonio Sanchez, a sensitive and dynamic drummer who has distinguished himself in groups led by the pianist Danilo Perez and the guitarist Pat Metheny, leads one of his own with two close compatriots: Miguel Zenon, on alto saxophone, and Scott Colley, on bass. At 10 p.m., 55 Bar, 55 Christopher Street, West Village, (212) 929-9883, 55bar.com; cover, $8. (Chinen)

JENNY SCHEINMAN (Tuesday) Ms. Scheinman is that rare jazz violinist who embraces her instrument's folksier side without making concessions to genre. She performs next week with the clarinetist Doug Weiselman, the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Kenny Wollesen. At 7 p.m., Barbes, 376 Ninth Street, at Sixth Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 965-9177, barbesbrooklyn.com; cover, $8. (Chinen)

TYSHAWN SOREY'S OBLIQUE/DAN WEISS TRIO (Tomorrow) Tyshawn Sorey is an often explosive drummer, but he brings some compositional subtlety to his main ensemble, which includes the alto saxophonist Loren Stillman and the trombonist Ben Gerstein. Dan Weiss, also a drummer, is well versed in Indian classical music, as well as in rock and modern jazz; he plays a later set with his frequent colleagues the pianist Jacob Sacks and the bassist Thomas Morgan. At 8 and 10 p.m., Rose Live Music, 345 Grand Street, near Marcy Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 599-0069, newlanguages.org; $10. (Chinen)

* TOMASZ STANKO QUARTET (Wednesday and Thursday) The Polish trumpeter Tomasz Stanko is one of Europe's most heralded jazz musicians, and he has roundly earned his accolades. ''Lontano'' (ECM) is his third album with a gifted younger rhythm section made up of the pianist Marcin Wasilewski, the bassist Slawomir Kurkiewicz and the drummer Michal Miskiewicz; it's a shimmering, gently abstract and warmly luminescent work, likely to sound even better in the flesh. (Through Oct. 28.) At 9 and 11 p.m., Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080, birdlandjazz.com; cover, $30, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

THIRD WORLD LOVE (Monday, Wednesday and Thursday) African and Middle Eastern rhythmic concepts provide the thrumming heart of this collective, consisting of Avishai Cohen on trumpet, Omer Avital on bass and oud, Yonatan Avishai on piano and Daniel Freedman on drums. Monday at 7 p.m., Knitting Factory Old Office, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3132, knittingfactory.com; cover, $8. Wednesday and Thursday at 10 p.m. and midnight, Smalls, 183 West 10th Street, West Village, (212) 675-7369, fatcatjazz.com; cover, $20. (Chinen)

BENNIE WALLACE (Wednesday and Thursday) Mr. Wallace, a tenor saxophonist, offers a preliminary taste of ''Disorder at the Border,'' an album in tribute to the original tenor hero, Coleman Hawkins. His nine-piece band includes fellow veterans like the alto saxophonist Jerry Dodgion and the drummer Alvin Queen. (Through Oct. 29.) At 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232, jazzstandard.net; cover, $25. (Chinen)

MICHAEL WEISS QUINTET (Tuesday through Thursday) Michael Weiss has ample experience with the Village Vanguard piano, though he usually plays it as a sideman. Next week he showcases some of his own thoughtful compositions with a good post-bop group featuring the alto and soprano saxophonist Steve Wilson. Through Oct. 29 at 9 and 11 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037, villagevanguard.com; cover, $20, with a $10 minimum. (Chinen)

BUSTER WILLIAMS AND SOMETHING MORE (Tonight and tomorrow night) The stalwart bass playing of Buster Williams provides an anchor but not the focal point of this dynamic chamber-jazz quartet, with Steve Wilson on alto saxophone, Danny Grissett on piano and Lenny White on drums. At 8, 10 and 11:30, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662, smokejazz.com; cover, $25. (Chinen)

Classical

Full reviews of recent music performances: nytimes.com/music.

Opera

'LA BOHEME' (Tonight and Wednesday) Updated to the years around World War I, this is one of the New York City Opera's best productions. A new cast has taken over for the rest of this run, which ends on Wednesday, including two singers new to the company, Inna Dukach as Mimi, and Robert Gardner as Marcello. Dinyar Vania will sing Rodolfo, Dana Beth Miller is the Musetta, Kyungmook Yum is Schaunard, and Eric Jordan is Colline. Steven Mosteller conducts. Tonight at 8, Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $66 to $125 tonight, $25 to $125 on Wednesday. (Anne Midgette)

'CARMEN' (Sunday and Thursday) Rinat Shaham, who made her company debut as Zerlina, is a small singer for Carmen; worse, the New York City Opera's production seems to have veiled her spark, rendering her a mere stereotype. The high point of this cast is Latonia Moore as a radiant-voiced Micaela. On Thursday night, a new cast takes over: Vanessa Cariddi, Kerri Marcinko and Daesan No will make their company debuts as Carmen, Micaela and Escamillo, and Gary Thor Wedow will replace Ari Pelto in the pit. Sunday at 1:30 p.m., Thursday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 tickets remaining on Sunday, $25 to $125 on Thursday. (Midgette)

'CAVALLERIA RUSTICANA'/'PAGLIACCI' (Tonight, Monday and Thursday) Even for its war horses, the Metropolitan Opera is pulling out some big vocal stops. Of interest in this classic double bill is the appearance of Salvatore Licitra, a tenor who has the vocal goods but has not always fully shown them, as Leoncavallo's Canio, alongside the Nedda of the luminous Patricia Racette, and the always dramatic Maria Guleghina as Santuzza in ''Cavalleria.'' Marco Armiliato conducts. Tonight and Thursday night at 8, Monday night at 7:30, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $275. (Midgette)

'COSI FAN TUTTE' (Tomorrow and Tuesday) Mozart's fantastic battle of the sexes arrives in a New York City Opera production, with a cast that includes Julianna Di Giacomo as Fiordiligi; Sandra Piques Eddy as Dorabella; Ryan MacPherson as Ferrando; Kyle Pfortmiller as Guglielmo and James Maddalena as Don Alfonso. Julius Rudel returns to its podium for this production. Tomorrow at 1:30 p.m.; Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 tickets remaining tomorrow, $25 to $125 on Tuesday. (Allan Kozinn)

'THE ELIXIR OF LOVE' (Tomorrow) The director Jonathan Miller has created an all-American version of Donizetti's ''Elisir d'Amore,'' transposing the action to a vintage roadside diner to create something that's dramatically consistent but also dramatically slight. Yet ''Elisir'' is a delightful opera, and it's decently sung by Anna Skibinsky, an Adina with a little ribbon of a voice; John Tessier, an honest, solid, if North American Nemorino; and especially Jan Opalach, who has a lot of fun and sounds very good as Dulcamara. George Manahan's conducting is not exactly Italianate. At 8 p.m., New York State Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nycopera.com; $25 to $125. (Midgette)

'LA GIOCONDA' (Tomorrow) The Metropolitan Opera's barn-burning, old-fashioned production has a Saturday matinee, still with Violeta Urmana in the title role, and now offering Olga Savova as Laura and Eduardo Villa as Enzo. At 1:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; remaining tickets, $42 to $375. (Bernard Holland)

* 'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' (Tomorrow and Tuesday) The abstract staging of Anthony Minghella's visually beautiful production of ''Madama Butterfly'' deftly employs movable screens, billowing fabrics, stylized costumes and, most daringly, a life-size puppet manipulated by three black-clad puppeteers to portray Butterfly's 3-year-old son. Vocally, neither of the leads, the earthy-voiced soprano Cristina Gallardo-Domas as Butterfly, and the robustly Italianate tenor Marcello Giordani as Lieutenant Pinkerton, is ideal. But they do honorable work. Asher Fisch conducts. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Tuesday at 7:30 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; sold out. (Anthony Tommasini)

'RIGOLETTO' (Wednesday) Otto Schenk's grimly realistic production of Verdi's ''Rigoletto,'' will provide a showcase for a veritable night of debuts at the house. The German soprano Ekaterina Siurina as Gilda, the Malta-born lyric tenor Joseph Calleja as the Duke of Mantua, and the Austrian conductor Friedrich Haider are all making their company debuts. In the title role the veteran baritone Juan Pons should be a steadying influence on his new colleagues. At 8 p.m., the Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212) 362-6000, metopera.org; $15 to $375. (Tommasini)

Classical Music

* ALARM WILL SOUND (Tonight and tomorrow night) Even in the lively world of new-music ensembles, few groups assemble programs as imaginatively, or perform with as much zest, as Alarm Will Sound. For its residency at the Kitchen, the group is performing works by Harrison Birtwistle, Benedict Mason and Dennis DeSantis, one of several composers who also perform in the group, as well as arrangements of Conlon Nancarrow's player-piano pieces and a group of rhythmically complex works from the 14th century. At 8:30, the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org; $12. (Kozinn)

AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Sunday) Leon Botstein's orchestra takes a religious turn with a program called ''The Art of the Psalm.'' It includes pieces by Bruckner, Reger, Schreker, Zemlinsky and Liszt. At 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, americansymphony.org; $27 to $55. (Holland)

BARGEMUSIC (Tonight through Sunday) Robert White, the Irish tenor, is the George Hamilton of the vocal world: an unbowed, ageless veteran. This weekend Bargemusic is celebrating his birthday. (The organizers aren't saying, but it's his 65th.) They are presenting songs, works for piano trio and a few pieces that combine both. Mr. White will sing; the composer Lowell Liebermann will be the pianist (the program includes two of his works); Mark Peskanov, Bargemusic's president and executive director, and Darrett Adkins will join in on violin and cello. Tonight, before the celebration begins, the cellist Robert Cohen and the pianist Paul Ostrovsky offer a varied program, from Mozart to Bruch. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday afternoon at 4, Fulton Ferry Landing next to the Brooklyn Bridge, Brooklyn, (718) 624-2083, bargemusic.org; $35; $20 for students. (Midgette)

* CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER (Tonight and Sunday) Following its successful gala opening concert, the Chamber Music Society begins its regular season under its dynamic new artistic directors (the pianist Wu Han and the cellist David Finckel) with the first in a series of programs titled ''Through Brahms: A Path From Schubert to Kirchner.'' The first program offers works by Schubert, Mendelssohn and Schumann and culminates in Brahms's lushly scored and elegant String Sextet in G. Tonight at 8 and Sunday at 5 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, (212) 875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org; $28 to $50. (Tommasini)

* CHOIR AND ORCHESTRA OF ST. IGNATIUS LOYOLA (Wednesday) This opening concert in Kent Tritle's superb Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series includes Handel's Coronation Anthem, ''The King Shall Rejoice''; Carl Philip Emanuel Bach's ''Magnificat''; and Randall Thompson's exquisite setting of texts from Isaiah, ''The Peaceable Kingdom.'' The soloists are Serena Benedetti, soprano; Sasha Cooke, mezzo-soprano; Oliver Mercer, tenor; and Jesse Blumberg, baritone. At 8 p.m., Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue, at 84th Street, (212) 288-2520, saintignatiusloyola.org; $35 to $45, and $25 for students and 65+. (Kozinn)

BEN HEPPNER (Wednesday) If any tenor has the voice to command a vocal recital in Carnegie Hall it is Mr. Heppner, who sings Grieg, Sibelius, Tchaikovsky and Tosti. The pianist is Thomas Muraco. At 8 p.m., (212) 247-7800; $25 to $82. (Holland)

* KIROV ORCHESTRA (Monday and Tuesday) Last spring Valery Gergiev began his survey of the complete 15 symphonies by Shostakovich, part of Lincoln Center's tribute to the composer for the centennial of his birth. The series continues this week with Mr. Gergiev conducting the Kirov Orchestra of the Maryinsky Theater in Nos. 11 (''The Year 1905'') and 6 on Monday night, and Nos. 12 (''The Year 1917'') and 14 on Tuesday. Mr. Gergiev's spring performances were by turns volatile, bitter, searing and darkly beautiful. Expect the same. At 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; $35 to $69. (Tommasini)

BRAD LUBMAN'S ELECTRIC FUZZ (Tonight) The American Composers Orchestra is looking into the world of composer-performers this season, presenting several composers and their ensembles at Joe's Pub. In this installment Brad Lubman leads Electric Fuzz, which draws on everything from contemporary classical and electronic styles to jazz, klezmer and world music. The program includes works by Mr. Lubman; collaborations between him and Lauren Radnofsky, the ensemble's cellist; and scores by David Lang and Pierre Boulez. At 7, Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 967-7555, americancomposers.org; $20. (Kozinn)

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC (Tonight, tomorrow and Thursday) There are two more chances this weekend to see Sergei Eisenstein's 1938 cinematic masterpiece ''Alexander Nevsky'' at Avery Fisher Hall, with Prokofiev's pulsating score played live by the Philharmonic under its dynamic young associate conductor, Xian Zhang. On Thursday the British-born conductor Jonathan Nott, a champion of contemporary music, comes to the Philharmonic for a program that juxtaposes two works by Beethoven, the seldom-heard ''King Stephen'' Overture and his Fifth Symphony, with two 20th-century scores, Gyorgy Ligeti's atmospheric ''Lontano'' and Bartok's rhapsodic Piano Concerto No. 1. The pianist Peter Serkin is the soloist. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Thursday at 7:30 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, nyphil.org; $28 to $96. (Tommasini)

NHK SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA (Monday) The NHK from Japan gives the music of Toru Takemitsu pride of place in a program that includes the Bartok Third Piano Concerto and the two ''Daphnis et Chloe'' suites of Ravel. Vladimir Ashkenazy conducts the NHK and the Dessoff Symphonic Choir, and Helene Grimaud is the pianist. At 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; $26 to $87. (Holland)

IVO POGORELICH (Thursday) This iconoclastic Croatian pianist has struck some listeners as brilliantly original, and others as purely perverse, but in any case, his interpretations of the great 19th-century keyboard works are unlike anyone else's. He appears here this week with a hefty program that includes sonatas by Chopin (No. 3), Rachmaninoff (No. 2) and Scriabin (No. 4). At 8 p.m., Metropolitan Museum of Art, (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $60. (Kozinn)

STEVE REICH (Tomorrow and Sunday) Carnegie Hall's contribution to the citywide festivities for Steve Reich's 70th birthday are in full swing this weekend. The extravaganza includes a concert tomorrow with the Kronos Quartet and the guitarist Pat Metheny, performing ''Electric Counterpoint'' and ''Different Trains.'' Then the birthday boy and the ensemble he founded, Steve Reich and Musicians, will join Synergy Vocals to play ''Music for 18 Musicians.'' On Sunday Mr. Reich will perform ''Cello Counterpoint'' (with Maya Beiser), ''Piano/Video Phase'' and ''Drumming.'' He'll also present the world premiere of the ''Daniel Variations,'' written for Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter murdered in Pakistan. The other performers include David Cossin on percussion and video. Brad Lubman conducts. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Stern Auditorium, Sunday at 7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $28 to $58 tomorrow; sold out on Sunday. (Vivien Schweitzer)

* RIVERSIDE SYMPHONY (Wednesday) The impressive Riverside Symphony, conducted by George Rothman, opens its 26th season with a typically intriguing lineup. Stravinsky's eclectic Capriccio for Piano and Orchestra precedes the early Symphony No. 1 by the living French master Henri Dutilleux, a composer this orchestra has championed. Two lesser-known Prokofiev works conclude the program: the Chant Symphonique and a suite from the ballet score ''The Prodigal Son.'' At 7:30 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, riversidesymphony.org; $30 to $50; students, half-price. (Tommasini)

ANDRAS SCHIFF AND CAPPELLA ANDREA BARCA (Sunday and Wednesday) With this fine Hungarian pianist and his ensemble, the Mozart onslaught continues, but here at least with some very skilled musical warriors. On Sunday there will be two concertos and the Symphony in G minor (No. 40). Note also Mr. Schiff's all-Mozart solo recital on Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum. Sunday at 2 p.m., Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500, lincolncenter.org; Wednesday at 8 p.m., (212) 570-3949, metmuseum.org; $60. (Holland)

SPHINX CHAMBER ORCHESTRA/HARLEM QUARTET (Tuesday) The goal is to get black and Hispanic students involved with classical music. A continuing result, or a part of it, can be heard in the Carnegie Hall performance by winners of the Sphinx competition. The winners -- as soloists, members of the Sphinx Chamber Orchestra or as the Harlem Quartet (in its Carnegie debut) -- play Mozart, Marsalis and a range of music in between. The orchestra is an outgrowth of the Sphinx Organization, a 10-year-old nonprofit that has provided scholarships and instruments to thousands of students, and its last Carnegie gala was said to be first-rate. At 6 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $20 to $80. (Midgette)

YSAE QUARTET (Sunday) This string quartet, formed more than two decades ago by students at the Paris Conservatory, returns to the Frick Collection's music room with a program that includes Haydn's Quartet in F (Op. 77, No. 2); Debussy's Quartet in G minor; and Schumann's Quartet in A. The concert by the Ysae can also be heard free via a sound system in the Garden Court. At 5 p.m., 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan, (212) 547-0715, frick.org; $25. (Schweitzer)

(La Rocco)

* SARAH MICHELSON (Tonight and tomorrow) A star of downtown experimental modern dance gets her big Next Wave Festival break with a piece called ''Dogs,'' commissioned by the Brooklyn Academy of Music and designed for its Harvey Theater space. At 7:30 p.m., Harvey Theater, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100 or bam.org; $20 to $40. (Rockwell)

MOLLIE O'BRIEN/MOB PRODUCTIONS (Tonight through Sunday) Ms. O'Brien's quartet ''Mammal'' explores how aggression and force relate to intimacy and connection. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Sunday at 3 p.m., Dance New Amsterdam, 280 Broadway, at Chambers Street, TriBeCa, (212) 279-4200, ticketcentral.com and dnadance.org; $17. (Dunning)

PEAK PERFORMANCES: JAN FABRE (Tomorrow and Sunday) This series aims to provoke, and its choice is Jan Fabre, who is said to be a first-rate provocateur. His new ''Quando l'uomo principale e una donna'' (''When the Leading Man Turns Out to Be a Woman'') is a homage to Yves Klein, who used nude women as paintbrushes. Mr. Fabre takes things further by coating the stage floor with olive oil. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m., Sunday at 3 p.m., Alexander Kasser Theater, Montclair State University, Normal Avenue, Montclair, N.J., (973) 655-5112 or peakperfs.org; $35. (Dunning)

* SANKAI JUKU (Tuesday and Thursday) Japan's best-known Butoh troupe returns with a piece called ''Kagemi: Beyond the Metaphors of Mirrors,'' with seven near-naked, chalk-covered men enacting one of its slow-motion visionary dreamscapes. (Through Oct. 28.) At 7:30 p.m., Howard Gilman Opera House, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100 or bam.org; $20 to $60. (Rockwell)

SUNDAYS @ THREE (Sunday) Janaki Patrik and her Kathak Ensemble present ''New Links in the Chain,'' a program of traditional and new North Indian dance, with Max Pollak, in this informal series of dance and discussion. At 3 p.m., 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Center, 1395 Lexington Avenue, (212) 415-5500 or 92y.org/dance; $10. (Dunning)

WAVE RISING SERIES (Wednesday and Thursday) Clearly a workaholic, Young Soon Kim, director of the White Wave studios in Brooklyn and presenter of the Dumbo Dance Festival, moves on to another ambitious event. Fourteen emerging and established choreographers, chosen by Ms. Kim and other panelists, will present 17 pieces in 8 programs over 2 weeks in Wave Rising. (Through Nov. 5.) At 7:30 p.m., John Ryan Theater, 25 Jay Street, Dumbo section of Brooklyn, (718) 855-8822 or whitewavedance.com; $25 at the door, $20 in advance. (Dunning)
