HEADLINE: Gateway Newark

BYLINE: By Julia Vitullo-Martin. 
Julia Vitullo-Martin is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

 BODY:
WITH his first 100 days behind him, Mayor Cory Booker of Newark is already immersed in the difficult task of administering a city that Harper's Magazine once called the worst in America. Mayor Booker is young, smart and likable, but restoring his city to prosperity is not going to be easy. Soon after he took office, after a campaign in which he announced that public safety would be his top priority, both homicides and shootings in the city spiked. In effect, Newark welcomed its new mayor with a mini crime wave. 
 To borrow a favorite Booker word, the fundamental challenges facing Newark are ''daunting.'' The city is a living laboratory for nearly every bad planning idea of the 20th century. Urban renewal destroyed whole neighborhoods, replacing low-rise, vernacular residences with public housing projects. Built on superblocks, the projects wiped out the original grid as well as commercial and retail activity. Interstate highways cut the city into pieces, dividing and isolating neighborhoods. And crime, of course, made sport of the general civic unraveling. 
Corporations, most prominently Prudential Insurance, tried to help. But to protect employees from the deteriorating environment, they built fortress-like towers, connected to the train station and to one another by skywalks, bypassing the streets below and walling off the waterfront with parking garages and hostile architecture. Meanwhile, surface roads were widened to facilitate traffic, making escape to the suburbs more efficient. Gradually, shops and restaurants closed, leaving a few dejected discount stores behind.
 Despite this bleak history, there is cause for hope. Newark rightly calls itself a ''gateway'' -- in transportation the city has it all: a major international airport 10 minutes away; an international container port on the waterfront; passenger and freight railroads; light rail; and major highways. Newark is more accessible than almost any city of its size in America. 
 Moreover, unlike St. Louis, Detroit or Buffalo, Newark is situated in the heart of the most dynamic and economically powerful metropolitan region in the country. If the value of real estate is indeed derived from location, there is no reason for Newark to remain a crime-ridden, failing city of vacant lots and underused property bordered by a forlorn waterfront.
 That's why the Booker administration must emphasize a second priority right behind public safety-- development. To return people to the city's streets, parks and public spaces -- and to increase the tax base -- Newark needs intense, mixed-use development on vacant land as well as conversion of its many abandoned industrial buildings.
 The goal is to drive out harmful uses of space, like drug dealing, and replace them with positive uses -- people working, walking, shopping and playing in the parks. This can happen only if the administration accelerates the pace of redevelopment that has already begun, including the renovation of two magnificent downtown Art Deco buildings, one for offices, the other for residences. 
 To capitalize on its latent strengths, Newark should pursue three strategies:
 First, promote market-rate housing in the downtown core and publicize Newark's bargain prices. Though Newark is only 15 minutes by PATH train from Midtown Manhattan, luxury apartments in Newark rent for about half the price of those in Manhattan. In a bargain-scarce metropolitan region, a $1,500 per month luxury one-bedroom can attract urban pioneers to transitional neighborhoods, just as similar bargains attracted residents to Jersey City a decade ago.
 Second, invigorate the empty, largely inaccessible waterfront and reconnect it to downtown. The informal waterfront evenings organized last summer by the New Jersey Performing Arts Center proved that people will flock to Newark's waterfront if given access and a reason. The once decrepit waterfronts of diverse cities like Milwaukee, San Antonio, and Miami now teem with people, life, and revenue -- and so can Newark's.
 Third, clean up the city with business improvement districts. Newark's dejected appearance is in part due to its abundance of vacant property. But it's also a result of outdated and inappropriate signs and facades, says Linda Epps, president of the New Jersey Historical Society. ''We need a plan for the kind of image the city wants to project,'' Ms. Epps said, ''one that applauds the wonderful old architecture that hasn't been taken advantage of.'' 
 One proven mechanism is the creation of business improvement districts, in which successful property owners join those who need help. All parties contribute, with the wealthiest paying the largest share, to clean up and improve business areas for all. 
 There is no denying the challenges Newark faces. But with energetic new leadership and the right development strategies, the city can come back. Of the many post-industrial cities still devastated by the effects of job loss, urban renewal, federal redlining, highway construction, riots, flight to the suburbs, corruption and mismanagement, Newark has the best chance of returning to the ranks of the successful. 
 The right development will capitalize on Newark's strategic location, realizing a long-desired ''gateway'' not only to New York City, but to a prosperous future.

HEADLINE: For Latinos, Familiar Faces May Not Be Friendly Bosses 

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
GLORIA AZPEITIA worked as a secretary in Mexico before she came to this country in 1993, and for a while managed to get by selling tamales door to door. Then eight years ago she began cleaning houses, preferring to work for other Latinos because they also spoke Spanish and, she said, were more understanding of her needs.
 That is why, Ms. Azpeitia said, she was stunned three years ago when a Mexican-American boss she had worked for for two years suddenly showed his authoritarian side after her daughter went into labor and Ms. Azpeitia showed up late because of the family emergency.
'' 'I'm going to punish you,' he said, like I was a little girl,'' Ms. Azpeitia recalled. '' 'You're going to do more for the same price.' '' 
 She quit on the spot, she said, offended by his condescension. And while such a reaction could have come from any boss, that it came from a Latino, she said, felt ''like a bucket of hot water.''
 ''It hurts more when it comes from Latin people because they are compatriots,'' said Ms. Azpeitia, 50, who is divorced and has two daughters and five grandchildren. ''We all need each other. They forget we are all the same.''
 In the employment market for both legal and illegal immigrants, many nannies and maids are finding their first jobs among the older generations of Latinos, who are now in a position to hire domestic help. But while the two groups of strivers may gravitate toward each other because of cultural and language similarities, their intersection can also be fraught with odd tensions and broken expectations, say researchers, employers and workers.
 A slight, for instance, can take on new dimensions. 
 ''Sometimes the skin is kind of thin,'' said Leo Chavez, an anthropology professor and director of the Center for Research on Latinos in a Global Society at the University of California, Irvine. ''If an Anglo says something, they let it shake off, but when a Latino says it, they are hurt. They expect empathy.''
 Immigration has spawned a Hispanic population that is now 60 percent American-born and 40 percent immigrant. Particularly in established Latino footholds like California and Florida, the educational and economic gains among American-born Latinos enable many to offer work to immigrants in their businesses and homes, although there are no hard figures on the frequency of these ''co-ethnic'' interactions.
 According to an analysis of census figures by the Pew Hispanic Center, 36 percent of Hispanic households in 2002 had assets that put them in the middle class, and 7 percent more belonged in the top ranks of wealth. While cheap labor and availability play a role in Latinos' seeking Latino workers, employers are also motivated by personal reasons, like wanting their children to grow up bilingual through daily interaction with a Spanish-speaking nanny. And for workers without English and an understanding of American culture, turning to other Latinos for jobs at least guarantees communication and some degree of familiarity in a foreign land. 
 Reina I. Flamenco, 43, a Salvadoran nanny, said she is never certain what she has just agreed to when working for English-speaking employers.
 ''When she gave me cooking instructions, I was like, did she mean she wanted her eggs scrambled or fried?'' Ms. Flamenco said of one.
 ''Once they told me, 'When you leave, don't let the cat out,' but sometimes I'd be so insecure. Did she say to leave the cat inside or outside? It's hard because I don't want people to get mad.'' 
 Carmen Denis, the coordinator of the Caring Hands job-training program at Mujeres Unidas y Activas, a Bay Area group for immigrant Latinas, said most members are undocumented, recently arrived, and ''in the beginning they resist working with English-speaking families.'' 
 But the dynamics of Latinos working for other Latinos also depend on class, sociologists and others familiar with the labor market said: on whether, for example, the employers come from families who also labored in menial jobs. Nowhere are the social relations more intimate than in the close quarters of a home. For the workers, there can be both benefits and tensions in the same household.
 Marta Rodriguez, 33, works for a Latina who hired her to care for her elderly mother twice a week. She said her employer is always available to help with translations and calls that require English. The employer, a real estate agent, also encourages her to go to school and aim high, Ms. Rodriguez said.
 But she said that the employer's own experience as a hotel housekeeper 30 years ago, when she came to this country from Argentina, has made her unusually demanding. Ms. Rodriguez, who is married to a baker and has five children, said she is also expected to clean, cook and garden. She must use a toothbrush to get dirt out of windowsills, she said, and must clean floors on her knees as if they were ''a work of art.''
 ''She says, 'You're going to leave here well taught,' '' Ms. Rodriguez said.
 But some employers say they have a deeply personal reason to seek Latino employees: They want to help a fellow Latino who sometimes reminds them of the struggles of their own parents.
 Elizabeth Gallagher, 52, who owns a general contracting business in Las Vegas, said that her mother made a living as a maid for most of her working life after her father died when Ms. Gallagher was 5. Now that she is able to offer work to a Latino, at home and at her company, she said, ''I try to bring people up along with myself.''
 ''I know how hard my mother worked, and there were times we didn't have food,'' said Ms. Gallagher, who grew up in Tucson and has four siblings.
 Some Latino employers have more practical reasons. When Stella Blankenship's elderly father was hospitalized, and it was obvious he could no longer take care of her mother alone, Ms. Blankenship, 50, a registered nurse in the Bay Area, said she desperately called employment agencies to find a companion who spoke Spanish.
 Her mother, Lupe Valencia, 82, who never learned English well and suffers from Alzheimer's, needed someone she could connect with, Ms. Blankenship said. So in came Maria Guadalupe Calvillo, 36, who came from Mexico like her parents and had toiled as an immigrant as they did when they arrived in this country in the 1950's, her mother as a laundress, her father working in the field and laying railroad tracks.
 Ms. Calvillo, who is married and has two young children, cooks Mexican treats like fried tripe, tongue tacos and bread pudding. When Mrs. Valencia has a bad day, they hold hands and pray together to the Virgin of Guadalupe for a cure.
 Ms. Blankenship's father, Bernardo Valencia, 80, who still works as a notary public despite diabetes and heart disease, says of Ms. Calvillo, ''She has the humanity and kindness typical of the State of Michoacan,'' where she comes from.
 Ms. Calvillo, too, has wrapped emotions around the couple that go beyond the employee-employer relationship.
 ''My mother died of cancer 10 years ago, and I would have liked to have taken care of her the way I do with la senora Lupita,'' said Ms. Calvillo, who works from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. on weekdays and is paid $15 an hour. ''She treats me with so much affection, and that is what reminds me of my mother.''
 When relationships work, there is a deep comfort level, cultural sensitivity and communion of values and customs. But some Latina domestic workers say they avoid Latino employers because of the attitudes some bring from their home countries, like treating workers like servants or haggling over pay. 
 In some surveys Latino employers get mixed reviews. ''It's a mixed bag,'' said Abel Valenzuela Jr., an urban planning professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, who has surveyed workers and employers. ''You have Latino employers who want to help immigrants and understand their struggle,'' he added. ''But not all Latinos are benevolent.''
 In a study of 500 day laborers Professor Valenzuela did in 1999, the workers ranked Latinos lower than Anglos in fair treatment, but higher than Asians and right alongside blacks. The workers were employed by homeowners as construction laborers, landscapers and painters.
 Professor Valenzuela said the workers may be holding Latinos to a higher standard than other employers. ''Here's a Latino who has the means to hire them,'' he said. ''The workers have higher expectations.''
 AMONG Latina nannies, house cleaners and companions, common complaints about bosses, regardless of ethnicity, revolve around being asked to do more work than was originally agreed upon for the same pay, having their working hours extended, being constantly watched while they work and having to put up with difficult employers. ''They complain that their bosses take out their frustrations on them,'' said Ms. Denis of Mujeres Unidas y Activas.
 But pay is the biggest issue, Ms. Denis said, since most of the women are heads of household. A 2004 survey of 247 domestic workers by a coalition of groups that represent the women in the Bay Area found that most of the workers reported being unable to meet basic living expenses and that most worked overtime without compensation.
 A bill that would ensure overtime for nannies and allow them and other domestic workers to sue for back wages was vetoed last month by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who said it would encourage frivolous litigation. 
 But while household workers lack many basic worker rights like health insurance and paid days off, they can still seek to ''do the job with dignity,'' said Guillermina Castellanos, a coordinator of worker programs at La Raza Centro Legal here. The most active of the women teach one another how to fend for themselves at organizations like La Raza and Mujeres Unidas y Activas. Housed in the Women's Building in the Mission District, Mujeres trains women to negotiate hours, to clean with natural products like vinegar and baking soda and to perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
 Ms. Azpeitia, a Mujeres member, said she is cleaning for a Latina employer who shares her values and ''sentimientos.'' Her employer didn't make a fuss, for example, when Ms. Azpeitia showed up for work with her granddaughter on one occasion because her daughter couldn't take care of the child. ''She said, 'No problem, turn the TV on,' '' Ms. Azpeitia said. 
 ''Because she is Latina she knows how to value me.'' And in the end, Ms. Azpeitia said, she looks at her Latino employers as role models.
 ''If they could make it,'' she said, ''why wouldn't I accomplish the same?''

 HOME AWAY FROM HOME -- Marta Rodriguez said that her Latina employer is supportive and encouraging, if demanding. (Photographs by Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For Music's Sake

BYLINE: By DANIEL J. WAKIN

 BODY:
IT can wreck a marriage, reconfigure a home, lead to late-night sorties and seductive soirees -- and yet hundreds of suburbanites nurture an obsession with a seemingly genteel practice: playing chamber music. 
 Behind the placid lawns and condominium walls of New York's suburbs, these amateur musicians cluster around music stands in living rooms and dens after connecting at seminars and on street corners, through e-mail messages, word-of-mouth and cold calls. Many, after studying since childhood, had aspired to performing careers and even attended conservatory, but went instead into law or medicine or accounting or teaching. The yen to play, though, never left, so they live in a parallel musical world of amateur orchestras, ad hoc music sessions and long-established groups that adopt the familiar patterns of married couples (or more often, quartets or quintets).
''It's a great labor of love,'' said William Becker, 75, of West Orange, N.J. ''I lose myself in it.''
 Mr. Becker said that in the early 1980's, he picked up his cello after a long layoff following a ''tremendous personal tragedy,'' one that he did not wish to talk about. 
 ''I found my cello in the attic and got it fixed,'' he said. ''I just needed it. It was there for me. It pulled me back to life.'' 
 He now plays in two amateur orchestras in New Jersey -- the Summit Symphony and the Metropolitan Orchestra in West Orange -- and takes part in chamber music seminars. Scores of such seminars, like music camps for adults, take place around the country, mostly in the summer.
 ''I like playing with other people,'' Mr. Becker said. ''You're sitting there, and you're playing. You know you may not be playing perfectly in tune, and your interpretation may be bizarre, but the fact is, there are times where it really sounds good. It's transforming. It's transcendental -- is that the word?''
 Many of the amateurs, like Mr. Becker, a former securities analyst, are retirees who have the leisure time to play and who delight in the social connections. Others have to maneuver around the schedules of their young children to find time to rehearse. Still others are single and keep their antennae up for potential mates when they join new chamber ensembles. 
 Groups form and dissolve, often fed by the amateur orchestras that dot the region. They are all part of the larger universe of amateur classical music-making, which includes choruses. 
 Playing at home and for the love of it is an unseen aspect of the nation's cultural life, an activity that follows a direct line from 18th-century European drawing rooms to 21st-century family rooms. Nowadays, e-mail has made organizing groups much easier. Musicians also have a formal network, the Amateur Chamber Music Players association, which publishes directories listing willing players around the world. Its Web site quickly yields a handful of oboists or double bassists in any given region. Players grade themselves according to the association's guidelines and list their instruments, contact information, availability and languages spoken. 
 The association lists 75 members in northern New Jersey, about 50 each in southern Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester and 200 in the five boroughs of New York. Countless other music makers, of course, do not belong to it.
 Community orchestras and music seminars are also an important source for playing partners. So are chance encounters.
 ''I've met somebody on the street with an instrument and said, 'Hey, you want to play quartets?' '' said Lucretia M. Harrison of Port Washington, N.Y. Ms. Harrison, a violist, said she plays quartets once or twice a week, and performs occasionally at gatherings of the Port Washington Music Study Club in Nassau County, ''a bunch of ladies that meet once a month in people's homes and perform for each other.''
 The habit is ingrained in Ms. Harrison, a wry 85-year-old who has been playing chamber music for more than 60 years.
 The quartet that she has been playing with has been ''very tolerant'' of her, she said, ''although I miss some of the notes.''
 Ms. Harrison said she started playing violin in the fourth grade and switched to viola several years later. She formed her first quartet in high school in Port Washington, meeting the other members in an amateur opera company. As a young adult, she moved in with her sister in Manhattan, where an old boyfriend from high school tracked her down.
 ''He came a-courtin','' she said. ''So, by golly, we got married, and I moved back to Port Washington.'' 
 She worked as a public school teacher and librarian and raised four children, one of whom, a son, is an amateur French horn player. 
 Days after being interviewed, Ms. Harrison fell in her home and broke a hip. Yet she was undaunted and determined to keep playing. ''I couldn't live if I couldn't get back to it,'' she said in a later interview. ''If it takes three weeks or three months or three years, I'll get back to it.''
 Joseph Gluck, a violinist who retired from the New Jersey Symphony two years ago, runs a weekend workshop in Maplewood that has 82 people signed up. Mostly string players, they are generally assigned to groups by Mr. Gluck and rehearse for two hours on Saturdays. A coach counsels them for one of the two hours of the session. At the fourth session, they perform for each other. The cost is $160. The sessions take place in an Ethical Culture Society building.
 Mr. Gluck said he must negotiate around musicians who rate themselves too highly, or too modestly. ''I always try to encourage people to believe that if they are the strongest person in the group, it's a wonderful opportunity to share their knowledge and expertise,'' he said. 
 At the same time, he does not blame people for wanting to play with others at their own level.
 ''If I'm good at something, it's maintaining an atmosphere where people lose their competitive edges and try to remember we're playing music as a joyful experience, and to leave all the stuff that they do in real life away from the building and just come here for the pure joy of the whole thing.''
 Professional musicians sometimes get caught up in the business aspects of performing, Mr. Gluck said. ''But when you surround yourself with people who are doing it with one motivation, who love music, it infects oneself and keeps you optimistic,'' he said.
 The nature of suburban life, including the need to travel by car, often on heavily trafficked roads, inevitably creates differences in the way chamber music is lived in New York City and outside of it. Suburban players say there seems to be less socializing after music sessions, partly because of the time it takes to drive home. But the hours invested in travel also imply a greater commitment to the sessions.
 ''Just to try to get four people together at a common time is quite difficult,'' said Lisa Uckardes, a violinist and public school string teacher from Hicksville, N.Y. ''Honestly, I wouldn't look past Queens for anything because the traffic can really be kind of bad.''
 Groups that may not be compatible will often stay together because it is harder to find a substitute nearby, some players said. At the same time, playing in a house as opposed to an apartment means there is less worry about disturbing the neighbors downstairs, so rehearsals can go longer and later. 
 But living in a house has not necessarily made rehearsing easier for Kevin Root, a cello-playing psychotherapist who lives in Greenwich, Conn. He has 13-year-old identical twin boys whose presence makes scheduling music sessions difficult.
 ''They're asrambunctious as the day is long,'' he said. ''They would never allow me to take up that much space.'' His solution would probably not occur in Manhattan. He is converting his garage into a chamber music room in a $20,000 renovation.
 In many ways, Mr. Root exemplifies the rhythms and customs of the amateur chamber musician. He plays in an amateur group called the American Chamber Orchestra, based in Fairfield County. During a break in a rehearsal a little more than six months ago he turned to a violist nearby and asked if she would be interested in playing string quartets.
 ''She said, 'Definitely,' '' Mr. Root recalled. Whom, they wondered, could they recruit? The violist, who runs an after-school string program, mentioned a violin teacher who had recently graduated from the Eastman School of Music, in Rochester. The violist also brought in a second violinist she had played with years ago. 
 Presto, a string quartet.
 ''We get along quite well,'' Mr. Root said. ''That seems to be at least 50 percent of playing music, the ability to get along. I find it extremely difficult to put together groups, because of personality conflicts.''
 In fact, he said, it has taken him 10 years to form a quartet that stuck. Once, a nascent group fell apart because the first violinist had a ''dictatorial approach'' to playing music. ''No one wanted to play again,'' he said. ''It's personalities that just have to jell.''
 Another quartet lasted only six months. The first violinist was a conservatory-trained pianist who taught himself the violin. ''He sounded like a pianist playing the violin,'' Mr. Root said. ''He was very percussive. I couldn't stand to play with him anymore. I had to remove myself from that group.''
 In another case, Mr. Root said, he joined a quartet with a woman who had recently divorced. ''She decided she wanted me to be her boyfriend,'' he said. ''That fell apart very quickly.''
 Mismatched ability levels can also be a problem. A weaker player can frustrate the stronger players. 
 ''It's very hard to find the proper level and somebody you like and want to be with,'' said Lori C. Marden, a violinist also of Greenwich. Ms. Marden, a committed practicer, generally plays trios with a pianist and cellist on Monday mornings; string quartets from morning until after lunch every other Wednesday or so; and duos with a pianist on Friday mornings.
 ''I'm a fanatic,'' she said. ''It's part of me. There's no way that I could not do this. Music is so much a part of my life. It's always in my head, always.''
 Ms. Marden, who is unmarried, said she sometimes wondered how people dealt with enthusiastic music-making spouses. A pianist she has played with was married to a nonmusician, she said. ''The pianist became much more of a pianist and practiced all the time, and the marriage broke up,'' she said. The pianist later married a horn player, Ms. Marden said, adding that they remain happily together. 
 Some musical groups last longer than many marriages.
 Dr. Ralph Kirmser of Wilton, Conn., an oboist, founded a woodwind quintet 25 years ago with a French horn player, who remains with the group. (The other three members have changed.) ''We're called the Prevailing Winds,'' Dr. Kirmser said.
 The quintet often performs in nursing homes and libraries. ''It makes a difference,'' Dr. Kirmser said. ''It really focuses our rehearsals.''
 The personnel is typical: the horn player is a lawyer in Fairfield; the bassoonist is a dentist in Westport; a Bridgeport lawyer plays flute; the clarinetist teaches music in the Greenwich school system; and Dr. Kirmser is a cardiologist at Norwalk Hospital. 
 Dr. Kirmser recently began playing with another quintet, based in New York City. The commute to rehearsals takes him an hour. ''It adds a certain level of difficulty to get in there, and hence commitment to keep that group going,'' he said.
 Other amateur players eschew performances, preferring to sight-read or rehearse just for themselves.
 ''You have to have more dedication,'' said Michael Ira Asen, an oboist who lives in Mamaroneck, N.Y. Mr. Asen said his wind quintet had given only a few performances since its founding in 1995. 
 A litigator during the week, Mr. Asen turns the weekends over to tennis and the oboe. He practices for an hour on Saturday afternoon. His golden retriever, Mr. Asen asserts, keeps track of wrong notes and bad intonation with a bark. On Sunday morning, ''the guys'' gather at the home of a member of the quintet, which also includes a doctor, an economics professor, a retired lawyer and a marketing executive. 
 ''There is something really extraordinary about playing music,'' Mr. Asen said. ''It elevates you.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: STRING TIME -- Kevin Root, right, a cellist, and Polly Jimenez, a violist, during a chamber music session at her home in Stamford, Conn. Allison McCann, a violinist, completed the trio. (Photo by Janet Durrans for The New York Times)(pg. 1)

HEADLINE: Boo! Halloween Is for the Kids

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Halloween on Heels,'' by Allison Glock (Op-Ed, Oct. 16):
 As a working mother of two young girls, I am taken aback by the glut of crude female fantasy images that saturate our culture. 
 But I am also struck by the parade of female representations that are consistently either hyper-sexy (Wal-Mart's saucy Red Riding Hoods) or totally sexless (Ms. Glock's description of pumpkins and nuns).
Where are images of women that integrate an appreciation of mind and body, of sensuality and sense? 
 It is no wonder that girls grow up internalizing images that are polarized, one-dimensional and ultimately unrealistic. 

Sharon Bober
Cambridge, Mass., Oct. 16, 2006

To the Editor:
 One antidote for avoiding inappropriate Halloween costumes is to create them yourself. 
 I have no talent or training for sewing, but my daughter and I have managed to pull together outfits for her representing one of ''The Twelve Dancing Princesses'' from the Brothers Grimm, Ms. Frizzle from ''The Magic School Bus'' series, and Astrid Lindgren's ''Pippi Longstocking.''
 Our inspiration for the character selections came from her school's ''Books Come Alive'' event, which allows costumes to be worn on Halloween only if they represent characters from a book. Parents are invited to read stories in the classroom and participate in an all-school literary parade. 
 Need I mention that this approach is also economical, and no Halloween hookers need apply.

Raleigh Mayer
New York, Oct. 16, 2006

To the Editor:
 I am a 12-year-old girl who has always been the first in my group of friends to know what I am going to be for Halloween, and this article caught my eye. 
 This morning, I stood outside my Westchester middle school with a group of about five girls. The typical conversation starter this time of year is, ''What are you going to be for Halloween?'' So we were all surprised when everyone replied, ''I don't know.'' 
 As it turned out, we had all visited a costume store or flipped through a catalog this weekend and felt that all the costumes were too revealing. 
 This year, I was planning on being Superwoman, but when I went online to look for a costume, none of the skirts even came close to my knees. I could barely even get to my neighbor's house without freezing in a costume like that. 
 Luckily, I have lots of dress-up clothes I'm going to use to make my costume this year, but what I want to know is, When did ghost and hippie costumes turn into French maids?

Julia Schwarz
New Rochelle, N.Y., Oct. 16, 2006

HEADLINE: Who Will Heal Us as We Grow Old?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Geriatrics Lags in an Age of High-Tech Medicine'' (front page, Oct. 18):
 The population is aging, and there will never be enough geriatricians to provide care to even the frailest boomers. Training nongeriatricians in geriatric care is vital.
But we must also train geriatricians of the future to be leaders of health care systems. In leadership roles, geriatricians can bring geriatric principles of care to bear on large populations of older people. 
 Failure to ''geriatricize'' our health care system will condemn older Americans to care organized in a manner incompatible with their needs, and will bankrupt the nation.

Bruce Leff, M.D.
Baltimore, Oct. 18, 2006

The writer is an associate professor, Division of Geriatric Medicine, at Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine.

To the Editor:
 Your excellent article about the growing demand for geriatricians highlights the adverse financial incentives for physicians considering this challenging specialty.
 Changing Medicare's fee structure is an obvious and simple solution. But when Medicare spending comprises 14 percent of the federal budget, fears of escalating costs (and taxes) sabotage rational discussion. Underlying these fears are common assumptions or myths about aging and economics.
 We must both broaden and clarify our policy discussions concerning economic productivity in our aging society. A serious examination of the evidence leads to the provocative yet undeniable conclusion that the economic benefits of high-quality geriatric care will outweigh its costs.

Marianne C. Fahs
New York, Oct. 18, 2006

The writer is a professor of urban public health at Hunter College and acting executive director of the Brookdale Center on Aging.

To the Editor:
 Ask experienced geriatric social workers, and they will confirm the points made in your article.
 We spend a great deal of time second-guessing doctors' diagnoses and care plans that recommend surgery and other invasive ''high tech'' procedures. We go to seminars and conferences to share best practices for our elderly clients, knowing that we may have to intervene on behalf of the family members, or, in many cases, the client, who is all alone.
 We search for geriatricians like Dr. Rosanne Leipzig at Mount Sinai, and feel lucky to have found a few. We team up with nurse practitioners who treat the patients holistically and with respect. This takes time, patience and persistence, along with experience and skill.
 We joke around that while we ''dropped out of medical school,'' we're following the doctors' creed of ''first, do no harm.''

Beth Zeidel
Brooklyn, Oct. 19, 2006

To the Editor:
 Medical students' and residents' time, as well as the funds of training programs, are limited. Additional geriatrics training has to be taken from someplace else, and I suspect that it will be pediatrics.
 In my medical school we were inundated with geriatric instruction that seemed endless because it was nothing more than a duplication of material we'd been taught in internal medicine. To the contrary, we received the minimum amount of pediatrics instruction necessary to maintain our accreditation.
 I am not aware, nor did you present any evidence, that the medical care of the elderly is substandard. In fact, every trend I'm aware of indicates that people in this country are having longer functional lives than at any time in history and that the elderly are subjected to too many expensive procedures. 
 On the contrary, there is much evidence that children hospitalized in dedicated children's hospitals have less morbidity and shorter hospitalizations than those hospitalized in community hospitals. 
 This may be because the pediatric training of specialists not trained by a pediatric fellowship -- that is, surgeons, radiologists and emergency-room physicians -- is occasionally inadequate. 
 Unfortunately, millions of American children do not have access to children's hospitals.
 Please, no more wailing about the state of geriatric medicine in this country. The elderly receive excellent medical care. Children's health care desperately requires more resources and better-trained practitioners.

Jonathan D. Reich, M.D.
Lakeland, Fla., Oct. 18, 2006

The writer is a fellow of the American Academy of Pediatrics.

To the Editor:
 The concept that one field of medicine is of more value than another and that hence some doctors deserve to be paid more than others is absurd and is just one more symptom of our ailing medical care system.
 Neurosurgery is no more difficult than geriatrics; cardiology is not more beneficial than pediatrics. If we continue to reimburse physicians as if one specialty deserves more than another, we will continue to shunt physicians into fields of greatest financial remuneration and we will attract into medicine people who would rather be technicians than caregivers. 
 While some physicians will benefit, patients certainly will not. 

Mark Miller, M.D.
Seattle, Oct. 18, 2006

The writer practices emergency medicine.

HEADLINE: Tension, Desperation: The China-North Korean Border 

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

 BODY:
NORTH KOREA'S porous 880-mile border with China is its lifeline to the outside world. About 39 percent of its trade last year was with China, which, critically, supplies it with 80 to 90 percent of its oil. Trafficking in money transfers and human beings also flourishes. 
 By contrast, North Korea's border with Russia is 11 miles and heavily guarded; the 150-mile-long demilitarized zone with South Korea has hundreds of thousands of soldiers on each side. Until now, the North's ships have regularly visited Japan, from which relatives sent cash and goods, but North Korea's nuclear test is expected to end that trade.
For China, the bottom line is to erect the right number of fences, as it did along the border city of Dandong recently. Build too few and you invite instability in China. Build too many and North Korea collapses.
 A collapse is clearly something Beijing doesn't want, and why it is lukewarm toward harsh sanctions. A collapse might send more North Koreans into China than the 100,000 to 300,000 estimated to have flooded the border during the North's great famine in the mid- to late-1990's. (Paradoxically, the famine also opened trade links when local North Korean groups formed to barter raw materials for Chinese grain.) 
 The end of the North Korean state could also bring reunification of the Korean Peninsula under America's ally South Korea, another development Beijing does not want. Also, the border itself could be put into question. South Korea has, in recent years, challenged China over the legacy of Koguryo, an ancient Korean kingdom whose rule extended into present-day China. The region is home to hundreds of thousands of ethnic Korean-Chinese, who face discrimination in China and might be sympathetic toward a reunified Korea making territorial claims.

HEADLINE: Marie Antoinette, Citoyenne

BYLINE: By ERIC KONIGSBERG

 BODY:
SHE may never have said the words that got her in Bartlett's -- ''Let them eat cake'' -- but she might as well have. Nevertheless, the image of Marie Antoinette -- dauphine, villain, tea-party thrower in shepherdess garb -- is in the midst of an extreme rehab.
 What with Sofia Coppola's movie, two sympathetic books (''Queen of Fashion,'' a biography by Caroline Weber, and ''Abundance,'' a work of historical fiction by Sena Jeter Naslund); and a PBS documentary, we're having a Marie Antoinette moment. And she doesn't even have a publicist. 
The question, then, might be less a matter of what to make of Marie Antoinette, than of why the makeover, and why now? Of all the victimizers in history, why are we suddenly flooded with these new narratives that show us Marie Antoinette -- vain, selfish, solipsistic and venal -- as a victim?
 The simplest answer may be that most Americans don't have even the flimsiest grasp of who she was.
 ''Never underestimate our historical illiteracy,'' says the historian Ron Chernow, whose biography of Alexander Hamilton explored the Founding Fathers' disagreements over the excesses of the French Revolution. ''Unburdened by an existing context through which to view her life, it becomes much easier to see her simply as a captive of the monarchy and a captive of her own celebrity.''
 Even in the packaging, the current depictions paint Marie Antoinette -- the most significant target of a most significant populist revolt -- as herself a revolutionary. 
 ''Her required wardrobe included 12-foot wide hoopskirts,'' reads the jacket copy of Ms. Weber's book. ''But when she became queen, Marie Antoinette rebelled, seeking to establish her own royal style as a way to seduce the public (and distract attention from her failure to conceive).'' 
 The cover flap of ''Abundance'' describes her as ''a heroine of inspiring stature, one whose nobility arises not from the circumstance of her birth but from her courageous spirit.'' And the lettering on the advertisements for Ms. Coppola's movie -- on crudely cut hot-pink banners -- recall the cover of the Sex Pistols' album ''Never Mind the Bollocks.'' (God save the Queen, anyone?)
 Americans' relationship to rebellion, in any case, is more complicated than you might think. ''It was thought of as an attractive concept through much of the 20th century,'' Mr. Chernow says. ''But at the moment, we're living in the aftermath of many failed revolutions -- Communism and Fascism come to mind -- and with the conspicuous exception of the jihadists, people are more attuned to the excesses of revolution.''
 Robert H. Frank, the Cornell economist whose books include ''Luxury Fever: Why Money Fails to Satisfy in an Era of Excess,'' says that although the gap between the rich and the rest of us has only widened over the last 35 or 40 years, ''Americans aren't known for great class resentment toward the wealthy.
 ''It's not that the extra spending of the rich hasn't caused problems for the middle class -- it has, particularly in the housing market,'' Professor Frank says. 
 But to be angry about that, Professor Frank says, is too complicated. ''People in the U.S. don't look at what the people at the top have and say, 'That's making life more difficult for me.' They watch and say, 'That'll be me someday. So, I'd better vote to abolish the estate tax, because you never know what the future may bring.' ''
 In other words, there are many Americans who see themselves -- accurately or not -- in Marie Antoinette (just as there are people who spend their Sundays at open houses for $10 million dollar co-ops on Fifth Avenue, even though they're raising a family in a cramped two-bedroom where the oven doubles as a china closet).
 On another level -- one of personal experience, rather than socioeconomic station -- we're an entire nation of Marie Antoinettes. 
 ''I meet these people all the time: binge consumers, intentionally oblivious young people who see amassing a great shoe collection as their purpose in life,'' says Richard Florida, the author of the books ''The Rise of the Creative Class'' and ''The Flight of the Creative Class.''
 ''As our whole society is fundamentally challenged -- war, terrorism, globalism -- there is a large segment whose measured response has been self-expression through shopping and partying,'' he says. ''They're constructing their own fantasy world, a bubble to seal themselves off from the trauma of our times.''
 Even in France, the revisionism has taken hold. It was only last May that Antonia Fraser's 2001 biography, ''Mary Antoinette: The Journey'' (on which Ms. Coppola's film is based), was finally translated into French and published by a French house.
 ''And when it finally happened, they refused to put the subtitle,'' Ms. Fraser says. ''I was interested in the journey, her development. The French seemed not to want to acknowledge that.''
 On the other hand, and despite the fact that the movie was booed when it made its debut at Cannes, the American novelist Diane Johnson says over the phone from Paris, where she is currently residing, that the French also have their ''Marie Antoinette mania.'' 
 She cites ''My Name Was Marie Antoinette,'' a play in Paris, at the end of which audience members were asked to vote on the Queen's ultimate fate. ''The audience generally votes to let her live,'' she says. Today, she says, ''in the stores, you see a lot fashion that's been very much influenced by her new popularity.'' 
 This has taken the form of taffeta gowns by Alexander McQueen, new shoes by Manolo Blahnik and dresses by John Galliano for Dior Couture. 
 ''I guess you could call that tie-in merchandise,'' Ms. Johnson says. ''If it were a Disney film, of course, they'd have made plastic figures.''

HEADLINE: On the Block

BYLINE: By JENNIFER BLEYER

 BODY:
NOT since the Dodgers departed in 1957 has there been a slugfest in Brooklyn like the one over Atlantic Yards. 
 The plan is colossal -- 16 high-rise buildings and an 18,000-seat basketball arena on 22 acres near the borough's busy downtown -- and fans and opponents have matched its magnitude with their own statistics. The developer, Forest City Ratner, which is also the development partner of The New York Times Company for its new headquarters in Midtown, says that the $4.2 billion project will bring 4,000 permanent jobs, billions of dollars in tax revenue and more than 6,000 units of housing. Opponents counter that the plan will corral $2 billion in public money and tax breaks, crowd 15,000 new residents into the area and clog local streets with thousands more cars.
Ever since the idea was floated in 2003, the sides have also framed their appeals broadly, citing big-picture concerns about urban policy and socioeconomic justice. 
 Less noticed amid the large numbers and loud clamor is the sound of the street: the skepticism and dread, or hope and excitement, of people who live and work near Atlantic Yards. 
 But that sound is there, on the neighborhood's sidewalks and stoops, in its stores and coffee shops, in its kitchens and parlors. There is the Nets fan dreaming of walking to home games. The mother worried about steering her stroller across an even busier Flatbush Avenue. The teacher hoping that one apartment in the tall towers has her name on it. And the gardener fretting over the shade thrown by those same towers. JENNIFER BLEYER

THE GARDENER

Jon Crow
Coordinator, Brooklyn Bear's Community Garden
 Back in 1982, the East Pacific Street Block Association worked to create the garden. There was a lot of prostitution, drug dealing, vagrancy in the area. Broken glass, used condoms, crack vials. People got together and little by little tried doing something nice.
 Because we were surrounded by nothing, there was really nothing we couldn't grow. We were basking in sunshine. The original garden was lots of vegetables, trees, shrubs and flowers. And because we were such a diverse population of gardeners, there were plants that were more typical of Cuba or Japan or Greece. Now we have about 21 little vegetable boxes and planting areas. We have a goldfish pond and a waterfall.
 Our fear is a few things. One is shade. The project would take away our sunshine until about noon every day. So from enjoying 12 or more hours of full sun, we're going to be down to 6 or 8. And in Los Angeles, one of Frank Gehry's buildings raised the ground temperature of the surrounding area to over 125 degrees because of the material and the glare. 
 We don't know what kind of environment we'll be in that people would want to garden. Would you want to do a vegetable garden next to Madison Square Garden?

THE APARTMENT SEEKER

Mildred Coleman
Teacher, Crown Heights
 My family is originally from South Carolina, but we migrated to New York in the 50's. We landed in Brooklyn, and this is where we stayed. I grew up in Williamsburg, and then I moved to Crown Heights. I teach third grade between 8 a.m. and 3 p.m., and I'm a day-care worker from 3 to 6.
 When they came up with this Atlantic thing, I said, this is great. This is a place where I could live in peace. Crown Heights is fine, but it's not comfortable like what I need. I've heard they're supposed to build this complex that gives you a laundry room, places to exercise, places to shop. 
 I'm hoping I'm a candidate. After being a teacher for 22 years, that's what I need. I need comfort. I don't have it where I'm living. 
 I remember years ago when I was a little girl, Downtown Brooklyn had Loehmann's and all those nice places, and you had to dress up to go to Junior's. 
 If that's what Atlantic Yards is going to do, if it's going to bring back a certain culture and standard we had years ago, I think that's great.

THE RETIREE

Mildred Davis
Resident, Fort Greene
 In 1942, I was 18, going on 19. My husband came from Washington to go to school for photography. In Washington, we lived in neighborhoods of two-story private homes. I didn't like Manhattan. I was disoriented with all the skyscrapers and the tall buildings. So we moved to Brooklyn. I felt it was a better place for my kids, and a warmer community than I had found in Manhattan.
 Sixty years ago there was a bill passed by two politicians, Mitchell and Lama, so working people could afford good housing. What's happening now is developers are going to take over, and people like me on a fixed income will be pushed out. The Mitchell-Lama building I'm living in will soon be developed into something higher priced. 
 I would like to stay in the community, but unfortunately I'm not eligible for senior citizen housing. That means I pay fair market. 
 This is a neighborhood I loved. I just don't know what the future holds for me and people like me, who can't afford the high prices of the high-rises.

THE BASKETBALL FAN

Kelly Burwell
Resident, Crown Heights
 I was born in Brooklyn Jewish Hospital in Prospect Heights 36 years ago, and they brought me straight to Lincoln Place in Crown Heights. I've been there ever since. I have my own business doing garbage removal and demolition.
 I'm looking forward to Brooklyn having a professional basketball team. The Knicks broke my heart so many times. I left them when Patrick Ewing was still playing and went over the water to New Jersey. I go as often as I can. Every time I get free time from work and the Nets have a home game, I go to the Continental Arena. I have five nephews, and they're all Nets fans. When I get Nets tickets, I take my nephews and we chant, ''Brooklyn Nets! Brooklyn Nets!'' 
 It'll be great the year they first play as the Brooklyn Nets. I believe they're going to win the championship because of all the hype. We could walk right to the Atlantic Yards from our house and watch a basketball game. That's a beautiful thing. The fans, we're going to be ready for them.

THE INVESTOR

Christopher Morris
Real estate developer
 I want to be ahead of the game, so I want to be where all the action is. I have five properties in Brooklyn close to the stadium, which I bought for a total of $15 million. I bought two properties that are three blocks from the Atlantic Yards for about $4 million. One I'm turning into condominiums, 24 condos. I wouldn't have bought that property if it weren't for the Atlantic Yards. Mr. Ratner has brought a whole change to this neighborhood. 
 Is it good? Yeah, it's good for businesses. The smallest guy on the block selling something is going to sell more. All real estate investors are going to sell more. Everybody's property is going to go up in the next 10 years. Property in the range of a million will become $2 million, maybe $4 million. 

THE MOTHER

Sarah Caylor
Resident, Fort Greene
 We used to live on the Upper West Side in a big complex where we didn't know anyone. The first time we came to Fort Greene, we totally fell in love with the neighborhood. Here, we know everyone who lives in our building. We run into people when we walk down the street. 
 Parents with young children seem to come out of the woodwork here. My child is Felix. He's 8 1/2 months old. We go to Fort Greene Park pretty much every day, and I take him on the swings or hang out on a blanket. I've seen renderings where the skyscrapers would cast shadows over a third of the park, covering the entire playground, for half of the day. I can't imagine that the grass would be as green or it would be as nice a place to hang out. 
 Sometimes we cross Atlantic at South Portland and walk a few blocks to Fifth Avenue to run errands. There are a lot of cute little kids' shops there. When I'm crossing now, it's O.K., but I can imagine it being a lot worse -- like some intersections I try to avoid like the plague. If there's more traffic in the area, it's just more dangerous. It's not the type of situation I imagined raising a child in.

THE HOMEMAKER

Audrey Doyle
Resident, Fort Greene
 We've lived here for 21 years, about five blocks from the rail yards. I'm a homemaker, and my husband works in computers. When we first moved in, a lot of the area was run-down, and crime was very high. Over the years, things have changed a lot. 
 I feel mostly positive about the changes. Fort Greene still has a varied population. People in public housing and people who own $2 million brownstones live side by side. I absolutely like that mix. I have friends and acquaintances in the neighborhood who are white from the Midwest, and some who immigrated from Argentina or India, and quite a few Caribbean neighbors. 
 There's a Chinese family on the street and a few doors down there's a Japanese family. There are a lot of working-class people who have owned the houses they live in for a long time, mostly African-American. And there's a lot of street life, people walking around or sitting on stoops or kids playing outside.
 If there's a huge development plunked down in the middle of our neighborhood, the tone of the whole area will gradually change. People who can afford very high housing prices have to be well off, and I would suspect that most of those new people would be white. I'm fearful of the neighborhood changing so much that we wouldn't want to live here.

THE MERCHANT

Ludlow Beckett
Owner of Yu Interiors, Fort Greene
 I've been open since December 1999. I sell home accessories with a lean toward 50's and 60's vintage modern. Our customers are mostly from the neighborhood, but we get a lot from Park Slope, Carroll Gardens, all the brownstone neighborhoods. A lot of them come by car. My concern is, if they can't park, will they stay? 
 It's not just that I work here, but I live here also, and I have to drive around sometimes two or three times just to find parking. We've seen a few larger buildings go up in the area, and parking has become an issue. It can only get worse.

THE BUSINESS HOPEFUL

Brian Saunders
Resident, Crown Heights
 I live and grew up in Crown Heights. My father came to the United States from the Caribbean in the early 70's. He started off having a lounge, and I think it's in my blood. Basically, I've managed bars and restaurants in Carroll Gardens and the Village. 
 What I've been hearing is they'll help individuals who want to open small businesses in the footprint of the project, whether by reducing the rent or helping you with a business plan. I heard they want it to be like mom-and-pop places.
 I'd like to have a little lounge in the community, something nice and upscale with a ''Cheers'' atmosphere. I want a place where people from those condos can come down and relax. Not a big club blaring music. Something for 50 or 75 people at most.
 That's my goal. Financing and capital play a big role in opening up something, and I don't have the capital to jump-start it. If I can get in with help in terms of rent and the development of my dream, I'm with it.

HEADLINE: For a Wobbly Walk, A Dressing Down

BYLINE: By JENNIFER BLEYER

 BODY:
ON Tuesday morning, Albert DeSimone once again had to fix the bricks. 
 In front of a building where he works as a maintenance man on a bustling shopping strip on White Plains Road south of Pelham Parkway, he supervised two other workers who pulled loose red bricks from the sidewalk. They cleaned the bricks, swabbed them with quick-setting concrete and inserted them back into their places. 
''We have to do this so nobody trips,'' Mr. DeSimone, a bearish man who wore black suspenders over a plaid shirt, said with a shrug as he explained that fixing the bricks was a regular part of his job.
 But brick sidewalk repair will not be among his responsibilities for long. This month, contractors began removing the bricks that adorn this part of White Plains Road, a four-block stretch of jewelry shops, florists, pharmacies and banks bisected overhead by the elevated tracks of the No. 2 subway. 
 The bricks are being replaced with concrete at a cost of $160,000, in a project overseen by the city's Economic Development Corporation. 
 The bricks were installed in the early 1980's by a local development corporation, since disbanded, that wanted to beautify a retail strip that had cooled slightly after a period of midcentury glamour. 
 ''There was a time after World War II when this area was chic,'' said Larry Prospect, director of the White Plains Road Business Improvement District. ''We had the most expensive stores. People came from all over the city to shop here.''
 The bricks were attractive but problematic. Weather and wear caused them to loosen and crumble. Pedestrians often tripped on them, sending the fear of lawsuits rippling among landlords. 
 ''They added an upscale ambience, but people were always stumbling on them,'' Mr. Prospect said. ''If the bricks came loose, we'd repair them. But it's not our responsibility.''
 For merchants on White Plains Road, of whom a handful of the oldest remain, bidding farewell to the brick sidewalks was easy. 
 ''I once had to pay for new eyeglasses for someone who fell on the bricks,'' said Sandi Simon, the owner of Frishman's, a women's clothing store opened in 1932 by her father, Sol Frischman, who died last week at age 105. 
 Thankfully, Ms. Simon added, ''we know the people at the optical store across the street.'' JENNIFER BLEYER

HEADLINE: On Fordham Road, Signs of the Times

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Re ''Uneasy Street'' (Oct. 15):
 Bill the Greek certainly has his finger on the pulse of the local economics around Fordham Road, especially when he mentioned ''Then rents went up'' in the 1990's. 
The cost of housing is draining more and more from the quality of life of low- and moderate-income working people. It continues to worsen as rent regulations are loosened and ignored. 
 Bill Kourdis and other merchants will see better times when the gap between what people earn and the cost of renting an apartment is narrowed.

John M. Reilly
Exec. Dir., Fordham Bedford Housing Corporation
Fordham, the Bronx

To the Editor:
 I really enjoyed reading your report on Fordham Road. The department store Super Mundo is indeed one of the best bargain places in the region. But it is not ''just'' an abandoned synagogue. 
 It used to be the Jacob Schiff Jewish Center, a kind of Jewish community center that opened in 1917. The center was named after the German-born banker and philanthropist Jacob Henry Schiff (1847-1920), who was, among other things, one of the founding fathers of the Jewish Theological Seminary and the Hebrew Union College. 
 Schiff was a kind of Edgar Bronfman of his time, and the Jacob Schiff Center one of the most prominent Jewish buildings along the Grand Concourse -- a place that also contained a Hebrew school and numerous other Jewish facilities. 
 The area around Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse is therefore not only worth exploring for a bargain hunt, but also a treasure hunt, searching for Jewish traces. 

Julian Voloj
Sunnyside, Queens

The writer is founder of JWalks, a Jewish heritage walking-tour group.

HEADLINE: Mastic Weighs Pros and Cons of Traffic Circles

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

DATELINE: MASTIC 

 BODY:
ROUNDABOUTS, common in Europe and increasingly popular among transportation planners in parts of the metropolitan region, are running into trouble in Mastic.
 A Suffolk County road improvement and downtown renewal plan that is under consideration calls for building three of the traffic-calming circles along a one-mile stretch of Montauk Highway in downtown Mastic. 
 That section of the road, a notorious bottleneck, has one lane in each direction, a center turning lane and a roadside lined by small businesses, fast-food franchises and strip malls.
 Roundabout proponents, including the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, Vision Long Island and some local residents, say the circles will slow but not impede traffic, make road crossings safer for pedestrians and be a first step toward a more inviting downtown. 
 ''Roundabouts create more of a community rather than cars speeding through town,'' said Kate Slevin, the associate director of Tri-State, a nonprofit transportation planning group based in New York. 
 Volunteer fire departments and ambulance companies in Mastic and neighboring areas take a different view. They say the roundabouts are a bad idea because they would delay emergency vehicles. 
 ''To make fire trucks and ambulances responding to emergencies go around circles is just asinine,'' said Fred Wesemann, a fire and ambulance volunteer and business owner in Mastic.
 Mr. Wesemann said emergency vehicles stuck in traffic would have to make up time by going over the curb onto the raised center median that would replace the center turn lane. He said they would have to go back onto the road to negotiate each of the roundabouts. ''Try that while you're putting an IV in a patient,'' he said. 
 Currently, emergency vehicles can use the center turning lane, which is at grade level. 
 Emergency volunteers support an alternative plan, also under consideration, that would synchronize traffic signals but include no roundabouts, and it would allow emergency vehicles traveling in the center turn lane to change lights to green as they approached them.
 Public hearings on the roundabouts have been held, and now the county's Department of Public Works will decide which plan to recommend to the Suffolk Legislature. But it will probably be weeks before a decision is made, officials said.
 ''Both plans are acceptable from a capacity and safety standpoint,'' said William Hillman, the chief engineer for public works, noting that the median curbs were designed so that vehicles could mount them. ''We wouldn't propose something that doesn't work.'' 
 County Executive Steve Levy set aside $16 million for the project in Suffolk's capital budget for 2007 through 2009. That amount includes $12 million in federal money.
 The entire project covers 1.7 miles from the Montauk Highway intersection with William Floyd Parkway eastward. It would add an extra lane in both directions from William Floyd a short distance to Garden Place.
 County Legislator Kate M. Browning, a Working Families Party member whose district includes Mastic, said the views of emergency volunteers should weigh heavily. 
 ''I grew up in Northern Ireland and I'm familiar with roundabouts,'' said Mrs. Browning, a native of Belfast. ''They are good, but what works there maybe doesn't work here.'' 
 The State Department of Transportation recommends that roundabouts be considered a primary tool for improving intersections. They have been built recently in Great Neck Plaza, Huntington and Westhampton Beach.

HEADLINE: A Storyteller With an Eye for History 

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN GENOCCHIO

 BODY:
As an artist, Jacob Lawrence (1917-2000) was interested primarily in storytelling. His most famous work is ''The Migration of the Negro'' (1940-41), a series of paintings depicting the Northern movement of African-Americans during and after World War I. Painted in a Social Realist-inspired style, with sharp-edged, flattened shapes and forms, it is a powerful allegory of the social and economic plight of African-Americans in the United States.
 Three series of Lawrence's prints fill adjoining galleries at the Heckscher Museum of Art. These are also about storytelling, though with one exception they tend to be more decorative than his earlier work and less inclined toward direct social comment. Lawrence mellowed a bit in his later years, mining personal interests and some old favorite themes as subjects. 
Born in Atlantic City in 1917, Lawrence grew up in Harlem, studying art in the 1930's at the Harlem Community Art Center and other schools. He began to make naive-looking figurative paintings relating to Harlem and the daily lives of its people, meeting with swift success. In 1941, Lawrence became the first African-American artist to be represented in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art, where he was honored with a solo exhibition in 1944. He was one of the first black Americans to win wide recognition in the art world.
 Lawrence's best works never varnish raw facts; instead, he presents us with human suffering in what seems like a supremely indifferent world, then invites us to empathize with the victims. So it is with ''Hiroshima,'' a provocative series of prints he made in 1983 based on the 1946 account by the writer John Hersey of the aftermath of the dropping of the atomic bomb.
 The prints depict everyday scenes -- women at the market, children in a playground -- though the figures are faceless. Look closer and you can see that they are writhing in agony, flesh dripping off their bones. You can feel mentally bruised looking at these prints.
 ''Toussaint L'Ouverture'' (1986-1999), the largest series here, is a reworking of some paintings from the late 1930's based on the life of Toussaint L'Ouverture, a hero of the Haitian slave uprising of the late 18th century, which led to the country's independence from France. In 1801, Toussaint also invaded Spanish-controlled Santo Domingo on the other side of the island and freed slaves there. Soon afterward Haiti became the first independent republic to be run by people of African descent. 
 All the prints are serigraph, or silkscreen, which seems the perfect medium for this subject matter. Used for T-shirts and posters, it emphasizes flat, bold, bright and graphic images. 
 The tone of ''Toussaint L'Ouverture'' is elegiac, the artist zeroing in on specific moments in the life of the revolutionary leader, from his early years as a slave, to his role in the overthrow of the French government in Haiti, to his death two years later. You don't need to know the story to follow the narrative, for the prints offer a realistic portrayal of these volatile events, arranged in more or less chronological order. 
 It is the little details that enchant, like the artist's attention to the clothing and jewelry worn by ordinary people animating the battle scenes, or the wonderful verdant foliage conjured with little more than a few blocky, angular lines. These prints have a muscular lyricism, most apparent perhaps in a half-length portrait of Toussaint dressed as a general. He comes across as a determined hulk of a man. 
 The final series, ''Genesis'' (1989-90), draws on the artist's experiences of religion; he was baptized in the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem and recalled hearing passionate sermons there about the Creation. Lawrence depicts those sermons in this series, showing an animated minister and his congregation. Perhaps it was there at church that Lawrence's love of storytelling began.

''Jacob Lawrence: Three Series of Prints,'' Heckscher Museum of Art, 2 Prime Avenue, Huntington, through Nov. 5. Information: (631) 351-3250 or www.heckscher.org.

Center, a visitor views ''The Capture'' (1987). (Photos by Bottom left and above center, photographs by Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Plug-In Hybrid Cars, For Long Island's Future

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 David Morris's excellent article about local initiative in fostering plug-in hybrid vehicles (''Turn On the Electric Road,'' Op-Ed, Oct. 8) makes good sense, but there are three aspects of it that must be borne in mind. 
 First, we should not allow the ''perfect to become the enemy of the good.'' The last thing we ought to do is wait around for the plug-ins to arrive. 
 The most important single step we can take to cope with the energy problems facing us is to improve the efficiency of our transportation sector. We can do this right now by replacing our cars, when their time has come, with already available fuel efficient or hybrid vehicles. They are just as comfortable as the gas burners and benefit the natural environment.
 Second, plug-in hybrids are sensible because of what they plug into. In most of the United States, regions get their electricity from hydroelectricity or power plants burning coal or nuclear. The power plants on Long Island, New York City and most of downstate New York burn either oil or gas. 
 Plug-ins still make some sense here because we get some of our power from other places, generated by hydroelectricity, coal and nuclear. But new power plants using indigenous fuels and renewables are being walled off from us by legislative actions, making it more difficult to build transmission lines to the places in the western part of the state where those plants could be built and would be welcomed.
 Finally, plug-ins would be a really good thing for the economics of electric supply. If people plugged in at night, it would help spread the costs of owning all the major facilities needed to supply electricity, tending to lower electric costs for all of us.

Ira L. Freilicher
East Hills

The writer is an energy lawyer.
