HEADLINE: Rachael Ray Gives the Gift Of Time

BYLINE: By DAVID CARR

 BODY:
At the unveiling of the new Hearst building in Manhattan some weeks ago, there was a magical moment when two sturdy media icons, Oprah Winfrey and Martha Stewart, ended up chatting with one another. Each occupies a singular place in American cultural consciousness: Ms. Winfrey, with her bootstrap message of personal empowerment, and Ms. Stewart, with her relentless pursuit of steely domestic perfection (she dismissed prison time as if it were a fallen souffle).
 But there was a runway between them big enough to land another behemoth: Rachael Ray, who's probably best known for giggling her way through 30-minutes recipes on the Food Network. 
Compared to Ms. Winfrey and Ms. Stewart, it is easy to dismiss Ms. Ray as a confection. But as a businesswomen, she is ditzy like a fox. While other start-up magazines wither, Everyday With Rachael Ray, published by Reader's Digest North American Publishing, is exploding, with a promised circulation of 1.7 million by next year. As an author, Ms. Ray has few peers, with 16 cookbooks that have total sales of nearly five million. 
 Her ''30 Minute Meals'' is the highest rated show on the Food Network and with the addition of her other shows about budget travel and dining, more than 11 million viewers watch her every week. Last month, she took her down-home ethic beyond the kitchen, coming up with a general interest five-day-a-week talk show, ''Rachael Ray,'' which had the highest rated debut of any show since ''Dr. Phil.'' Those are some big numbers for a woman that was doing in-store cooking demonstrations a little more than five years ago.
 Whatever is at work here, it isn't just the food. Ms. Ray's ad-hoc kitchen ways -- spices measured by the palm and mistakes covered up with more olive oil -- represent a sharp departure from the aspiration that drives most cooking shows and magazines. She prepares food on the fly that actual civilians can make and eat, an approach that people with serious culinary backgrounds generally find unbearable; they see it as a plague of locusts served over a bed of toads in runny sauce. 
 OPRAH taught us we can be better human beings. Martha taught us we can do better than is humanly possible. And Ms. Ray? She thinks better is overrated. Now, you want some nachos and a cold one to go with that?
 In an interview, Ms. Ray conceded some of the criticisms that trigger her harshest detractors' gag reflexes -- that she is a clumsy cook, smiles too much and has less than demure hands.
 ''It's all true and I can't do much about it at this point,'' she said by phone. ''I am doing programming that goes into people's homes and kitchens, about their kids and their pets, really personal stuff, and not everybody is going to like what I do.
 ''When I first heard from the Food Network, I told them that I was beer in a bottle and they are champagne, but it worked out,'' she said. ''I'm too loud one day and giggle too much next, or flub the intro, but what I do is not about technique. I need a story to go with the burger. People want to relax a little.''
 Standing in line to watch the taping of her daytime show near Grand Central Station last Wednesday, a trio of women who had driven in from Long Island talked about how ''natural'' and ''down to earth,'' Ms. Ray was. Ann Marchesiello suggested Ms. Ray's time-saving idea of placing a garbage bowl next to the cutting board may be, ''the greatest thing in the world.''
 Corey Champeau drove down from Connecticut to watch with her husband, Matt, a testament to how Ms. Ray, who once posed in lingerie licking a spoon for the men's magazine FHM, draws across genders. Ms. Champeau tunes in for the tips and recipes, while Mr. Champeau said, unlike most kitchen goddesses, ''she's the kind of girl you could actually ask out.'' (Actually you can't: she's married. And so are you.)
 Just then, chef and bon vivant Anthony Bourdain came ambling down the block, stopping by for some voice-over work for his show on the Travel Channel. Rather than toe the chef's line that Ms. Ray is a perky philistine who is not so much democratizing dining as dumbing it down, he said her appeal had nothing to do with cooking or food.
 ''This is about a very recognizable, comfortable person, someone we all think we know, the sort of dream mom or sister we never had,'' he said, calibrating his words. ''People are attracted to her warm, if strident, embrace of the familiar.''
 But Ms. Ray's folksy approach belies the sophistication of her message. She is part of the cut-to-the-chase genre of media, like Lucky, Domino and Real Simple magazines, and their success is built on this fact of modern life: if people are more secure economically, it is only because they are working longer and harder than ever before. Lifestyle porn is fine and all -- who wouldn't want to have that epic downtown loft in Architectural Digest or those lemon caper calamari steaks in Gourmet? -- but even if you can afford the ingredients, you can't afford the time to conjure them before dinner. 
 Ms. Ray's recipes may call for store-bought turkey loaf but she is really trafficking in the ultimate modern luxury: time. Other magazine cover lines promise to make you fit in 30 days or give you better orgasms in six steps. The latest Everyday With Rachael Ray promises ''Fall Style: lazy weekends, comfort food, easy entertainment.'' Inside, there are ''Messes and Successes,'' a shopping list that includes frozen fish sticks and a food shot that includes a can -- the horror! -- of beef broth, plain as day. The pitch for her show in the magazine pretty much sums the ethos up, suggesting viewers will ''realize that life just doesn't have to be that hard.'' 
 Of course, life is plenty hard, which is why a woman who tends to find succor in a slurp of store-bought pasta is hitting a sweet spot. That may not meet Ms. Stewart's definition of a good thing, but Rachael Ray's fans know that, after a long day, it's all good.

HEADLINE: Northwestern Town Is Awash In Sun and Those Drawn by It

BYLINE: By MATT VILLANO

DATELINE: SEQUIM, Wash. 

 BODY:
HERE in the foothills of the Olympic Mountains, near the northwesternmost corner of the 48 contiguous states, retirees have flocked to a place they affectionately call the Blue Hole.
 Some have come for the weather. A typical year in these parts has 299 days of sunshine, and fewer than 17 inches of rain fell last year, far less than the amount that soaked Seattle, which is just a short drive and ferry ride away.
Still other recent transplants to Sequim (pronounced skwim), which is on the Olympic peninsula, moved here for the quality of life -- access to outdoor activities that include fishing, biking, hiking, birding and golfing, not to mention the city's eclectic shopping and vibrant art community. 
 ''They don't call this place the Blue Hole for nothing,'' said Diane Johnston, 74, who moved from suburban Lynnwood in 2000, when she felt it had become too crowded. ''It's like one big playground -- we have it all.'' 
 Whatever the reasons, Sequim is on the rise, particularly among retirees. According to the most recent data from the Census Bureau, the city's population rose nearly 20 percent, to 4,323 in 2000 from 3,616 in 1990. Marny Hannan, the executive director of the local Chamber of Commerce, said that the total had since topped 5,000, and added that about 60 percent of the residents were 65 or older.
 This influx of retirees has resulted in a development boom. Open space has given way to tracts of new homes. The city and surrounding area have sprouted a Costco, Wal-Mart and Home Depot.
 Most people welcome this growth. Some, however, including Ray Millard, a 72-year-old who retired to Sequim in 1991, view it as a sign that their once-tiny town may be growing up too fast.
 ''Someone put out the word that this was a place to retire and now it's becoming a metropolis,'' Mr. Millard said. ''I only hope we don't get too big.''
 Sequim, which means ''quiet waters'' in the language of the local S'Klallam American Indian group, began in the 1880's as a farming town, its arid prairies irrigated by ditches that carried glacial runoff from the Olympic Mountains. Produce from the valley supplied food for the booming city of Victoria, British Columbia, across the Strait of Juan de Fuca. Over time, as Canadians planted their own farms, the need for imports declined.
 Sequim remained a farm community and stayed small for decades. Then, in the 1970's, an older population began trickling in. These arrivals reached a peak in the last few years, when retirees from states like California, New Mexico and Arizona were able to make good profits from selling their homes.
 Olaf Protze was one such transplant. After years of working as a church custodian in Danville, Calif., Mr. Protze retired in 2001 and moved north with his wife, Charlotte. The Protzes looked at a number of communities across the Northwest, but said they were drawn to Sequim's charm and location in particular.
 ''In choosing a home, we were looking for a small-town atmosphere within easy driving distance of a major city and close proximity of the ocean,'' Mr. Protze said.
 With the money from their California house, the couple bought so much land they were able to open the Red Caboose Getaway, a bed-and-breakfast where guests sleep and also eat in renovated railroad cars. For Mr. Protze, a die-hard train fan who calls himself the property's ''stationmaster,'' the endeavor is the realization of a lifelong dream.
 ''I always knew I wanted to do this, but I had to come to Sequim to make it a reality,'' he said during a visit in mid-September. ''I couldn't have imagined retirement being any better.''
 Remarkably, the housing market that lured the Protzes five years ago is still chugging along. The Sequim Association of Realtors, an independent association of local real estate professionals, says that the median home price in September was $280,000, down from $317,000 in September 2005, but up from $241,000 in 2004.
 Mike McAleer, the chairman of the group's government affairs committee, said that most of the people buying homes in Sequim were retirees. ''Seniors definitely are leading the pack,'' he said of the city's newest homeowners. ''A lot of them come with a fair amount of equity, so our prices don't disturb them at all.''
 Yet the picture in Sequim isn't entirely rosy. A controversy in 2004 over the arrival of Wal-Mart polarized the community, leaving retirees like Mr. Millard frustrated with a perceived lack of planning by the municipal government. Similar disputes are brewing over proposed housing developments scheduled to break ground early next year.
 Linda Rotmark, the executive director of the Clallam County Economic Development Council in nearby Port Angeles, has expressed concern over other issues related to growth. Specifically, she is worried that the area's shrinking hospital system will not be able to support the increasing number of elderly patients.
 ''What happens if a bunch of our residents become ill at once?'' she asked. ''Will we be ready to process their Medicare transactions and give them the care they need?''
 Help may be on the way. The Olympic Area Agency on Aging, a local group dedicated to addressing some of these problems, recently received a $750,000 grant from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J., to overhaul elder-care service on the peninsula.
 Ms. Rotmark said the agency would use the grant to rethink every aspect of the current medical climate, including house calls, hospice care and administration.
 Others are taking a more grass-roots approach to the issue of quality of life here. At the Sequim Senior Center, for instance, which sits just up the street from Mr. Protze's depot, retirees have organized a volunteer program that offers their contemporaries tax assistance and transportation to and from the doctor.
 Michael Smith, the center's executive director, said the program was a good example of the enthusiastic and supportive small-town attitudes that make Sequim a great place to retire.
 ''We're growing, but we're very much still a community,'' said Mr. Smith, who is 44. ''No matter what kind of growth happens here in the next couple of years, I don't think that's going to change at all.''

HEADLINE: There but for Health Coverage Go I Out the Door

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON

 BODY:
MANY save for years, dreaming of early retirement. But there is often a catch: though the potential retirees may no longer need the salary, they cannot forgo the health insurance.
 These people are too young for Medicare, the federal program that typically provides coverage for those 65 and older. And as more employers eliminate retiree health benefits, early retirees are unlikely to have any sort of company-sponsored plan once they stop working. The result, say health policy experts and financial planners, is that many people who want to retire early may not be able to find health insurance they can afford -- if they can find it at all.
 When Gene Matthews retired three years before he could qualify for Medicare, he assumed he would have no trouble buying an individual insurance policy. ''I was really silly in my thinking,'' said Mr. Matthews, who lives in Park City, Utah. He discovered he could not get private insurance because he had high blood pressure, even though he was active, playing golf and skiing, and taking the proper medication. 
 He took advantage of a federal law that allowed him to continue the coverage he had with his former employer for 18 months. After returning to work for the same employer for a short period, he was then able to retire again and extend that coverage for another 18 months. In August, he turned 65 and happily enrolled in Medicare; he pays just $150 or so for his benefits, which include prescription drug coverage. 
 His wife, Ann, who has worked part time at a local ski resort, is not so lucky -- she still faces one year in which she will not have coverage and will still be too young for Medicare. Mr. Matthews said that his wife may simply work full time for the health benefits she needs.
 ''The risk of not having health insurance is catastrophic,'' Mr. Matthews said.
 But Mr. Matthews's experience is hardly unique, said Bil Jeppson, a financial planner with Financial Strategies Institute in Midvale, Utah, where Mr. Matthews is a client. He estimates that about a third of the group's clients face the same challenge: they have the financial means to retire but difficulty in finding health insurance. Some pay as much as $1,200 a month for a plan offered by the state for people who are unable to get coverage elsewhere. 
 ''We're seeing this problem more and more,'' said Mark Rylance, a financial planner with RS Crum in Newport Beach, Calif. 
 Despite longstanding recognition of the lack of options for early retirees, there is little activity on the federal or state level to address the issue. The idea of allowing early retirees to buy Medicare coverage, for example, has been ''a perennial'' in policy discussions in Congress, but ''it doesn't go anywhere,'' said David A. Osterndorf, a senior health consultant for Towers Perrin, which specializes in employee benefits and compensation.
 Congress is reluctant to come up with a national solution because most people who retire early are able to find insurance, said Paul Fronstin, a researcher at the Employee Benefit Research Institute. Recent counts put the number of uninsured retirees between the ages of 55 and 64 around 800,000. 
 ''Congress doesn't perceive this as a problem because the numbers aren't so big,'' he said.
 And some policymakers are unwilling to consider expanding Medicare because it could represent a step toward government-run health insurance, said Richard W. Johnson, a health economist at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit policy research group. ''You get that much closer to universal coverage,'' he said. 
 On the state level, legislative efforts have focused on addressing the insurance needs of active workers. Early retirees ''tend to be a lost group and missed in this conversation,'' Mr. Osterndorf said.
 Options and their availability depend on circumstances. If just a year or so short of 65 -- and Medicare eligibility -- the retiree can probably use company-sponsored coverage for at least 18 months under provisions of the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act, known as Cobra. 
 While choosing to continue the coverage may not be cheap, it allows employees to pay the group rates available to their former employers rather than their trying to forage for an individual policy, experts say. Mr. Matthews, for example, paid roughly $600 a month for his coverage.
 Another option may be to buy coverage from a former employer even if that employer does not subsidize the cost of the plan. Intel, for example, is one of many large companies that allow its retirees to buy health insurance from the company, even when they have a pre-existing condition that would disqualify them in the individual market. Some 30 to 40 percent of the company's retirees have enrolled in the program, said Steve Lensing, a benefits program manager for Intel.
 The company also contributes to an account, based on an employee's years of service, that retirees can use when they leave Intel to lower the premiums they would otherwise pay. The cost of coverage varies, Mr. Lensing said, but tends to be around $9,000 a year for early retirees.
 Many early retirees are able to avail themselves of some insurance, relying on company-sponsored plans or policies available through a spouse's employer. But a sizable number of retirees are left to their own devices, according to Mr. Johnson. Buying an individual policy can be easier in a few states, like New York, where insurers are required to offer community-rated coverage, grouping individuals into a ''community'' and charging the same rate for the entire group. ''It means the premiums in these states tend to be higher, but you cannot be turned down,'' said Nancy E. Frank, a financial planner in Manhattan who heads Frank Advisory Services. Depending on the plan, a resident of New York City may pay as little as $500 a month for coverage -- or roughly twice that amount.
 Other states that rely on community-based pricing include Vermont and New Jersey, but most states allow insurers to set the rates for individual coverage, which can make policies for people at high risk for medical treatment either unaffordable or unavailable.
 Individuals may have other options, depending on where they live. Because Mr. Matthews's former employer was based in California and used a California insurer, his wife has the option of converting the coverage she had through Cobra to an individual policy. Mr. Matthews also said that AARP, the group that represents the nation's retirees, offers health insurance in some states for people older than 50. Mr. Matthew's home state, Utah, so far is not among them. 
 But even when the premiums are affordable, many people are disappointed in the benefits that are offered, said Thom K. Hall, a planner with Financial Strategies Institute. The coverage does not match that of their former employer, and they may have to switch doctors or pay more for care.
 For people who simply cannot get private insurance, many states offer programs that are intended to cover high-risk individuals. But those plans can be costly -- priced at well over $1,000 a month -- and may not offer much in benefits. ''It's a huge problem,'' said Mr. Matthews, who said that many of his friends have found that they could not buy individual policies. 
 The result is that many early retirees may have to consider finding work that offers them coverage. Some people can work out an arrangement with a former employer who will give them work as a consultant. 
 Others might want to consider finding work with employers who offer coverage to part-time workers, like Starbucks Coffee, which gives benefits to those who work 20 hours or more a week. Financial planners and health policy experts agree that the options available to those under 65 who want to retire are few, with people paying much more of their retirement savings to health care than they had expected. ''I don't know any silver lining we're missing,'' said Mr. Rylance, the California planner, who said that many of his clients had simply not thought about health care when they started to discuss retiring early. ''When it's brought up, it does scare people,'' he said.
 And, of course, some people decide not to retire after all. ''A lot of people keep their jobs simply for the benefits,'' said Ms. Frank, the New York planner. While they may flirt with the idea of retiring, they may stop thinking about it once they realize just how much it costs.
 ''People who have worked in a corporation all their life have no idea what health insurance costs,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Planning: It's More Than Filling in the Blanks 

BYLINE: By ERIC A. TAUB

 BODY:
ANY number of Web sites offer simple online calculators for retirement. Fill out a few easy questions about your assets, income and expenditures, and you will know how much money you will need.
 And that is what you should not waste your time doing, said Laurence J. Kotlikoff, a professor of economics at Boston University. ''Getting retirement planning right is rocket science,'' he said.
Knowing how much money you will need involves a wide range of variables that can drastically change your financial position. They include matters like the property tax in your state, when you decide to withdraw from your 401(k) and whether you receive Social Security benefits before or after you take money from other private retirement funds. 
 Still, companies continue to offer simple questionnaires. Fidelity does so because ''we are trying to break the inertia,'' said Carolyn Clancy, Fidelity's senior vice president for personal investments. The company, she said, hopes that an individual will explore the much more extensive questionnaire on its Web site and ask the company's financial planners for further assistance. 
 The more popular tools, like those from Fidelity, Quicken and Vanguard, have a number of similarities. They all populate the fields with information culled from in-house accounts or previously entered information. They also have ''what-if'' possibilities: changes in income, rates of return and inflation and age of retirement, among others.
 The tools offered by a financial institution might also have a built-in conflict of interest; while the software is available to anyone, it is intended to encourage users to set up retirement accounts with the institution. That makes them not very useful, said Darius Gagne, a financial adviser at Quantum Wealth Management Investments in Los Angeles. Using retirement planning software, Mr. Gagne said, is ''like building your own home without an architect.''
 The brokerage houses do not deny that they would like users of their retirement planning software to delve deeper into their companies' offerings, but they say that it is an advantage for the customer.
 Vanguard will prepare a one-time customized financial plan, based on answers to the online questionnaire, at no charge to customers who have $250,000 in Vanguard assets or who bring $100,000 into the company. Fidelity offers its Income Management Account, which sends e-mail notifications if you are withdrawing retirement funds at too rapid a rate or if your portfolio investment classes should be reweighted.
 Both Fidelity and Vanguard believe that an individual should have enough assets for retirement to generate 85 percent of one's income during the working years. According to Ms. Clancy at Fidelity, most people have enough assets to cover only 57 percent of their needs.
 Professor Kotlikoff said that that required figure was drastically inflated. ''The typical rule of thumb for retirement income is too high for the middle class,'' he said. ''People cannot meet that target without investing in risky securities.'' Encouraging risks, he added, is ''a form of financial malpractice.''
 To put his theories into practice, Professor Kotlikoff developed ESPlanner. He faults typical retirement calculators for overly simplifying the process. The amount you need to save and what you can spend ''is very sensitive to minor fluctuations,'' he said.
 Here is a look at four popular programs:

ESPLANNER -- Rather than ask users how much money they want to have in retirement, the program ($149-$199 at esplanner.com) finds the appropriate spending target for each user. ESPlanner can determine the financial consequences of a number of actions, including moving to a state with lower taxes (the program includes tax data for every state) or taking Social Security before a 401(k). It can determine whether someone is saving too much, resulting in higher-than-necessary taxes.

FIDELITY -- The company's free Retirement Income Planner software uses a wide range of financial data to help people determine how much they can spend before the money runs out. Account assets of Fidelity customers are automatically loaded into the program. Sidebar tips help users understand the implications of variables. Users can vary such items as life expectancy, and whether they wish to die with or without assets. Fidelity will suggest various mutual funds, including those marketed by other companies and offered through Fidelity's Funds Network program.

QUICKEN -- Available as a feature within the Windows-based Quicken 2007 Deluxe product ($59.95), the software can download financial information from 4,300 institutions directly into the retirement calculator. Anticipated inflation rates, age when taking Social Security and tax rates can be changed by the user. Users are advised if they are on their way to having enough assets or if they should save more. The program warns them if their appreciation rate seems higher than normal, or if they forget to enter the value of an obvious asset, like a home.

VANGUARD -- The company helps investors determine how much to save for retirement, explains the types of I.R.A.'s and why it pays to start saving early, how investment costs affect savings and when to cash out of an employer's retirement fund. The tools, which can be used at no charge, do not advise people when to start taking Social Security, but they do show the effects of starting it at different ages. Nor are investors advised to switch out of funds if they are not performing well; the company says it does not believe in trying to time the market.

HEADLINE: Two Doors Open on Inge's Lively but Curdled World

BYLINE: By CHARLES ISHERWOOD

DATELINE: CHICAGO 

 BODY:
Loneliness -- the kind that gnaws quietly at the soul, fills empty rooms with an oppressive presence and turns a pleasant Sunday afternoon into an invitation to despair -- is at the very heart of the work of William Inge, the now little-celebrated American playwright whose popularity in the 1950's rivaled that of Arthur Miller and Tennessee Williams.
 The ordinary folks in Inge's dramas -- housewives and waitresses, salesmen and saloon singers -- do not have access to language that would give lyrical voice to their yearning for love and companionship, as in the work of Williams, but the feeling is true nonetheless, expressed in shamed silences, embarrassed smiles, the clumsy exchange of banalities and, occasionally and alarmingly, confused cries of anguish and desperation.
Inge, who suffered from depression, committed suicide in 1973, his career in steep decline, and you could say that loneliness dogs him yet. The four major plays from the 50's on which his faded fame tentatively rests haven't been subject to the kind of exciting rediscovery that regularly burnishes or re-establishes the reputations of Miller and Williams. Broadway revivals of ''Bus Stop'' and ''Picnic'' in the 1990's -- the first since the original productions -- were greeted tepidly. 
 With their larger casts of characters and livelier humor, those two are actually the most enduringly popular of the big four. Neither ''Come Back, Little Sheba,'' the 1950 play that marked Inge's breakthrough, nor ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs,'' his most autobiographical play and last real stage success, from 1957, has made it back to Broadway at all. 
 So it is surprising, and intriguing, to find warmly received productions of these two plays running simultaneously at small theaters here. This is not exactly an Inge festival -- the concurrent stagings are just a coincidence -- but the acclaim for David Cromer's production of ''Sheba'' for the Shattered Globe Theater, which opened first, has undoubtedly helped fuel interest in the American Theater Company's staging of ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs,'' directed by Damon Kiely, which recently extended its run through Nov. 12.
 ''Sheba,'' which ended its run on Saturday, is the better-known play, primarily because of the movie version that earned Shirley Booth an Oscar to match her Tony for creating the role of the lonesome Lola onstage. (''Dark'' was also filmed.) It is also the better play. With its poignant story of the troubled relationship between a slatternly, chattering housewife and her alcoholic husband, it has an emotional clarity that the more diffuse ''Dark at the Top of the Stairs'' does not.
 Mr. Cromer's precisely detailed production trains a clear gaze on the two souls trapped in a marriage that has slowly curdled, as the shared happiness of Doc and Lola's youth, baldly symbolized by the little puppy that ain't comin' back any time soon, has given way to solitary helpings of disappointment. In the tight confines of the Victory Gardens Greenhouse Theater, the audience is almost sharing morning coffee with the bustling Lola (Linda Reiter), the gentle Doc (John Judd) and their boarder, Marie (Maggie Corbett), whose nubile beauty and healthy sexuality unsettle both of them in different ways.
 Scuttling quickly around her kitchen and living room (designed in acutely drab detail by Kevin Hagan), Ms. Reiter's Lola is refreshingly softer-hued than Booth's memorably bleating Lola. Inge did not exactly understate Lola's loneliness -- must she shanghai both the postman and the milkman with assaults of small talk? -- but Ms. Reiter, who bears a resemblance to Judi Dench, shares some of that great actress's natural warmth, too. She dignifies the character with the graceful depth of feeling she brings to the role, in particular in the telling silences that punctuate the stream of chipper talk. The vision of Lola at the front door, slowly turning back to face her empty living room as if it were the gallows, reveals the anguish of her daily solitude in a manner that goes beyond her homely language. 
 If the skills of a fine actress are required to save Lola from either bathos or sheer silliness, the role of Doc poses its challenges, too. Mr. Judd, who appeared as Laurence Olivier in ''Orson's Shadow'' Off Broadway (a role he created for Mr. Cromer's production at the Steppenwolf Theater Company in Chicago), performs with a contained economy that suggests the inward energies Doc must devote to waging a moment-by-moment battle against the furies in his soul. These are unleashed in the play's climactic scene, in which a fallen-off-the-wagon Doc subjects his cowering wife to a torrent of cruel abuse. Mr. Judd performs it with a harshness that is harrowing to watch; squirming in your seat, you almost forget the scene's essential staginess. 
 But you don't, quite. ''Sheba'' was Inge's first successful play, and he would show a more graceful touch in ''Bus Stop'' and ''Picnic,'' in which the pathos that paved his work like linoleum -- and the clotted sexuality sometimes spilled across it -- was spread around to a wider variety of characters. Concentrated heavily in the characterizations of Doc and particularly Lola, it retains a slightly mawkish flavor, even in Mr. Cromer's emotionally trenchant production.
 ''Sheba'' was Inge's first success, but not his first play. That was ''Farther Off From Heaven,'' written in 1947 under the inspiration of ''The Glass Menagerie,'' which Inge had seen with Williams himself, who had befriended him and encouraged him to try his hand at drama. (Inge was working as a critic in St. Louis at the time.) Ten years later, Inge reworked the play as ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs,'' but blurred traces of Williams's influence are still evident. 
 The central character, a frazzled Midwestern mother and wife named Cora Flood (Cheryl Graeff), is like Amanda Wingfield stripped of the Southern graces that disguise the hint of cruelty in her desire to force her offspring into joining the rough flow of life. Like Amanda, Cora has a pathologically shy daughter, Reenie (Kelly O'Sullivan), whom she cattle-prods into sociability; a sensitive son, Sonny (Edward Heffernan); and an essentially absent husband, Rubin (Tim Decker), a salesman on the road a lot. Mr. Kiely's cast largely does well by the sometimes obvious material, although Ms. Graeff's crabbed Cora could use more warmth. 
 The play was bold for its time, with its sober and complex depiction of marital dissatisfaction and the fraying fabric of American family life. But today the strained subplot involving the suicide of a minor character -- a Jewish boy nicely played by Jurgen Hooper, who takes Reenie to a local party -- registers as a fatally histrionic touch that breaks the spell of small-town frustration. (This doomed and exotic fellow even has a movie star for a mother, who doesn't come to the funeral.)
 Inge did not have a gift for the bold stroke, as Williams and Miller did in vastly different ways, Williams with his heady lyricism and outsized but still richly human characters, Miller with his taste for stark moral inquiry. (Inge's shrill screenplay for ''Splendor in the Grass'' has dated none too well.) The strident bids for a richer-hued theatricalism -- Doc's drunk scene, the spinster schoolteacher's hysteria in ''Picnic,'' the suicide in ''The Dark at the Top of the Stairs'' -- sort of stick out like palm trees on a Kansas prairie.
 Inge came from Kansas, and his writing is most moving when it sticks to the prosaic rhythms of his characters' lives and the homespun flavor of their talk. There's nothing to do about those palm trees now, of course, but when fine actors instill his everyday folk with the warm blood of real humanity, as they do in particular in the Shattered Globe's ''Sheba,'' you can at least squint a little and pretend you don't see them.

HEADLINE: Extended Stay, Extended Pampering 

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER ELLIOTT

 BODY:
The Fairmont Washington knows Andrew Breslow's room preference, his fondness for foam pillows and his favorite cocktail: Jack Daniels with club soda. But that is not why Mr. Breslow, a tax lawyer from Southlake, Tex., likes to check into the hotel on his extended business trips to Washington. 
 ''They make sure I look good,'' he said. ''If I'm not dressed right -- if maybe my socks don't match or my shirt collar is turned up -- they'll say something to me. Someone will pull me aside and say, 'You might want to try a different pair of socks.' It really makes me feel like I'm at home.''
Free fashion advice is just one of the benefits that business hotels like the Fairmont offer. Resorts have been making a special effort to cater to their long-term guests lately, not only by adding perks like grocery shopping, DVD rentals and laundry services at no extra charge, but also by introducing unusual amenities that are not in their brochures. 
 With good reason. By many measures, business trips are getting longer. The average guest at an extended-stay hotel checked in for 15 nights in 2005, up by one night from 2004, according to the Highland Group, a hotel industry consulting firm that specializes in extended-stay lodging.
 A survey of holders of Barclaycard Business cards in Britain found that businesspeople will on average be spending an extra night away from home each month, up from 4.1 nights now, to 5.2 nights by 2015.
 There are many reasons for the apparent increase in the duration of business trips, according to experts. A healthy economy is keeping business travel at record levels. Rising air fares and the delays and frustrations at the security checkpoints are pressing business travelers to extend their stays over a weekend instead of commuting back and forth between a job site, according to experts and business travelers.
 ''Many hotels are making an effort to get to know the individual preferences of their return guests,'' said Debra F. Cannon, director of the school of hospitality at Georgia State University. ''I have heard of rearranging furniture and even letting guests bring in personal items, like artwork, for their stays.''
 The Fairmont Washington, for example, sometimes issues Mr. Breslow the keys to his favorite room, the spacious Georgetown Suite, when he arrives from Dallas. If it is not available, he gets a room with a balcony. His favorite cocktail is waiting for him.
 He is given access to the exclusive gold floor, which serves breakfast in the morning, hors d'oeuvres in the afternoon and chocolate fondue in the evening. And the staff makes sure guests like Mr. Breslow do not miss a meal. On one recent morning, they delivered eggs Benedict to his room when he could not make it to the gold floor lobby in time for breakfast. ''I used to come up to Washington for four days and then fly back to Dallas for the weekend,'' Mr. Breslow said. ''But flying is such a headache now, so why bother? Now I try to plan my meetings so that I can stay for two weeks at a time.''
 Jeff Senior, a senior vice president for marketing and sales at Fairmont Hotels and Resorts, said Mr. Breslow's experience was becoming increasingly common. ''We are seeing a definite trend to longer stays,'' he said. ''In fact, stays today are almost a full day longer, on average, than only three years ago.''
 In response, his hotel staffs have found themselves doing things that were once uncommon, like helping one long-term guest quit smoking or taking care of another guest who had fallen ill by delivering soup to his room and nursing him back to health. Business travelers, he added, are looking for ''a higher level of personal service.''
 Other hotel chains are catering to similar needs of business guests. Extended Stay Hotels, a chain of 680 long-stay properties in North America, offers its long-term business travelers a similar list of services.
 ''We'll find out what a guest's favorite candy is and buy it for them, or notice the type of soda or bottled water that they drink, and then surprise them with a complimentary case,'' said Jennifer Kearney, a spokeswoman for the hotel chain. Some extended-stay guests are even given the cellphone numbers of hotel managers, just in case they need something after hours.
 At Marriott International, which operates Residence Inn and TownePlace Suites -- two brands that cater to long-term guests -- efforts to make extended-stay guests feel more at home have focused on the lobby areas. Laura Bates, a senior vice president for brand management at Marriott's extended-stay and select service brands, said services like grocery shopping are not quite enough to make a hotel feel like home. ''There needs to be a meeting area where they can connect with other guests or associates, or just hang out and relax,'' she said.
 To that end, Residence Inn is planning to overhaul its lobbies next year to build a more inviting public space. The changes will create what Ms. Bates calls a more ''warm and inviting'' area centered on a fireplace, where guests can unwind, watch TV or work in private seating areas called studies. 
 Marriott is also building outdoor deck areas where it will play host to weekly barbecues and receptions.
 At Staybridge Suites, the extended-stay brand owned by the InterContinental Hotels Group, some hotels will add home theaters to their public areas next year. The rooms will feature a big-screen plasma TV and a surround-sound system. 
 Peggy Berg, president of the Highland Group, sees a future with even more adaptations to the needs of long-term guests. ''Guest rooms and baths will get bigger, which is a good thing, since humans are getting bigger,'' she said. ''They'll also offer bigger fitness centers and more by way of lounges and light food service.''
 Industry experts and hotel executives predict that personalized services will grow along with the new amenities. 
 It could even get to the point where the off-the-book offerings make it on to the books, they suggest. Take rearranging the furniture, for instance. At the upscale Langham Hong Kong Hotel, which is part of the Lanham Hotels International chain, guests can ask the hotel to redecorate the room for them and adjust shelves to their preferred height. 
 At the Four Seasons Hotel Miami, moving desks and chairs around is not an unusual request, either. Recently, the hotel created a complete office in one of its rooms for a guest, a lawyer who was working on a trial. 
 ''For now, furniture moving isn't something we would advertise,'' said Eveliny Bastos-Klein, a hotel spokeswoman. ''But you never know what will happen in the future.''

HEADLINE: Chrysler Reports It Has an Unsold Inventory of About 50,000 Vehicles 

BYLINE: By NICK BUNKLEY

DATELINE: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., Oct. 23 

 BODY:
The Chrysler Group said Monday that it had not yet accounted for tens of thousands of cars in its inventory numbers, which are already considered high by industry standards.
 Chrysler said it had routinely excluded these vehicles, worth billions of dollars, from its tally of unsold cars and trucks because they had not yet been assigned to a specific dealer or ordered by a customer.
 While there are no requirements for how automakers report their inventories, the disclosure has frustrated competitors who say they are being more forthright about their struggles. Chrysler says the practice is common, but other automakers say they abandoned it decades ago, after the oil shortages of the 1970's caused inventories to bloat quickly. 
 A Chrysler spokesman, Kevin McCormick, said about 50,000 vehicles were currently unassigned and therefore not included in Chrysler's inventory figures, adding that the number had been as high as 100,000 this summer. 
 At an average price of $25,000 each, those 100,000 vehicles would be worth $2.5 billion. By year's end, Mr. McCormick said, all of the company's unassigned inventory will be gone.
 ''We're actively working with our dealer body to reduce that,'' he said. ''It's a number that's higher than what we would like for it to be.''
 The situation was first reported Monday by Ward's Automotive Reports, an industry trade publication. But it had been no secret this year that Chrysler was overloaded with unsold vehicles. 
 Flights going into and out of Detroit's international airport pass over expansive mosaics of shiny Chrysler, Dodge and Jeep vehicles produced months ago and deposited in parking lots that would otherwise be vacant. Vehicles have also accumulated on lots near Chrysler's Jeep plants in Toledo, Ohio.
 Officially, Chrysler, a division of DaimlerChrysler, reported that it had an 82-day supply of vehicles in inventory at the end of September, amounting to 86,400 passenger cars and 447,000 light trucks. 
 An additional 50,000 vehicles would bring supplies to about 90 days' worth -- more than triple the number that Asian manufacturers like Toyota and Honda keep on hand, and at least a third above the stocks that auto companies routinely keep available during summer months.
 ''That means they've overstated the level of demand for their vehicles,'' said George Pipas, the chief sales analyst for Ford Motor Company. ''The practice that Chrysler has engaged in over the last two years is something this industry did 25 years ago. It's a practice that we have not engaged in since then.''
 Ford only builds vehicles after they have been ordered by dealers, Mr. Pipas said. General Motors said it occasionally ran assembly lines without specific dealers in mind, for example when new vehicles were introduced. But a company spokesman, John M. McDonald, said every unsold vehicle was included in monthly inventory reports. Currently, he added, G.M. has no unassigned vehicles.
 ''They are all accounted for in the inventory numbers one way or another,'' Mr. McDonald said. ''We don't have any vehicles sitting around not accounted for.''
 G.M. said it had about a million surplus vehicles at the end of September, and Ford reported an inventory of 655,000. About 70 percent of those vehicles were trucks.
 Both companies are much larger than Chrysler, however.
 This is not the first surprise from Chrysler recently. In September, it revealed that, rather than losing $600 million in the third quarter as it had previously projected, it now expects to lose as much as $1.5 billion because sales slumped ahead of the introduction of many new models this fall. DaimlerChrysler plans to report its earnings on Wednesday.
 Chrysler executives admitted they reacted too slowly to shifting consumer demands in light of rising gasoline prices and that they thought deep discounts offered over the summer would keep inventories in check -- an assumption that proved incorrect. 
 One of the first steps taken by Lee Iacocca when he joined Chrysler in 1978 was to begin to deplete the company's order bank which had reached 100,000 vehicles in the late 1970's, after a series of gasoline shortages. 
 ''At a time when cash was dwindling and interest rates were soaring, the costs of carrying this inventory were astronomical,'' Mr. Iacocca wrote in his best-selling 1984 autobiography. ''Even worse, the cars were just sitting there in the great outdoors and slowly deteriorating.''
 Ron Pinelli, president of the Autodata Corporation, an industry statistics firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said he paid more attention to sales figures and production levels to gauge an automaker's health. But inventory levels are a factor in analysts' impressions of an automaker, Mr. Pinelli said.
 And while the precise level of inventories may not be a critical statistic, Mr. Pinelli said, most people would assume inventory reports to be valid -- especially after Chrysler's image was tarnished by the practice decades ago. Mr. Iacocca, for his part, argued that the order bank was ''destroying the company'' and said that the words ''order bank'' should be struck from Chrysler's corporate vocabulary.

HEADLINE: Iraq And Your Wallet

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

 BODY:
For every additional second we stay in Iraq, we taxpayers will end up paying an additional $6,300.
 So aside from the rising body counts and all the other good reasons to adopt a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq, here's another: We are spending vast sums there that would be better spent rescuing the American health care system, developing alternative forms of energy and making a serious effort to reduce global poverty.
In the run-up to the Iraq war, Donald Rumsfeld estimated that the overall cost would be under $50 billion. Paul Wolfowitz argued that Iraq could use its oil to ''finance its own reconstruction.'' 
 But now several careful studies have attempted to tote up various costs, and they suggest that the tab will be more than $1 trillion -- perhaps more than $2 trillion. The higher sum would amount to $6,600 per American man, woman and child. 
 ''The total costs of the war, including the budgetary, social and macroeconomic costs, are likely to exceed $2 trillion,'' Joseph Stiglitz, the Nobel-winning economist at Columbia, writes in an updated new study with Linda Bilmes, a public finance specialist at Harvard. Their report has just appeared in the Milken Institute Review, as an update on a paper presented earlier this year.
 Just to put that $2 trillion in perspective, it is four times the additional cost needed to provide health insurance for all uninsured Americans for the next decade. It is 1,600 times Mr. Bush's financing for his vaunted hydrogen energy project.
 Another study, by two economists at the American Enterprise Institute, used somewhat different assumptions and came up with a lower figure -- about $1 trillion. Those economists set up a nifty Web site, www.aei-brookings.org/iraqcosts, where you can tinker with the underlying assumptions and come up with your own personal estimates.
 Of course, many of the costs are hidden and haven't even been spent yet. For example, more than 3,000 American veterans have suffered severe head injuries in Iraq, and the U.S. government will have to pay for round-the-clock care for many of them for decades. The cost ranges from $600,000 to $5 million per person. 
 Then there are disability payments that will continue for a half-century. Among veterans of the first gulf war -- in which ground combat lasted only 100 hours -- 40 percent ended up receiving disability payments, still costing us $2 billion each year. We don't know how many of today's veterans will claim such benefits, but in the first quarter of this year more people sought care through the Department of Veterans Affairs than the Bush administration had budgeted for the entire year.
 The war has also forced the military to offer re-enlistment bonuses that in exceptional circumstances reach $150,000. Likewise, tanks, helicopters and other battlefield equipment will have to be replaced early, since the Pentagon says they are being worn out at up to six times the peacetime rate.
 The administration didn't raise taxes to pay for the war, so we're financing it by borrowing from China and other countries. Those borrowing costs are estimated to range from $264 billion to $308 billion in interest. 
 Then there are economic costs to the nation as a whole. For example, the price of oil was in the $20- to $30-a-barrel range early in this decade but has now shot up to more than $50, partly because of the drop in Iraq's oil exports and partly because of war-related instability in the Middle East. Professors Stiglitz and Bilmes note that if just $10 of the increase is attributable to the war, that amounts to a $450 billion drag on the economy over six years.
 The bottom line is that not only have we squandered 2,800 American lives and considerable American prestige in Iraq, but we're also paying $18,000 per household to do so.
 We still face the choice of whether to remain in Iraq indefinitely or to impose a timetable and withdraw U.S. troops. These studies suggest that every additional year we keep our troops in Iraq will add $200 billion to our tax bills. 
 My vote would be to spend a chunk of that sum instead fighting malaria, AIDS and maternal mortality, bolstering American schools, and assuring health care for all Americans. We're spending $380,000 for every extra minute we stay in Iraq, and we can find better ways to spend that money.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

HEADLINE: Homecoming Is a Victory, by Any Definition

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

DATELINE: PORT SULPHUR, La., Oct. 21 

 BODY:
Highway 23 is the only road in and out of this marshy peninsula where the Mississippi River runs to the gulf. Early Friday afternoon, the road was shut down for a stretch of two and a half miles by the wail of sirens and flashing lights, to attend to not a disaster but a parade celebrating the first football game played in the lower end of Plaquemines Parish since Hurricane Katrina. 
 Maids on the homecoming court of South Plaquemines High wore gowns and corsages and rode past atop the backseats of convertibles, handing out roses and drinking cups bearing their names. They also tossed beads, candy and stuffed animals to children who scurried along the shoulder of the two-lane blacktop, scooping up the trinkets in plastic bags.
 Stanley Gaudet, the principal at South Plaquemines High, took the stem of a yellow rose and stuck it in his mouth as if he were a flamenco dancer. ''We need this like New Orleans needs Mardi Gras,'' he said. 
 For just a moment along the parade route, it was possible to ignore the Federal Emergency Management Agency trailers and crumbled buildings, the vulnerable levees and uprooted trees, and even the cemetery, where two coffins had floated away in the storm and still waited in their concrete vaults for a proper reburial. Bulldozers, debris-removal trucks and double-wide trailers sat in traffic for more than an hour as another kind of hurricane recovery ran its jubilant course.
 Homecoming was meant to celebrate the resilience of not one devastated town but three -- Port Sulphur, Buras and Boothville-Venice. The ravaged schools in these fishing, citrus and oil-and-gas communities have been consolidated into South Plaquemines High, whose students nicknamed themselves the Hurricanes in a spirit of unity and defiance. 
 After playing their first seven games on the road or at a neutral site, the Hurricanes finally came home Friday and defeated McMain High of New Orleans by 57-0 in a victory that was as emotional as it was thorough.
 ''This is important for the same reason it was important for the Saints to return to the Superdome,'' said Julie Butler, a home economics teacher at South Plaquemines. ''It means we're still here.''
 After losing three of their first four games, the Hurricanes have won three of their last four. A trip to the state playoffs in Class 2A can be secured with a victory over the next opponent, Isidore Newman School of New Orleans. There could not be a starker contrast between two schools.
 Newman is one of Louisiana's elite private schools, the alma mater of such privileged sons as Peyton and Eli Manning. The school sustained some wind damage from Katrina but reopened in January. Officials said enrollment is nearly back to pre-Katrina levels.
 At the newly formed South Plaquemines, classes began in mid-August, but the cafeteria has yet to open and the science lab still awaits test tubes and slides for its microscopes.
 The football team has no locker room or weight room. Until two weeks ago, it traveled 60 miles round-trip each day to practice on a borrowed field. Homecoming, as encouraging as it was, represented only ''the beginning of a new beginning'' in an uncertain recovery, a speaker said at a pregame ceremony to dedicate the new school. In some places in lower Plaquemines, it seems as if Katrina hit yesterday, not 14 months ago. And it is impossible to know what the future holds. For one thing, the federal government has decided not to immediately fortify the levees along Highway 23 to full strength. The cost would be $1.6 billion, and so few people have returned.
 Only 266 students are enrolled in grades 7 through 12 at the consolidated high school. Mona Boutwell, a preschool teacher at adjacent South Plaquemines Elementary, is unsure whether she will keep her son Dylan, a freshman receiver, here beyond this year.
 ''Besides football, what else is there here?'' she said plaintively, sitting in her FEMA trailer near the school. ''There is nothing normal about these kids' lives.''
 Yet football persists as a galvanizing force in these beleaguered communities. When Wayne Williamson Sr. saw the stadium lights being tested Wednesday night, he drove from a nearby trailer park with his son Wayne Jr., a receiver and defensive back.
 ''I just had to look,'' Williamson Sr. said. ''It meant we were getting closer to home.''
 On Friday, Marcelin Ancar wore his letter jacket to homecoming. He had been an all-state center at Port Sulphur High in 1984. Now his two sons, Jordan and Maverick, play for South Plaquemines. The original letter jacket was lost in the hurricane as the Ancars' home was shoved into a canal. A few months after Katrina, Jeanitta Ancar presented her husband with a replica jacket. It brought tears to his eyes.
 ''It was like seeing my kids born, that's how much it touched me,'' Marcelin Ancar said.
 The days before homecoming were called Spirit Week at South Plaquemines High. Students wore cowboy outfits one day, camouflage the next, and the school colors of blue and silver the day of the game. The journalism class printed a thick game program filled with photographs of players and homecoming maids and well-wishes from their families.
 Gaudet, the principal, took care of other necessities, like two cases of insect repellent.
 ''To fight West Nile virus,'' he said, holding up a can in his office Thursday afternoon. Each spectator would be offered a spray as they entered the stadium, he said.
 ''You've got to be prepared in south Plaquemines,'' Gaudet said with a laugh.
 He took it upon himself to order sideline markers when the purchasing agent for the school district was called to serve on the jury of a murder trial. 
 Still, he was worried about a cheap first-down marker and was waiting on a louvered replacement due to arrive by courier a few hours before kickoff. ''I don't want one of those flimsy, flip-up markers,'' Gaudet said. ''I want a Dial-a-Down.''
 He had more urgent concerns, too, namely the stadium lights.
 The temporary buildings of South Plaquemines High are on the campus of the destroyed Port Sulphur High. A 28-foot storm surge and 120-mile-an-hour winds from Katrina swamped the football field, pushing water over the crossbars of the goal posts. The scoreboard was battered, the stadium lights left inoperable. Later, four inches of crushed stone were placed on the field, which served as a staging ground for the national guard.
 The turf was resodded in late August, but it took several weeks to take root. By Thursday, new goal posts and a new scoreboard were in place, but only the stadium lights on the visitor's side were working. On Friday morning, a teacher and a school-board employee spray-painted a hurricane logo at midfield.
 ''It's going to be a race to the finish,'' Gaudet said. ''Everything around here has been a race to the finish.'' 
 By Friday afternoon, on a cool, azure day, knots of people gathered along the highway for the parade. Others sat on lawn chairs or perched on the tailgates of pickup trucks. A few brought their barbecue grills. In the middle of the parade, lights flickered to life on the home side of the field. Wearing a tuxedo and a velvet crown, Dwayne Ancar, the homecoming king, rode past and tossed plastic footballs. He is the anchor of the team's offensive line, but this triumphant moment almost eluded him.
 Like many others, Ancar struggled after the storm. His family scattered ahead of Katrina, and one of his uncles died of cancer before he got to see him again. When the family found its way back to northern Plaquemines Parish,17 or 18 relatives crammed into one house, he said. Ancar's grades slipped and he seemed to lose his temper easily.
 ''I couldn't get comfortable,'' he said.
 He was not the only one. One of the team's starters was suspended for yelling at Coach Cyril Crutchfield during the season opener. Another starter was later suspended for hitting his girlfriend.
 ''There's a lot of pent-up anger in these kids that we don't know about,'' Gaudet said.
 Even football did not provide much relief at first. The Hurricanes were outmanned against much larger schools. Players bickered at each other on the sidelines. Ancar said he nearly quit.
 ''I didn't think the team cared about winning,'' he said. ''Everyone was selfish. Now we're joking with each other and everyone's friendly.''
 As his teammates warmed up for Friday's game, Ancar remained in his tuxedo for the naming of the homecoming queen. Then he hustled into his uniform. The crowd swelled to about 1,100, some of whom had tailgated for hours. At the last minute, the newly ordered first-down marker arrived on the sideline.
 ''Seniors, this is your last homecoming,'' Crutchfield told his players. ''I've been waiting for this for a long time. We're back home. Let's make it count.''
 The Hurricanes fumbled their first snap, but quickly began to dominate. By halftime, they led by 32-0 and spectators danced to throbbing music from the public-address system. 
 In the second half, the celebration became far more engaging than the game. Some of the homecoming maids joined the cheerleaders in the thick sand along the sideline. ''They're cheering in high heels!'' said Maverick Ancar, an eighth-grade receiver.
 Afterward, the players knelt at midfield. Patrick Sylve, a senior running back, said everything finally felt as it should feel. Then he yelled to his teammates, ''Pool party at the river, everybody invited.''
 Tired and satisfied, Crutchfield sat outside his office and watched as traffic inched from the parking lot.
 ''This is what people have been waiting for,'' he said. ''A year ago, there was nothing. People have been wanting to come home, looking for some place to go on Friday night.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Dwayne Ancar, South Plaquemines's homecoming king, said anger and frustration nearly led him to quit the football team this season. (Photo by Cheryl Gerber for The New York Times)(pg. D1)
Three schools combined to form South Plaquemines High, where only 266 students were enrolled in grades 7 through 12. Kevin Smith and his teammates have won four of eight games. A playoff berth is still possible.
 Hurricane Katrina's storm surge lifted the water level higher than the crossbar at what was then Port Sulphur High. (Photographs by Cheryl Gerber for The New York Times)(pg. D6)

HEADLINE: Suspect Charged in Bronx Triple Murder

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE and KATE MEYER; Al Baker and Rebecca Cathcart contributed reporting.

 BODY:
A 38-year-old Bronx man was arrested last night and charged with bludgeoning three people to death, including his companion and her son, in the basement of the family's apartment building, the police said. A bloody dumbbell and metal pipe found at the scene are believed to be the murder weapons, they said.
 The three victims, who also included a 60-year-old man who was filling in as a superintendent, were found shortly before noon yesterday in the building where the couple and her son had lived, a few blocks south of Crotona Park. 
The police said they believed that the man, Rafin Vellon, had killed his companion, Gloria Valdez, 56, and her 36-year-old son, Carl Valdez, in their basement apartment, and that the other victim, Polonio Peralta, was attacked later in a basement hallway, perhaps after he encountered the killer on his way out.
 Mr. Vellon was charged with three counts of second-degree murder. As he was led out of the 41st Precinct station house last night, wearing a gray sweatshirt, he stared straight ahead and did not respond to reporters' questions.
 All three victims had been beaten severely on the head, investigators said. The Valdezes were found dead in their apartment, the police said, and Mr. Peralta was taken to St. Barnabas Hospital, where he later died. A number of bloodied objects were found at the scene, including the dumbbell and the metal pipe, and investigators believe that they were the weapons used, the police said. 
 Three weeks ago, investigators said, Mr. Vellon was accused of using a similar weapon in a violent rampage at a car service office. He was arrested on a charge of criminal mischief on Oct. 2, suspected of using a five-pound free weight to break windows around the car service, Mega-Radio Dispatch at 951 Westchester Avenue in the Bronx, the police said. He is accused of bashing in the front door of the office along with some car windshields in the area. He has also been charged with assault in a previous case, the police said.
 T. J. Trinidad, an employee of Mega-Radio, said last night in a telephone interview that he was at the office on Oct. 2 when a woman came in crying. ''She was out of breath and she was tearing a lot,'' he said. ''She asked for a cab quick, the quickest cab she could have.''
 About four or five hours after she left, an enraged man came into the office. ''The reason he was supposedly mad was because we supplied the cab service for his girlfriend to leave,'' Mr. Trinidad said. ''He broke the main entrance door, the window right next to the main entrance door, and the radio dispatcher glass -- the one in front of the computers.
 ''After that, he went outside and went on a wild rampage. He broke the windshields of about seven cars,'' he said. ''He had a butterfly knife and slashed the tires of every car of which windshield he bashed.''
 The car service office is a few blocks from the building where the killings took place, at 1029 Hall Place. The police said Mr. Peralta was found by a maintenance worker who had gone downstairs to get some tools. 
 Mr. Peralta had been filling in for the building's superintendent, Rafael Diaz, while he was in the Dominican Republic for the month, said Jose Romero, Mr. Peralta's grandnephew, who lives in the neighborhood. Mr. Peralta was a retired construction worker living in Philadelphia who came up to help out. ''He didn't even work here,'' Mr. Romero said. ''He was just doing someone a favor.'' 
 The Valdezes were discovered later by investigators when they arrived at the building, and found that it had been carved up into a mazelike warren of single-room apartments. The basement also was a storage area for tools and contained the superintendent's residence.
 Mr. Vellon and the Valdezes moved into the building last year, said Lydia Colon, a neighbor. They mainly kept to themselves, she said, being newcomers in a neighborhood where families had lived for multiple generations. 
 Neighbors remembered Mr. Valdez as being hungry for company. ''Every time he talked to someone, he would talk your ear off because he didn't have many friends. It was the same with his mother,'' said Ms. Colon, who said she was one of the few residents who talked to them regularly. The two were often seen walking their Chihuahua, Taco, around the block. 
 Ms. Colon said that she clearly felt the tension between Mr. Vellon and Ms. Valdez one day when the two women were talking. ''We were standing in front of the building one day and talking and all of a sudden a big guy came out of a cab,'' she said. ''He had a very solemn face, sort of serious and tough. Her whole tune changed. She seemed really nervous. She introduced him as her husband. He was scary. I didn't like to talk to him.''
 Neighbors said Ms. Valdez had a distinctive style. She often wore summer dresses on top of dresses, even in the winter, residents said. ''It was her fashion sense. It was a really strange fashion sense,'' said Ms. Colon.
 One of her favorite dress combinations was a combination of a stretchy black and purple striped dress layered with a red dress with orange butterflies, Ms. Colon said. Mr. Valdez was known for practicing martial arts near the building, and had earned the nicknames Ninja Boy and the Karate Kid. ''He would always be dressed up like some samurai carrying swords,'' said Luis Reyes, 29, a resident of the building. ''I feel sorry for the Karate Kid; that kid was gentle,'' Mr. Reyes said. ''He wasn't trying to hurt anybody.'' He was also a big fan of the movie ''Scarface,'' boxing and a cartoon called ''Naruto.''
 Ms. Valdez and her son were both unemployed, but scraped together a living from government disability checks and selling odds and ends, neighbors said. Ms. Colon said her last interaction with Mr. Valdez had been helping him sell ''Scarface'' collector sets. ''He said he had bought them for $25 and that he was trying to sell them for $20 and I said: 'No, no, honey. You have to sell them for more than you bought them for.' ''
 She also advised him, ''Shine them up so they look good.'' The sets eventually sold.

PERSON: John Victor Murra 

HEADLINE: John V. Murra, 90, Professor Who Recast Image of Incas

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
John V. Murra, a professor of anthropology who culled voluminous Spanish colonial archives for research that reshaped the image of the Incas and their vast South American empire, died on Oct. 16 at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 90. 
 The death was confirmed by Blaine Friedlander, a spokesman for Cornell University, where Professor Murra taught from 1968 until his retirement in 1982.
''Before he came along, the image of the Incas was one of barbaric splendor,'' said Frank Salomon, the John V. Murra professor of anthropology at the University of Wisconsin-Madison. But Professor Murra's work ''forged a radically new image'' of that empire, Professor Salomon said -- one based on an intricate and often ceremonial exchange of produce as gifts among tribal kinfolk. They hiked from the edges of the rain forest to meet those living at the heights of the Andes, ensuring each other's survival by trading key lowland crops like maize and potatoes for scarce mountain goods like llama and alpaca wool. That economic system was named ''the vertical archipelago'' by Professor Murra.
 ''His 'vertical archipelago' model has been verified through research that archaeologists have since done in the Andean zone,'' said Heather Lechtman, a professor of archaeology and ancient technology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While some experts debate aspects of the theory, Professor Lechtman said, ''This is certainly the accepted model for the central Andes.''
 The Inca empire existed from about 1400 to 1535 in an area that now includes Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia and parts of Colombia, Argentina and Chile. What largely held it together, until the Spanish invasion in 1532, was its unusual economic system. The social system was documented by Professor Murra with his search through colonial archives and court documents in which the words of Incas were recorded.
 Born Isak Lipschitz on Aug. 24, 1916, in Odessa, Ukraine, John Victor Murra changed his name after emigrating to the United States in 1934. Two years later, he joined the republican forces fighting in the Spanish Civil War against the dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco. By then, he had completed undergraduate studies begun in Europe, earning a degree in sociology at the University of Chicago. He later turned to anthropology, receiving a master's in 1942 and a Ph.D. in 1956, both also at the University of Chicago.
 Professor Murra taught at the University of Puerto Rico from 1947 to 1950; at Vassar from 1950 to 1961; at Yale from 1962 to 1963; at Universidad de San Marcos in Lima, Peru, from 1964 to 1966, and then at Cornell. Twice married and divorced, he left no immediate surviving family members.
 It was Professor Murra's participation in the Spanish Civil War that forced him into his archival research. ''The U.S. State Department in the McCarthy years denied him a passport,'' Professor Salomon said. ''So, frustrated in the first thing an anthropologist does -- field work -- he dived into the chronicles of the Spanish Viceroyalty of Peru to examine the Inca past.'' Professor Murra was finally granted a passport in 1956.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 2, 2006

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Oct. 23 about John V. Murra, an anthropologist who was an expert in the economy of the Incas, incorrectly described the position of the republican forces in the Spanish Civil War, which Mr. Murra joined in 1936. At the time, they were supporting the legitimate government of Spain against Gen. Francisco Franco. They were not rebelling against his dictatorship, which was not established until after the republicans were defeated.
